choices.text: 35 days and 42 days
21 days and 35 days
28 days and 45 days
35 days and 28 days

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct storage period when phosphate added to acid citrate dextrose (ACD) and when phosphate and adenine together added to ACD: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 21 days and 35 days

 

Explanation

 

The storage period when adding phosphate alone to ACD would be 21 days and when adding adenine and phosphate together would be 35 days.

 

ACD was developed into CPD (citrate-phosphate-dextrose) version with phosphate added intended to reduce phosphate leakage from red blood cells. It does not improve shelf life appreciably, but patient recovery is improved.

 

CPD with adenine (CPDA-1), which boosted RBC survival by improving ATP synthesis of RBCs to five weeks when combined with plastic bags.

 

CPD, in combination with adenine-mannitol additives such as SAGM, is the current blood bank preservative as of 2012.

 

RBC hemolysis, thus increasing the storage period to 42 days.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phosphate alone added to ACD allows for a blood storage period of 21 days, while the addition of both phosphate and adenine (as in CPDA-1) extends the storage period to 35 days, reflecting improvements in RBC viability through enhanced ATP synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is known to be associated with the development of bladder carcinoma? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cyclophosphamide

 

Explanation:

 

Cyclophosphamide is a chemotherapeutic agent used to treat various cancers and autoimmune diseases. One of its known side effects is the increased risk of developing bladder carcinoma. This is due to the metabolite acrolein, which can cause urothelial damage leading to malignancy. Long-term use or high doses of cyclophosphamide significantly elevate this risk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cisplatin: Cisplatin is a chemotherapy drug effective against various cancers, including testicular, ovarian, and bladder cancer. However, it is not specifically associated with the development of bladder carcinoma as a side effect.

 

Option C. Taxane (e.g., paclitaxel, docetaxel): Taxanes are chemotherapeutic agents used in treating breast, ovarian, and lung cancers. They are not linked to bladder carcinoma development.

 

Option D. Tamoxifen: Tamoxifen is primarily used to treat breast cancer. While it can increase the risk of endometrial cancer due to its estrogen-like effects on uterine tissue, it is not associated with an increased risk of bladder cancer.

 

Additional Information on Drugs Associated with Bladder Cancer: Several drugs have been associated with an increased risk of bladder cancer, including:

  • Pioglitazone: A drug used to treat type 2 diabetes.
  • Aristolochic acid: Found in some herbal remedies.
  • Phenacetin: An analgesic and antipyretic.
  • Aminosalicylates: Used in the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyclophosphamide is a chemotherapeutic agent known to be associated with the development of bladder carcinoma due to its metabolite acrolein, which can damage the bladder lining.

choices.text: Seen in 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD
Increases risk of squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: All are true about Barrett esophagus except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increases risk of squamous cell carcinoma

 

Not squamous cell carcinoma, but esophageal adenocarcinoma is the cancer risk that is increased by Barrett's esophagus.

 

Barrett's esophagus is a premalignant condition.

 

Barrett's epithelium (columnar metaplasia), dysplasia, carcinoma in situ, and esophageal adenocarcinoma develop sequentially from one another.

 

Microscopically, goblet cells are shown to have taken the place of the squamous esophageal epithelium (intestinal metaplasia).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complication of chronic GERD: True, as Barrett’s esophagus commonly develops as a response to the damage from chronic acid reflux.

 

Option B. Seen in 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD: True, as approximately 10% of GERD patients develop Barrett's esophagus.

 

Option D. Intestinal metaplasia: True, and is a defining characteristic of Barrett’s esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barrett’s esophagus increases the risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma due to the transformation of squamous cells to columnar cells, not squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: Osborn waves in ECG are seen in: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hypothermia

 

Osborn waves, also known as J-waves, are characteristic findings on an ECG that are typically associated with hypothermia. These waves appear as a positive deflection at the J point (the junction between the end of the QRS complex and the beginning of the ST segment) and are most evident in moderate to severe cases of hypothermia. The appearance of Osborn waves is thought to be caused by a disparity in the action potential durations between the epicardial and endocardial surfaces of the heart during ventricular repolarization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism: This condition does not typically cause Osborn waves. Instead, hypothyroidism can lead to other ECG changes such as bradycardia, low voltage, and possibly prolonged QT interval.

 

Option C. Hypocalcemia: This typically leads to a prolonged QT interval but does not cause Osborn waves.

 

Option D. Hypokalemia: While hypokalemia can cause significant ECG changes, including U waves, flattened T waves, and ST depression, it is not associated with Osborn waves.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

J-wave or Osborn wave is seen in cases of moderate or severe hypothermia due to increase in the epicardial potassium current relative to that of endocardium during ventricular repolarization.

choices.text: Obtaining sexual pleasure by wearing clothes of opposite sex
Desire to seek surgery to become member of opposite sex
Sexual gratification by rubbing his private parts against another person
Exposure of one's genitals to an unsuspecting stranger

questions.text: Frotteurism is defined as: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sexual gratification by rubbing his private parts against another person

 

Frotteurism involves the act of touching or rubbing one's genitals against another non-consenting individual in a sexual manner, to attain sexual gratification.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Obtaining sexual pleasure by wearing clothes of opposite sex

 

  • Term: Eonism (also known as Transvestism)
  • Description: Involves obtaining sexual pleasure or emotional satisfaction by wearing clothes traditionally associated with the opposite sex.

 

Option B. Desire to seek surgery to become a member of opposite sex

 

  • Term: Transsexualism
  • Description: Involves a strong desire to undergo surgery to change one's biological sex to align with one's gender identity.

 

Option D. Exposure of one's genitals to an unsuspecting stranger

 

  • Term: Exhibitionism
  • Description: Involves exposing one's genitals to an unsuspecting stranger for sexual gratification. This behavior is typically intended to shock or arouse the observer.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Act of rubbing one's genitals against another person without their consent to achieve sexual arousal or gratification - Frotteurism
  • Obtaining sexual pleasure by wearing clothes of opposite sex – Eonism
  • Desire to seek surgery to become member of opposite sex - Transsexualism
  • Exposure of one's genitals to an unsuspecting stranger- Exhibitionism

choices.text: Herpes-simplex virus

questions.text: Punched-out ulcers in the esophagus are caused by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes-simplex virus

 

Infection with the Herpes simplex virus (HS) causes punched-out ulcers in the esophagus.

 

Immunocompromised patients are more likely to develop HS esophagitis.

 

Endoscopic findings may include multiple discrete or coalescent small ulcers that appear superficial, punched out, or volcano-like.

 

 

For diagnosis, the biopsy sample should be taken from the edge of the ulcer. The following microscopic findings are seen here:

 

  • Ballooning degeneration
  • Ground-glass changes in nuclei
  • Infected squamous epithelial cells show 3 M’s:
    • Molding of nuclear contours
    • Margination of chromatin to the periphery of nuclei
    • Multinucleation
  • Intranuclear inclusions:
    • Cowdry type A: acidophilic inclusion with surrounding clear halo
    • Equivocal cases require an HSV immunohistochemical (IHC) stain to confirm the diagnosis

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cytomegalovirus (CMV): Causes larger, shallow ulcers and might involve deeper tissue layers, with "owl's eye" inclusions typically seen.

 

Option C. Candida: Presents typically as white plaques or linear fissures rather than punched-out ulcers.

 

Option D. Acid: Causes erosive esophagitis with continuous areas of inflammation rather than discrete ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes simplex virus causes distinctive punched-out ulcers in the esophagus, particularly noted in immunocompromised patients, diagnosed by endoscopic appearance and confirmed via histopathological findings.

questions.text: Flask shaped ulcers in the colon are caused by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Entameoba histolytica

 

Flask shaped ulcers are classically seen in amoebiasis caused by Entamoeba histolytica.

 

 

The most typical form of amoebic infection, amoebic colitis, starts as a tiny region of necrosis of mucosa that may ulcerate. These ulcerative lesions may grow, develop ulcer edge undermining from trophozoite lytic action, and have a necrotic bed. Due to their structure, such chronic amoebic ulcers are called flask-shaped ulcers (narrow neck and broad base). In addition to the presence of Entamoeba histolytica trophozoites, the ulcer's edge exhibits an inflammatory response with an admixture of polymorphonuclear and mononuclear cells.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Giardia lamblia: Causes giardiasis, affecting the small intestine and leading to malabsorption and diarrhea but not flask-shaped ulcers.

 

Option C. Helicobacter pylori: Associated with gastric and duodenal ulcers, not typically flask-shaped or located in the colon.

 

Option D. Entamoeba vermicularis: Incorrect nomenclature; possibly meant to refer to a helminth such as Enterobius vermicularis, which causes pinworm infections and does not lead to ulcer formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entamoeba histolytica is the cause of flask-shaped ulcers in the colon, distinguishing it from other intestinal pathogens due to its invasive capabilities and the characteristic morphology of the ulcers it creates. Understanding these features helps in the differential diagnosis of dysentery and guides appropriate treatment and management strategies.

questions.text: Which of the following is measured by the device shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oxygen saturation

 

  • Oxygen saturation (often referred to as SpO2) is the percentage of oxygen-saturated hemoglobin relative to the total hemoglobin (unsaturated + saturated) in the blood.
  • The device measures this by non-invasively detecting the color change in blood as it binds oxygen.
  • The image displays a reading of "98%", which is consistent with an SpO2 reading. Thus, this option is correct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oxygen content of the blood:

 

  • This refers to the amount of oxygen bound to hemoglobin in the blood plus any oxygen dissolved directly in the blood.
  • Pulse oximeters do not measure the total oxygen content of the blood. They only measure the percentage of oxygen-saturated hemoglobin.

 

Option C. Partial pressure of oxygen:

 

  • Partial pressure of oxygen (often referred to as PaO2) is the pressure exerted by oxygen in the blood. It's typically measured using an arterial blood gas analysis.
  • Pulse oximeters do not measure PaO2.

 

Option D. Amount of inspired oxygen:

 

  • This refers to the concentration of oxygen that a person is inhaling, often given as a percentage or fraction (FiO2).
  • Pulse oximeters do not measure the amount of inspired oxygen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pulse oximetry measures the oxygen saturation (SpO2) of hemoglobin in the blood using the principles of Beer Lambert’s law and plethysmography.

questions.text: What is the treatment of ptosis caused by Horner's syndrome? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Fasanella servat operation

 

  • The affected muscle in Horner’s syndrome is Muller's muscle, a sympathetic muscle present in the eyelid responsible for upper eyelid retraction during sympathetic stimulation. 
  • In Fasanella servat surgery, the muller’s muscle is shortened and strengthened. 
    In the other two options, levator resection and frontalis sling surgery, Muller's muscle remains intact. 
  • Thus, if asked specifically for Horner’s syndrome, even if the grade of ptosis is not mentioned, Fasanella servat operation would be the better choice to answer.
  • Here the examiner is testing your knowledge about the pathogenesis of Horner’s syndrome and the involvement of Muller's muscle. 
  • Fasanella servat operation is done for mild ptosis (< 2 mm) caused by Horner's syndrome.

 

 

Horner's syndrome is a oculosympathetic syndrome characterized by a specific set of symptoms that typically occur on one side of the face and include:

 

  1. Ptosis: Ptosis occurs because the sympathetic nerves that control the Muller’s muscle, a modification of Levator Palpebrae Superioris, involved in elevation of the eyelid are affected.
  2. Miosis:  Dissenervation of the dilator papillae (supplied by the sympathetic system) leads to miosis.
  3. Anhidrosis: This refers to a decreased ability to sweat on the affected side of the face.
  4. Pseudo-enophthalmos
  5. Hyperemia – due to disenervation of vasomotor fibers.

 

 

Other options

 

Option A. Levator resection: Used for moderate to severe ptosis, not typically indicated for the mild ptosis seen in Horner's syndrome.

 

Option B. Frontalis sling operation: Reserved for severe ptosis with poor or no levator function, which is not typical in Horner's syndrome where levator function is usually preserved.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Fasanella-Servat operation is the appropriate surgical treatment for mild ptosis caused by Horner's syndrome, characterized by ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis due to sympathetic nerve disruption.

choices.text: Fingers are held in mild extension
Most common involvement is index finger

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding De Quervain's tenosynovitis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It affects APL and EPB

 

De Quervain's tenosynovitis involves inflammation of the sheaths of the extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) and abductor pollicis longus (APL) tendons. These tendons run side by side and are located on the radial side of the wrist, traveling through a tunnel (sheath) that can become narrowed due to the inflammation, causing pain especially with thumb and wrist movement.

 

 

Finkelstein's test: On grasping the patient's thumb and quickly abducting the hand ulnar ward, the pain over the radial styloid tip is excruciating. It's the most pathognomonic objective sign but is also seen in other conditions like radial nerve entrapment and arthritis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fingers are held in mild extension: This statement is not typically associated with De Quervain's tenosynovitis. Instead, the thumb is often held in a position of abduction away from the hand to minimize pain. The condition mainly affects the tendons and their sheaths at the base of the thumb, not the fingers.

 

Option C. Most common involvement is index finger: This is incorrect. De Quervain's tenosynovitis primarily affects the base of the thumb. While pain can radiate and might be felt in the nearby areas, including the forearm or even the index finger, the primary site of involvement is the tendons at the thumb's base, not the index finger itself.

 

Option D. Treatment is surgery: While surgery can be an option for De Quervain's tenosynovitis, it is generally considered when conservative treatments fail. Most cases of De Quervain's can be treated conservatively with methods such as: Rest and immobilization using splints, Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for pain and inflammation , Corticosteroid injections into the tendon sheath to reduce inflammation and Physical therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: John, a 55-year-old man, visits his primary care physician due to progressively worsening symptoms of difficulty swallowing and chest pain over the past few weeks. The physician refers John for an esophageal endoscopy to investigate the cause of his symptoms. During the endoscopy, the gastroenterologist observes serpiginous ulcers in John's esophagus. What is the likely diagnosis indicated by these findings?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. CMV esophagitis

 

Explanation:

 

CMV (Cytomegalovirus) esophagitis is an infection of the esophagus caused by the Cytomegalovirus. It predominantly affects immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS or transplant recipients. The characteristic endoscopic finding in CMV esophagitis is the presence of large, linear or serpiginous (snake-like) ulcers, often located in the distal esophagus. These ulcers typically have well-defined edges and are surrounded by relatively normal mucosa, which helps to differentiate them from other types of esophagitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Candida Esophagitis: Candida esophagitis is a fungal infection caused by Candida species, most commonly Candida albicans. It is common in immunocompromised patients or those on prolonged antibiotics or inhaled steroids. Endoscopic findings typically show white-yellow plaques or patches that can be scraped off, often described as having a "cottage cheese-like" appearance, rather than serpiginous ulcers.

 

Option C. Herpetic Esophagitis: Herpetic esophagitis is caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV) and can affect both immunocompromised and immunocompetent individuals. It is characterized by odynophagia (painful swallowing) and dysphagia (difficulty swallowing). Endoscopically, herpetic esophagitis usually presents with small, well-circumscribed ulcers that resemble "volcano-like" or "punched-out" lesions, which are different from the serpiginous ulcers seen in CMV esophagitis.

 

Option D. Radiation Esophagitis: Radiation esophagitis is a side effect of radiation therapy, particularly for cancers in the chest area, such as lung cancer. It manifests with symptoms like pain, difficulty swallowing, and a sensation of something stuck in the throat. Endoscopic findings may include mucosal redness, swelling, and non-specific ulcerations, but not the distinct serpiginous ulcers typical of CMV esophagitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serpiginous ulcers in the esophagus observed during endoscopy are characteristic of CMV esophagitis, especially in immunocompromised patients. This feature helps differentiate it from other forms of esophagitis such as Candida, herpetic, and radiation-induced esophagitis.

questions.text: Liver synthesizes all of the following except:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Immunoglobulins

 

Explanation

 

Immunoglobulins are produced by plasma cells.

 

Essentially all the albumin and fibrinogen of the plasma proteins, as well as 50 to 80 per cent of the globulins, are formed in the liver. The remainder of the globulins are formed almost entirely in the lymphoid tissues. They are mainly the gamma globulins that constitute the antibodies used in the immune system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Albumin: Exclusion, as albumin is a major protein synthesized by the liver, which is the most abundant protein in plasma, playing crucial roles in maintaining osmotic pressure and transporting substances such as drugs and hormones.

 

Option B. Coagulation factors: Exclusion, as these are primarily produced by the liver, including factors such as prothrombin and fibrinogen.

 

Option C. Acute phase proteins: Exclusion, as the liver significantly ramps up production of these proteins in response to inflammation or infection (like C-reactive protein (CRP) and serum amyloid A (SAA), which play roles in modulating the immune response and inflammation).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Common plasma proteins synthesized by the liver are:

 

  • Albumin
  • Coagulation/clotting factors
  • Acute-phase proteins
  • Steroid binding and other hormone-binding proteins

questions.text: What will be the level of the anti-Mullerian hormone in low ovarian reserve? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) <1

 

Explanation:

 

Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is a glycoprotein produced by the granulosa cells of small pre-antral follicles. It serves as a marker for ovarian reserve, reflecting the remaining egg supply in the ovaries.

 

  • AMH in Low Ovarian Reserve: In cases of low ovarian reserve, the AMH level will be less than 1 ng/mL. This indicates a diminished number of remaining follicles and a reduced capacity for fertility.
  • AMH in Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS): Women with PCOS typically have increased levels of AMH due to the presence of a higher number of small antral follicles.

 

Tests for Ovarian Reserve

 

  1. Biochemical Tests:
    • FSH (Follicle-Stimulating Hormone): Levels measured on Day 2 or 3 of the menstrual cycle are increased in poor ovarian reserve.
    • Estradiol: Day 2 levels are increased in poor ovarian reserve.
    • Inhibin B: Levels are reduced in poor ovarian reserve.
    • AMH: Levels are reduced in poor ovarian reserve.
  2. Ultrasound:
    • Antral Follicle Count (AFC): Done on day 2 or 3 of the cycle. The total number of visible follicles are counted. An AFC greater than 10 is considered normal.
  3. Clomiphene Citrate Challenge Test: This test evaluates ovarian reserve by measuring FSH levels before and after administration of clomiphene citrate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 1-4: Levels of AMH within this range might be seen in women with a moderate ovarian reserve. It is not indicative of low ovarian reserve.

 

Option C. >7: High levels of AMH are often associated with PCOS, where there is an increased number of small antral follicles.

 

Option D. >10: Extremely high AMH levels are usually seen in conditions like PCOS and do not indicate low ovarian reserve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) levels less than 1 ng/mL are indicative of low ovarian reserve.

 

Ref: Page 437, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: A baby assessed 5 minutes after birth, is found to be cyanosed with irregular gasping respiration. Heart rate is 60 beats/min, and a grimace is seen with some flexion of extremities. The Apgar score for this newborn is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

 

 

In this baby:

 

  • Color, blue - score 0
  • Heart rate, <100 beats/min - score 1
  • Grimace- score 1
  • Some flexion of the extremities - score 1
  • Irregular respiration - score 1

 

Thus the total score is 4.

 

Apgar score is not used to guide resuscitation, and resuscitation must be initiated before the 1-minute score. The change of score at sequential time points following birth reflects how well the baby is responding to resuscitative efforts.

 

A total score of 10 indicates that the infant is in the best possible condition. An infant with a score of 0-3 requires immediate resuscitation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An Apgar score is calculated based on five criteria, each ranging from 0 to 2. A score of 0-3 indicates severe distress, 4-6 indicates moderate difficulty, and 7-10 indicates that the newborn is in good health. The described baby, with a total score of 4, requires close monitoring and possibly further medical intervention.

choices.text: Duration of action is longer than filgrastim
Added advantage is that it can be taken orally
It is contraindicated in patients with sickle cell anemia
It is not effective in the treatment of severe neutropenia

questions.text: Which of the following is true about pegylated-filgrastim? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Duration of action is longer than filgrastim

 

  • Pegylated-filgrastim, also known as peg-filgrastim, is a long-acting formulation of filgrastim that is used to stimulate the production of white blood cells in patients receiving chemotherapy. The addition of polyethylene glycol (PEG) to filgrastim increases its molecular weight and slows down its clearance from the body, resulting in a longer duration of action compared to normal filgrastim.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Added advantage is that it can be taken orally:  Pegylated-filgrastim cannot be taken orally, as it is administered by injection.

 

Option C. It is contraindicated in patients with sickle cell anemia: Pegylated-filgrastim is not contraindicated in sickle cell patients, but caution should be exercised as it can stimulate the production of white blood cells, increasing the risk of sickling crises.

 

Option D. It is not effective in the treatment of severe neutropenia: Pegylated-filgrastim is effective in the treatment of severe neutropenia and can help to reduce the risk of infection in patients undergoing chemotherapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pegylated-filgrastim has a longer duration of action than regular filgrastim due to its pegylation, which slows its clearance from the body. It is effective in the treatment of severe neutropenia and is administered by injection, not orally. While not contraindicated in sickle cell anemia, caution is advised due to the potential risk of stimulating white blood cell production and increasing the risk of sickling crises.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the following MRI scan:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cerebellum

 

Explanation:

 

The given image shows an MRI of the sagittal section of the brain, where the red arrow points to the Cerebellum. This part of the brain is known for its role in motor control, and it can also be involved in some cognitive functions like attention and language.

 

Key features visible in the MRI that help identify the Cerebellum include its characteristic lobulated structure located at the posterior base of the brain, just below the cerebrum and behind the brainstem and fourth ventricle.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midbrain: Part of the brainstem, located higher and anteriorly relative to the cerebellum on sagittal images.

 

Option C. Brainstem: The brainstem, which includes the midbrain, pons, and medulla, is located anteriorly to the cerebellum in the image.

 

Option D. Cerebrum: The largest part of the brain, covering most of the upper sections of the image, involved in various higher-order functions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Cerebellum, distinct in its appearance and location in the posterior aspect of the brain, plays crucial roles in the coordination of voluntary movements and motor functions, which can be clearly seen on sagittal MRI scans.

questions.text: Which type of virus is rubella? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Togavirus

 

Rubella belongs to the Togaviridae family.

 

Rubella (German measles)

 

  • Causative organism belongs to family Togaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Incubation period: 2-3 weeks
  • Rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post infectious thrombocytopenia
  • Most serious complication: Encephalitis
  • Vaccination: 27/3 live attenuated

 

Congenital rubella syndrome:

 

  • When a woman in the 1st trimester gets infected with rubella, the resulting complications may include miscarriage, fetal death, premature delivery, or live birth with congenital defects.
  • The commonest malformations caused by rubella are cardiac defects, cataract, and deafness, which constitute the classical congenital rubella syndrome.
  • Thrombocytopenic purpura present in the babies gave rise to the term "blueberry muffin syndrome."

 

Expanded rubella syndrome:

 

  • Some babies present with several other features like hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenic purpura, myocarditis, and bone lesions constituting the expanded rubella syndrome.
  • This term also refers to a baby with metastatic neuroblastoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flavivirus: This group includes viruses like the West Nile virus and Dengue virus, not Rubella.

 

Option C. Paramyxovirus: Includes viruses like measles and mumps, which are clinically distinct from rubella.

 

Option D. Orthomyxovirus: This is the family of viruses that includes the influenza viruses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rubella, commonly known as German measles, is caused by a virus that belongs to the Togaviridae family, specifically the genus Rubivirus. This virus is typically transmitted via respiratory droplets and primarily causes a mild infection characterized by a rash, low fever, and swollen glands. However, its most significant health impact occurs when a pregnant woman is infected, particularly in the first trimester, leading to congenital rubella syndrome.

questions.text: Which Section of the IPC deals with the punishment of perjury? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 193

 

Perjury (false evidence) means intentional making of a false statement by a person who was under a legal obligation (e.g. under oath) to speak the truth.

 

Section 193 IPC (Now, BNS 229): Punishment for Perjury (false evidence). Specifies the punishment for giving false evidence under oath, which can be up to 7 years of imprisonment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 191: Defines the act of giving false evidence under oath but does not specify the punishment. (BNS 227)

 

Option B. 192: Deals with the fabrication of false evidence but not directly related to perjury. (BNS 228)

 

Option D. 197: Deals with issuing false certificates and provides the same punishment as perjury, up to 7 years, but it is not specifically for perjury. (BNS 234)

 

Educational Objective:

 

IPC related to false evidence:

 

191 IPC: Definition of Perjury (false evidence): Giving false evidence under oath

 

193 IPC: Punishment for Perjury (false evidence): up to 7 years

 

197 IPC: Issuing false certificates- same punishment as that of false evidence (upto 7 years)

 

201 IPC: Causing disappearance of evidence of offence or giving false information to screen offender: Upto 07 years. (BNS 238)

questions.text: What percentage of the distribution corresponds to one standard deviation in a normal curve? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 68%

 

Approximately 68% of the distribution corresponds to one standard deviation in a normal curve.

 

In a Normal/Gaussian/Standard Distribution curve,

 

1. B/L Symmetrical Bell shaped curve

2. Mean = Median = Mode à Known as coincidence

3. If Mean = 0 in Normal Distribution, then SD is 1

4. Mean ± 1SD à Covers 68% value [68.3%]

5. Mean ± 2SD à Covers 95% value [95.4%]

6. Mean ± 3SD à Covers 99% value [99.7%]

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Approximately 68% of the data in a normal distribution lies within one standard deviation (±1σ) from the mean.

choices.text: Porta hepatis and inferior vena cava
Right and left lobe of liver

questions.text: Cholecysto-vena caval line passes through? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Gallbladder and inferior vena cava

 

  • The cholecysto-vena caval line (Cantlie line) considered as true mid line of liver.
  • The Cantlie line is a fictitious line that divides the liver into two parts.
  • It contains the middle hepatic vein and extends from the midpoint of the gallbladder fossa at the inferior margin of the liver to the midpoint of the groove for inferior vena cava (IC).

 

 

Anatomy on visceral surface of the liver with division into right and left lobes by the plane of Rex-Cantlie line.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Porta Hepatis and Inferior Vena Cava: The porta hepatis, often called the "hilum of the liver," is a deep fissure on the inferior surface of the liver where several key structures, including the portal vein, common hepatic duct, and hepatic artery, enter or leave the liver. Though the porta hepatis is an essential landmark in liver anatomy and surgery, it's not associated with the cholecysto-vena caval line.

 

Option C. Caudate Lobe and Quadrangular Lobe: There isn't a distinct "quadrangular lobe" in the human liver. The liver has main lobes named right, left, caudate, and quadrate lobes. The caudate and quadrate lobes are smaller lobes situated on the liver's inferior surface. While they have importance in liver anatomy, they don't define the cholecysto-vena caval line.

 

Option D. Right and Left Lobe of Liver: On the Diaphragamatic surface Tthe human liver is typically divided into a larger right lobe and a smaller left lobe by the falciform ligament (anteriorly). The cholecysto-vena caval line helps delineate the boundary between the right and left lobes when viewed posteriorly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cholecysto-vena caval line is an imaginary line drawn from the fundus of the gallbladder to the point where the inferior vena cava (IVC) pierces the diaphragm. It roughly demarcates the boundary between the right and left lobes of the liver, especially when viewed from behind (posterior view).

choices.text: Left axis deviation
Mild ST changes in inferior leads
Atrial and ventricular premature contractions
Pansystolic murmur

questions.text: All are normal physiological changes in pregnancy except? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pansystolic murmur

 

Explanation:

 

During pregnancy, there are several physiological changes in the cardiovascular system:

 

  1. Clinical Examination:
    • Jugular venous distension and venous hum are commonly observed.
    • Mammary soufflé: A continuous murmur can be heard at the 2nd to 4th intercostal spaces.
    • Flow murmurs at the aortic or pulmonary areas.
    • Increased and widely split S1 sound.
    • S2 P component is increased, and S2 is split.
    • The apex beat is shifted to the 4th intercostal space, 2.5 cm outside the mid-clavicular line.
  2. Electrocardiography:
    • T wave inversion and bi-atrial enlargement.
    • Various dysrhythmias, including atrial and ventricular premature contractions, are relatively frequent.
    • Due to the diaphragm being elevated during advancing pregnancy, there is an average 15-degree left-axis deviation in the electrocardiogram (ECG), and mild ST changes may be seen in the inferior leads.
    • Pregnancy does not alter voltage.
    • Tricuspid regurgitation may be present.
    • Increased left atrial end-diastolic dimension and left ventricular mass.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left axis deviation: This is a normal change due to the diaphragm being elevated during pregnancy, causing an average 15-degree left-axis deviation in the ECG.

 

Option B. Mild ST changes in inferior leads: These are normal and can be seen due to the changes in heart position and function during pregnancy.

 

Option C. Atrial and ventricular premature contractions: These are relatively frequent and considered normal in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diastolic and pansystolic murmurs in pregnancy are not normal and should be investigated further.

 

Ref: Page 178, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: The most common triggering factor of the given condition is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Infection

 

  • The given image shows characteristic target lesions of erythema multiforme (EMF)
  • Most common cause – Herpes simplex virus infection.

 

Erythema multiforme:

 

  • Self-limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from Type IV cell-mediated hypersensitivity.
  • It most commonly occurs following an infection with Herpes simplex virus infection.

 

Target lesions are less than 3 cm in diameter, rounded, and have three zones:

 

 

Location:

 

  • Palms and the trunk.
  • Oral and genital mucosal membranes lesions are associated with erosions.
  • It presents as the classic acral iris or 'Target lesions'.

 

The common triggers apart from Herpes simplex infection are:

 

  • Mycoplasma infection
  • Bacterial infections
  • Fungal infections
  • Vaccinations
  • Malignancy- carcinoma, lymphoma, leukemia
  • Drugs- sulphonamides, rifampicin, penicillin derivatives.

 

Note: Atypical target lesions with only 2 zones may be seen in Stevens Johnson syndrome (SJS) & Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Drugs: While drugs can trigger EMF, they are not as commonly implicated as infections, especially HSV.

 

Option C. Vaccination: Vaccinations can occasionally trigger EMF but are less commonly a cause compared to infections.

 

Option D. Malignancy: Although malignancies can sometimes trigger EMF, they are much less common triggers compared to infections like HSV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common trigger for erythema multiforme, particularly when target lesions are present on the palms, is infection, notably with herpes simplex virus.

 

Additional information

 

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume I Chapter 4. Page no 4.11, 4.13

Question Level – Intermediate 

Question Id-7462 Unique Key-Q3225777

questions.text: Deficiency of which of the following causes increased glutamine in blood? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ornithine transcarbamoylase

 

Deficiency of ornithine transcarbamoylase is an X-linked genetic disorder known as ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency (OTC deficiency). This deficiency impairs the urea cycle's function, leading to the accumulation of ammonia and causing hyperammonemia. Elevated ammonia levels can indirectly affect glutamine metabolism, potentially leading to increased glutamine in the blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arginosuccinate lyase: Deficiency of arginosuccinate lyase is associated with argininosuccinic aciduria, a disorder that results in the accumulation of argininosuccinic acid and ammonia. However, this deficiency does not directly lead to increased glutamine levels.

 

Option B. Alpha-galactosidase-A: Deficiency of alpha-galactosidase-A is associated with Fabry disease, a lysosomal storage disorder. It does not lead to increased glutamine levels in the blood.

 

Option D. Arginase: Deficiency of arginase is associated with argininemia, a rare urea cycle disorder. Arginase deficiency leads to the accumulation of arginine and ammonia in the blood. As with OTC deficiency, elevated ammonia levels can indirectly affect glutamine metabolism, potentially leading to increased glutamine in the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency is a urea cycle disorder, which is inherited as an X-linked trait. Hyperammonemia Type II is characterized by OTC deficiency. Mothers also have hyperammonemia and an aversion to high protein diet. To reduce ammonia levels, glutamate combines with ammonia to form glutamine. Thus, elevated levels of ammonia are associated with high glutamine levels in CSF and blood.

 

Urea cycle disorders

questions.text: Excess ammonia reduces which of the following substrates of the Krebs cycle?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Alpha ketoglutarate

 

Excess ammonia has been shown to inhibit alpha-ketoglutarate. Ammonia interferes with the normal functioning of the Krebs cycle by inhibiting key enzymes, including those involved in the conversion of alpha-ketoglutarate. This disruption in the Krebs cycle can lead to metabolic imbalances and other health issues.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malate: Excess ammonia does not directly reduce malate. Malate is a key intermediate in the Krebs cycle but is not typically affected by ammonia levels.

 

Option B. Oxaloacetate: Excess ammonia does not directly reduce oxaloacetate either. Oxaloacetate is another intermediate in the Krebs cycle and is not a primary target of ammonia toxicity.

 

Option C. Fumarate: Similar to malate and oxaloacetate, fumarate is not a direct target of excess ammonia. It plays a role in the Krebs cycle but is not significantly affected by ammonia levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the CNS, Alpha ketoglutarate can combine with excess ammonia forming glutamate to reduce ammonia levels.

choices.text: 2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by same dose after 24 hours
1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 1 week
1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 24 hours and after a week
2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose 24 hours later and after 2 weeks

questions.text: What is the recommended amount of vitamin A dosage for a 2-year-old child diagnosed with keratomalacia? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose 24 hours later and after 2 weeks

 

The recommended treatment for a 2-year-old child diagnosed with keratomalacia involves high-dose vitamin A supplementation to rapidly replenish depleted stores and prevent further ocular damage. The specific dosage regimen is:

 

  1. 2,00,000 IU of vitamin A administered immediately.
  2. 2,00,000 IU administered again 24 hours later.
  3. 2,00,000 IU administered again after 2 weeks.

 

This regimen is designed to quickly correct vitamin A deficiency and provide sustained support to prevent recurrence and promote healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The suggested vitamin A dose for a 2-year-old child diagnosed with keratomalacia is 200,000 IU, administered promptly, then repeated with the same age-appropriate amount after 24 hours and again after a span of 2 weeks.

 

Dosage of Vitamin A as per age: -

 

  • <6 months – 50,000 IU orally
  • 6-12 months – 1,00,000 IU orally
  • above 12 months – 2,00,000 IU orally

questions.text: A patient presents with a slowly progressive swelling that has been noticeable for the past 18 months. The swelling exhibits variable consistency, with some areas feeling hard and others feeling soft, image of patient is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis for this clinical presentation? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pleomorphic adenoma

 

Explanation:

 

The case scenario and image showing a swelling lifting the ear lobe are suggestive of a pleomorphic adenoma. Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common benign tumors of the salivary glands, with the parotid gland being the most frequent site. These tumors are encapsulated and exhibit a mixed cellular composition, leading to a variable consistency, which is reflected in their name "pleomorphic." Clinically, they present as painless, slow-growing masses. The characteristic lift of the earlobe due to the swelling is a classic sign of a parotid gland tumor. Untreated pleomorphic adenomas may undergo malignant transformation, hence surgical excision is typically recommended.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Jaw Tumor: Jaw tumors, particularly those of the mandible or maxilla, are often bony growths or related to the teeth (odontogenic tumors). While they can cause facial asymmetry, they are usually centered around the bones and are not typically located in the parotid gland region. These tumors tend to be hard and lack the variable consistency described in the clinical presentation.

 

Option B. Dermoid cyst: Dermoid cysts are benign cystic tumors containing skin appendages (such as hair follicles), and sometimes hair, teeth, or sebum. They are typically congenital and found on the face, neck, or ovary. While they can appear on the face or neck, the described clinical presentation is less suggestive of a dermoid cyst compared to a pleomorphic adenoma. Dermoid cysts often show indentation due to putty material.

 

Option D. Sebaceous cyst: Also known as an epidermal cyst, a sebaceous cyst is a benign growth arising from blocked sebaceous glands, often containing a thick, cheese-like material. Sebaceous cysts can appear almost anywhere on the body where sebaceous glands are found, including the face, and often show a black punctum. However, the described clinical presentation and duration better match a pleomorphic adenoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the salivary glands, typically presenting as a painless, slow-growing mass with variable consistency and often lifting the earlobe due to its location in the parotid gland.

questions.text: Area marked in the given image is supplied by dermatome number? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. T10

 

The marked dermatome which includes the umbilicus is supplied by T10.

 

The T10 dermatome is significant because it corresponds to the umbilical region. Often, when clinicians check for sensation around the umbilicus, they are assessing the integrity of the T10 spinal nerve. This dermatome covers the region around the umbilicus, extending a bit below it.

 

Dermatomes are specific areas of skin that are supplied by sensory nerves originating from a single spinal nerve root. Each segment of the spinal cord gives rise to a pair (left and right) of spinal nerves, and each of these spinal nerves carries sensory information from a distinct region of the body to the spinal cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T8: The T8 dermatome primarily covers the area just above the level of the umbilicus. If you were to draw a horizontal line around the trunk at the level of the umbilicus, this would approximate the center of the T8 dermatomal distribution.

 

Option B. T9: The T9 dermatome is situated just below the T8 level and above T10. It covers the region between the umbilicus and the midline of the abdomen, approximately at the level where the xiphoid process (the small cartilaginous extension at the lower end of the sternum) ends.

 

Option D. T11: The T11 dermatome covers an area of the anterior trunk below the T10 level but above the groin. It is positioned just before the first lumbar dermatome starts, and it sits above the inguinal ligament, which is a band running from the pubic tubercle to the anterior superior iliac spine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dermatomal distribution of the abdominal region is as follows:

choices.text: A person who sheds pathogens during incubation period
A carrier who acquired pathogen from another carrier
A person who acquired pathogen from patient
A patient who became a carrier

questions.text: The term "paradoxical carrier" is defined as: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A carrier who acquired pathogen from another carrier

 

A paradoxical carrier is defined as a carrier who has acquired a pathogen from another carrier, yet does not exhibit any signs or symptoms of the disease. This situation is paradoxical because the pathogen is typically transmitted directly from an infected patient to a new host, but in this case, it has been passed from one asymptomatic carrier to another. This type of carrier plays a significant role in the epidemiology of certain infectious diseases by perpetuating the transmission cycle without showing clinical symptoms themselves.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A person who sheds pathogens during incubation period:  This describes an incubatory carrier, who sheds infectious agents during the incubation period of the disease. This is different from a paradoxical carrier, as it involves shedding pathogens before symptoms appear.

 

Option C. A person who acquired pathogen from patient:  This does not describe a paradoxical carrier. It refers to a typical transmission scenario where a pathogen is acquired directly from an infected patient, rather than another asymptomatic carrier.

 

Option D. A patient who became a carrier:  This refers to a convalescent carrier or a chronic carrier. A convalescent carrier is someone who continues to shed the disease agent during the recovery period, while a chronic carrier harbors the pathogen long-term. Neither term is synonymous with a paradoxical carrier.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A paradoxical carrier is a carrier who has acquired a pathogen from another carrier, but who does not show any signs or symptoms of the disease.
  • Incubatory carriers are those who shed the infectious agents during the incubation period of the disease.
  • Convalescent carriers are those who continue to shed the disease agent during the period of convalescence.
  • Healthy carriers are those who had a subclinical infection and developed a carrier state without suffering from overt disease.

questions.text: Which of the following lobes of the prostate forms the uvula vesicae? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Median

 

  • The uvula vesicae is formed by the prostate's median lobe.
  • The uvula vesicae is a slight elevation on the trigone immediately posterior to the urethral orifice caused by the median lobe of the prostate.
  • In benign prostatic hypertrophy, it is frequently enlarged.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior: The anterior lobe of the prostate, also referred to as the anterior fibromuscular stroma, is found at the front of the prostate, facing the pubic symphysis. Contrary to the other sections of the prostate, this area is primarily made up of fibromuscular tissue and contains fewer glandular elements. It doesn't commonly give rise to clinical conditions like benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) or prostate cancer.

 

Option B. Posterior: The posterior lobe is located at the back of the prostate, facing the rectum. This part of the prostate is significant clinically because it's the most common site for the development of prostate cancer. During a digital rectal exam, the physician can palpate this lobe, and any firm or irregular nodules felt here could suggest malignancy.

 

Option D. Lateral: The lateral lobes are the large bilateral portions of the prostate on either side of the urethra. These are the most voluminous parts of the prostate and are typically the primary sites involved in benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), a common condition in older men where the prostate enlarges and can cause urinary obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The middle lobe or median lobe of the prostate is situated between the ejaculatory ducts and the urethra. When the median lobe enlarges due to conditions like benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), it can project into the bladder, forming a structure called the "uvula vesicae." It is also known as Lietaud’s uvula. This growth can cause urinary symptoms by obstructing the bladder neck.

questions.text: What is the function of Tubuloglomerular feedback? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Regulate GFR

 

Tubuloglomerular feedback regulates glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

 

The major function of autoregulation in the kidneys is to maintain a relatively constant GFR and to allow precise control of renal excretion of water and solutes.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decrease plasma sodium: Incorrect as the primary function of tubuloglomerular feedback is not to decrease plasma sodium but to adjust renal blood flow and filtration to maintain stable GFR.

 

Option C. Increase plasma volume: Incorrect, tubuloglomerular feedback does not directly function to increase plasma volume; rather, it regulates the filtration rate to maintain balance.

 

Option D. Decrease tubular secretion: Incorrect, this feedback specifically regulates GFR, not tubular secretion processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tubuloglomerular feedback is an adaptive mechanism in the kidneys that helps regulate GFR in response to changes in blood pressure and filtrate flow rate, ensuring stable renal function and homeostasis.

questions.text: Which item below does not qualify as personal protective equipment? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lab coat

 

A lab coat is not a personal protective equipment.

 

While lab coats are worn in laboratory settings to protect clothing and skin from spills and splashes, they are not classified as PPE. PPE refers to more specialized equipment designed to provide a barrier against specific hazards.

 

Other 3 options are considered as PPE

 

Educational Objective:

 

Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) are:

 

  • Gloves - protect hands.
  • Gowns/ aprons - protect skin and clothing.
  • Masks protect the mouth/nose and respirators protect the respiratory tract from airborne infectious agents.
  • Goggles - protect eyes.
  • Face shields - protect face, mouth, nose, and eyes.

questions.text: Alcohol abuse is strongly associated with the development of: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dilated cardiomyopathy

 

Alcohol abuse is strongly associated with the development of dilated cardiomyopathy.

 

Alcohol and its metabolites, acetaldehyde, have a toxic effect on the myocardium which leads to the development of dilated cardiomyopathy.

 

 

Dilated cardiomyopathy causes include:

 

Acquisition of causes

 

  • The most frequent causes of myocarditis worldwide are infectious (particularly coxsackievirus B) and non-infectious myocarditis.
  • In India, alcohol is the most frequent culprit.
  • Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PCM) and pregnancy-associated cardiomyopathy (PACM) (PPCM)
  • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy brought on by stress

 

Meth-related:

 

  • Doxycycline (anthracycline)
  • Cyclophosphamide and trastuzumab

 

A lack of nutrition:

 

  • Carnitine deficiency; Keshan disease (selenium); Beriberi (thiamine);
  • Endocrine: acromegaly, diabetes mellitus, hypo- and hyperthyroidism
  • Additional
  • Toxicity of cobalt, Heavy metals (lead, mercury, arsenic, lithium)

 

Genetic factors (50%):

 

Haemochromatosis; Duchenne muscular dystrophy; Becker's muscular dystrophy; cardiac myocyte titin gene mutation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pericarditis: While alcohol can have widespread effects on the body, it is not directly associated with the development of pericarditis.

 

Option B. Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy: This condition involves the thickening of the heart muscle, primarily due to genetic causes, and is not directly linked to alcohol use.

 

Option D. Myocarditis: Generally caused by infections (particularly viral), autoimmune disorders, or toxic exposures, but not specifically by alcohol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dilated cardiomyopathy associated with alcohol abuse reflects the cumulative detrimental effects of alcohol on heart structure and function, compounded by nutritional deficiencies and genetic factors, making it a critical concern in chronic alcohol consumers.

choices.text: It is a type of droplet infection
Vertical transmission is possible
Infection in early pregnancy causes a milder form of disease
Fetus affected in late pregnancy may have only deafness

questions.text: All of the following are TRUE about Rubella infection, EXCEPT? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Infection in early pregnancy causes a milder form of disease

 

Rubella infection in the 1st trimester: 90% have a significant risk for abortion and severe congenital malformations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a type of droplet infection:  This statement is true. Rubella is transmitted via respiratory droplets.

 

Option B. Vertical transmission is possible:  This statement is true. Rubella can be transmitted from the mother to the fetus.

 

Option D. Fetus affected in late pregnancy may have only deafness:  This statement is true. While the risk of severe congenital malformations is lower in late pregnancy, the fetus may still be affected, with deafness being a potential outcome.

 

Educational Objective :

 

RUBELLA

 

Cause → RNA Togavirus

 

IP → 14-21 Days

 

Source → Cases [No carriers - No Iceberg phenomenon]

 

Mode of Transmission → Resp. [Air droplets]

 

Period of Communicability → 1 week before rash ← SYMPTOMS → 1 week after rash

 

Vaccine → Live attenuated RA 27/3 strain [C/I in pregnancy]

 

1st priority group → Non pregnant Non Lactating Reproductive 15-49 yrs female [1st trimester]


Congenital Rubella Syndrome → CVD [PDA], Cataract, Sensory Neural Deafness

 

Most common and most dangerous time for transmission of Rubella from Mother to Child is First trimester

questions.text: Cushing's ulcers are seen in? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Head injury

 

Cushing's ulcers are specifically associated with head injuries or conditions that lead to increased intracranial pressure (ICP). The mechanism involves vagal nerve stimulation due to the increased ICP, which in turn causes an overproduction of gastric acid leading to the development of ulcers. This is distinct from other types of stress-related gastric ulcers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Burns: This type of ulcer is known as Curling's ulcer, which occurs in response to severe burns and is related to the physiological stress and possible hypovolemia resulting from the burn injury, not the brain injury-related mechanism of Cushing's ulcers.

 

Option B. Stress: While stress can indeed lead to gastric ulcers, the specific term "Cushing's ulcers" is not used in this context. General stress-related ulcers do not typically involve the mechanism of vagal stimulation due to increased ICP.

 

Option D. Cell necrosis: This is a general process that can occur in many pathological conditions but does not specifically relate to the formation of Cushing's ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:


Cushing's ulcers are a specific type of peptic ulcer that occurs due to increased intracranial pressure resulting from head injuries. Recognizing this condition is important for managing patients with significant neurological trauma to prevent and treat these potentially serious gastrointestinal complications.

choices.text: Its diameter is less than left coronary artery
It arises from the anterior aortic sinus
It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch
Right conus artery is its first branch

questions.text: All of the following are true about the right coronary artery except?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch

 

  • This statement is false. The circumflex coronary artery is a branch of the left coronary artery, not the right. The circumflex artery travels in the coronary sulcus between the left atrium and left ventricle and supplies the left atrium and the posterior walls of the left ventricle.
  • Originating from the right coronary sinus of the ascending aorta, the right coronary artery has a smaller diameter compared to the left coronary artery.
  • It courses anteriorly and descends perpendicularly along the coronary sulcus, situated between the right atrium and the right ventricle.
  • Upon reaching the inferior border, it takes a posterior turn and persists along the sulcus onto the diaphragmatic surface and base of the heart.

 

 

Branches of right coronary artery:

 

  • Atrial branches are anterior, posterior and lateral. One of the anterior atrial branches is called SA nodal artery.
  • Right conus artery – it is usually the first branch. It forms an arterial circle around pulmonary trunk with a similar branch from the left coronary artery. The circle is called, ‘annulus of Vieussen’s’.
  • Ventricular branches are as anterior and posterior groups.
  • Right marginal artery
  • Posterior interventricular branch

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Its diameter is less than left coronary artery: This is true. The right coronary artery (RCA) typically has a smaller diameter compared to the left main coronary artery. The left coronary artery further divides into the left anterior descending (LAD) and the circumflex arteries, which are primary arteries supplying a significant portion of the heart, especially in left-dominant circulatory systems.

 

Option B. It arises from the anterior aortic sinus: This is true. The RCA arises from the anterior aortic sinus (also known as the right coronary sinus) of the aorta. It's one of the three aortic sinuses located just above the aortic valve. The other two sinuses give rise to the left coronary artery and have no coronary artery associated with them, respectively.

 

Option D. Right conal (or conus) artery is its first branch: This is true. The first branch of the RCA, in many individuals, is the conal or conus artery, which supplies the conus arteriosus of the right ventricle. After this, the RCA travels in the coronary sulcus and gives off other branches like the right marginal artery and, in many people, the posterior descending artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The circumflex coronary artery is actually a branch of the left coronary artery, not the right. It travels along the coronary sulcus between the left atrium and left ventricle, primarily supplying the left atrium and the posterior walls of the left ventricle.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations does not use antibody marking? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemagglutination Test

 

The Hemagglutination Test does not involve antibody marking. This test is used primarily to detect the agglutination of red blood cells (RBCs) by substances such as viruses or anti-blood group antibodies. The principle behind hemagglutination involves the ability of certain entities like viruses to bind directly to receptors on the surfaces of RBCs, causing them to clump together without the need for an antibody to be present as a marker.

 

It is routinely performed to type red blood cells in ABO blood-typing.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay): Uses antibodies that are tagged with an enzyme to detect the presence of antigens or other antibodies in a sample through a colorimetric change.

 

Option B. Radioimmunoassay: Involves antibodies or antigens labeled with a radioactive isotope to measure the concentration of substances in the blood.

 

Option C. Immunofluorescence: Utilizes antibodies labeled with fluorescent dyes to detect specific antigens in tissues or cells under a fluorescence microscope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hemagglutination test is unique in its use of direct interactions between particles (like viruses) and red blood cells to demonstrate binding and agglutination, distinguishing it from other tests that rely on labeled antibodies to indicate the presence of specific antigens or antibodies. This method is particularly useful in blood typing and viral detection.

questions.text: All among the following are clinical features of necrotizing enterocolitis except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metabolic alkalosis

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is a serious gastrointestinal problem that mostly affects premature infants. It involves infection and inflammation that causes destruction of the bowel (intestine) or part of the bowel.

 

This is not a typical feature of NEC. Instead, NEC can cause metabolic or respiratory acidosis due to the severe infection and inflammation affecting the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Other Options:

 

The typical clinical features of NEC include:

 

Option A. Vomiting: Vomiting is a common symptom in infants with NEC due to gastrointestinal dysfunction.

 

Option B. Abdominal mass: In severe cases, an abdominal mass can be palpated due to distended bowel loops filled with gas or fluid.

 

Option C. Erythema of the abdominal wall: This is seen in advanced stages of NEC, indicating severe inflammation and possible progression to perforation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) can cause metabolic or respiratory acidosis, not metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: Mrs. Kumar, a 60-year-old woman, has been experiencing difficulty swallowing and a feeling of pressure in her chest. Her doctor orders an ultrasound, which reveals a retrosternal goiter. The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Neck

 

Explanation:

 

The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via the neck. This is because the thyroid gland is anatomically located in the neck, and even when a goiter extends behind the sternum into the chest, the neck provides the most direct and least invasive access for surgical removal. The retrosternal portion of the goiter can usually be mobilized and delivered into the neck for excision without the need for more invasive thoracic approaches. The vascular supply of the goiter also predominantly comes from cervical vessels like the inferior thyroid artery, making the neck approach feasible and effective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chest: Surgical approaches through the chest are typically not used for retrosternal goiters. Accessing the thyroid gland through the chest would involve more invasive procedures, such as thoracotomy, and is generally reserved for rare cases with specific indications, such as very large goiters extending deeply into the chest cavity.

 

Option C. Median Sternotomy: Median sternotomy involves cutting through the breastbone (sternum) to access structures within the chest, particularly the heart and major blood vessels. While median sternotomy is common for cardiac surgeries, it is not the primary approach for treating retrosternal goiters, which can typically be addressed via the neck.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because the neck is the commonest and preferred approach for the surgical removal of retrosternal goiters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common and preferred surgical approach for a retrosternal goiter is via the neck due to its direct access to the thyroid gland and the feasibility of mobilizing the goiter from this region.

questions.text: Identify the condition:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Brodie’s abscess

 

BRODIE’S ABSCESS

 

  • It is a long standing localized pyogenic abscess in the bone (long standing because of strong defence mechanism of body)
  • Seen in immunocompetent host.
  • This intraosseous abscess is related to subacute or chronic pyogenic osteomyelitis.
  • It usually involves long bones (metaphysis or diaphysis); e.g., Upper end of tibia
  • Classical Brodie’s abscess looks like a small walled off (sclerotic margins) cavity in bone with little or no periosteal reaction.

 

 

  • Usual isolated organism is Staphylococcus aureus (although most cultures are negative)
  • Treatment: Trial of injectable antibiotics is given; if it fails, curettage of the cavity is carried out.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Osteoid osteoma. It is commonest benign true bone tumor. The patient has pain that is worse at night and is relieved by aspirin or other NSAID medications. When the lesion is in a vertebra, scoliosis may occur. Both Osteoblastic & Osteoclastic cells are seen. The lesion has central lysis with surrounding sclerosis. Growing center is called as Nidus (Seed). It is most common in diaphysis of femur. CT is the best study to identify the nidus and confirm the diagnosis. D/D of osteoid osteoma is bone island. Radiofrequency ablation is used for osteoid osteoma. Surgical management involves removal of the entire nidus done by burr-down technique.

 

 

Option C. Intra-cortical hemangioma. Hemangioma of bone is a benign tumor that usually involves a vertebra or the skull and commonly is found as an incidental asymptomatic lesion.  They are slightly less commonly encountered in men (M:F = 0.7:1) and most commonly seen in the 5th decade of life but can occur at any age. These tumors are slow-growing and are most commonly asymptomatic unless they exert mass effect on sensitive structures, present as a swelling or a palpable mass, especially in the skull. Most commonly, they are located in the thoracic spine, followed by the skull and facial bones, followed by long bones where they preferentially involve the metaphysis or diaphysis.

 

 

Hemangioma of proximal femur

 

Option D. Chondromyxoid fibroma. Chondromyxoid fibroma is a rare lesion of cartilaginous origin. Although chondromyxoid fibromas may occur at any age, most commonly occur in patients of 10-30 years old. Any bone may be involved, but the proximal tibia is the most common location. In contrast to other cartilaginous lesions, radiographic evidence of intralesional calcification usually is absent. Treatment consists of resection or extended curettage.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given image shows Brodie’s abscess, which is a long standing localized pyogenic abscess in the bone, seen in subacute or chronic pyogenic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: ADH acts through which aquaporin channel?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2

 

Antidiuretic hormone (ADH), also known as vasopressin, plays a crucial role in regulating water balance in the body by concentrating urine. It acts primarily through the aquaporin-2 (AQP-2) channels located in the kidney's collecting ducts. Here is how ADH functions:

 

  1. Receptor Interaction: ADH binds to V2 receptors on the basolateral membranes of cells in the late distal convoluted tubules, collecting tubules, and collecting ducts of the kidney.
  2. Signal Transduction: The binding of ADH to these receptors activates the cyclic AMP (cAMP) pathway, leading to the activation of protein kinase A (PKA).
  3. Aquaporin-2 Mobilization: PKA then phosphorylates specific proteins that lead to the translocation of AQP-2 water channels from intracellular storage vesicles to the apical membrane of the kidney cells.
  4. Water Reabsorption: Once inserted into the membrane, AQP-2 channels allow water to be reabsorbed from the tubular fluid back into the bloodstream, thereby concentrating the urine.
  5. Regulation by ADH Levels: Chronic high levels of ADH enhance the synthesis of AQP-2 channels through increased gene transcription, while low levels lead to the internalization of these channels, reducing water reabsorption.

 

Clinical Relevance:

 

In conditions such as nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, there is a genetic mutation that affects the V2 receptors or the AQP-2 channels themselves, rendering the kidney tubules unresponsive to ADH. This results in the inability to concentrate urine and excessive urine output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aquaporin 1: Incorrect, as AQP-1 is primarily involved in passive water transport in other parts of the kidney and other tissues, not under the control of ADH.

 

Option C. Aquaporin 3 and Option D. Aquaporin 4: Both are incorrect as these aquaporins are located in the basolateral membrane of collecting duct cells and are involved in water transport but are not the primary channels through which ADH acts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ADH specifically regulates the body's water balance by acting through aquaporin-2 channels in the kidney's collecting ducts, facilitating the reabsorption of water back into the bloodstream and thus concentrating the urine. This mechanism is crucial for maintaining proper hydration and electrolyte balance in the body.

choices.text: Interferes with DNA and RNA synthesis
Inhibits epoxidation of squalene in fungi

questions.text: What is the mechanism of triazoles? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inhibition of ergosterol synthesis

 

Triazoles include drugs like Itraconazole , Voriconazole , Fluconazole and Posaconazole. They are antifungal drugs that act by inhibiting 14-α demethylase , which prevents the conversion of Lanosterol to Ergosterol , thereby inhibiting the fungal cell wall synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interferes with DNA and RNA synthesis: This mechanism is characteristic of nucleoside analogues such as flucytosine, which are incorporated into RNA and disrupt protein synthesis.

 

Option C. Forms pores in fungal membranes: This mechanism is characteristic of polyenes, such as amphotericin B and nystatin, which bind to ergosterol and form pores in the fungal cell membrane.

 

Option D. Inhibits epoxidation of squalene in fungi: This mechanism is characteristic of allylamines, such as terbinafine and naftifine, which inhibit the enzyme squalene epoxidase, leading to ergosterol depletion.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following investigations is shown in the radiograph? ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Barium meal

 

Explanation:

 

The given image is a barium meal. This study is used to examine the stomach and proximal duodenum.

 

Visual Cues: The image shows the distribution of barium within the stomach, outlining its contours and revealing its internal structure, which is typical in a barium meal examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Barium Swallow: This study primarily evaluates the esophagus and does not extend into the stomach. The radiograph showing the stomach filled with barium indicates that the procedure goes beyond just a barium swallow.

 

Option C. Barium Meal Follow Through: This investigation involves not only the stomach but also a sequential imaging of the small intestine as the barium passes through. The specific image provided does not show barium beyond the proximal duodenum, which is typical in a simple barium meal.

 

Option D. Barium Enema: This procedure is used to visualize the large intestine (colon) and rectum using barium introduced via the rectum. The provided image showing the stomach filled with barium clearly indicates that it's not a barium enema.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4-8%

 

The risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is higher than in non-consanguineous marriages. The risk depends on several factors, such as the prevalence of genetic diseases in the population, the degree of consanguinity, and the genetic makeup of the couple.

 

The estimated risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is around 4-8%, which is higher than the general population's risk of around 2-4%. However, the risk can vary widely depending on the specific genetic diseases and the population's prevalence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is estimated to be around 4-8%, which is higher than the general population risk of approximately 2-4%.

choices.text: Apo E1
Apo E2
Apo E3

questions.text: Which of the following is a risk factor for Alzheimer's disease? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Apo E4

 

Apolipoprotein E4 is a risk factor for Alzheimer's disease (AD)

 

The chromosome 19 genetic region that codes for apolipoprotein E (ApoE) has a significant impact on the likelihood of developing AD. Based on two amino acid polymorphisms, there are three alleles (alleles 2, 3, and 4). Individuals with the 4 allele are overrepresented in communities of patients with AD because the 4 allele's dosage decreases the age of illness start and raises the risk of AD. According to estimates, this locus accounts for around 25% of the risk for developing sporadic AD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apo E1: Not commonly recognized in the context of Alzheimer’s risk.

 

Option B. Apo E2: Known to be protective against Alzheimer’s, potentially by promoting a more effective clearance of amyloid-beta from the brain.

 

Option C. Apo E3: The most common allele and considered neutral in terms of Alzheimer’s risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Apo E4 allele is a well-documented genetic risk factor for Alzheimer's disease, influencing the disease's onset and severity. Understanding the genetic risk factors like Apo E4 is crucial for early intervention strategies and for personalizing treatment and management plans for at-risk populations.

 

Apo E2 is protective for Alzheimers disease.

questions.text: An 88-year-old male presented to the emergency department with the sudden onset of severe epigastric pain. On physical examination, she had a temperature of 101.44° F, a pulse of 115 bpm and a blood pressure of 125/72 mm of Hg. Abdomen was tender & rigid. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pneumoperitoneum

 

Explanation:

 

The presence of free gas under the right diaphragm in the X-ray. This is suggestive of pneumoperitoneum.

 

  • C/F: Acute abdominal pain, rigidity, tenderness, guarding.
  • Most sensitive X-ray: CXR-PA erect.
  • Most sensitive Ix: CECT with oral contrast.
  • Next step: Resuscitation with IV fluids, Exploratory laparotomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax: Involves air in the pleural space, not under the diaphragm. The clinical presentation and X-ray findings do not support this diagnosis.

 

Option C. Subdiaphragmatic abscess: Typically presents with localized pain and fever, but X-ray findings would be more consistent with an abscess formation rather than free air.

 

Option D. Intestinal obstruction: While it might present with abdominal pain and distension, free air under the diaphragm is not a characteristic finding unless there is a concurrent bowel perforation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pneumoperitoneum is a critical finding indicating a potential perforation of the gastrointestinal tract, requiring immediate assessment and surgical intervention. This diagnosis is supported by the presence of free air under the diaphragm seen on the X-ray.

choices.text: Fibrinoid necrosis
Gangrenous necrosis
Fat necrosis

questions.text: What is the type of necrosis seen in the vessel wall of a patient with polyarteritis nodosa? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fibrinoid necrosis

 

Immune responses that affect blood vessels, such in polyarteritis nodosa, typically display fibrinoid necrosis.

 

Grossly, PAN lesions appear as minute beaded nodules at the bifurcations and branching of vessel segments.

 

Antigen-antibody complexes accumulate in the blood arteries in several immunological diseases. Complement activation brought on by these complexes causes type III hypersensitivity, which damages cells. This leads to leakage of fibrin out of the blood vessel, giving a pinkish appearance around the blood vessels.

 

Fibrinoid necrosis is characterized by deposition of fibrin-like material which has the staining properties of fibrin. It is encountered in various examples of immunologic tissue injury (e.g., in immune complex vasculitis, autoimmune diseases, Arthus reaction etc.), arterioles in hypertension, peptic ulcer etc.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gangrenous necrosis: Typically associated with ischemic necrosis of limbs or bowel, not primarily a feature of vascular inflammation.

 

Option C. Fat necrosis: Occurs in adipose tissue due to trauma or pancreatitis, not related to vascular injury.

 

Option D. Caseous necrosis: Characteristic of tuberculosis, involving granulomatous inflammation with a cheese-like appearance, unrelated to PAN.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibrinoid necrosis is seen in the following conditions:

 

  • SLE
  • Libman-sacks endocarditis
  • Arthus reaction
  • Serum sickness
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  • Malignant hypertension

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV-positive man presents with fever for 3 weeks, dry cough, and significant weight loss. His HRCT thorax is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia
