In patients with HIV and respiratory failure, findings of GGO & cysts within GGO in perihilar locations on HRCT are characteristic for PCP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcal pneumonia: This typically presents with more localized consolidations or cavitary lesions rather than the diffuse, bilateral ground-glass opacities seen in PCP.

 

Option B. Pneumococcal pneumonia: Often manifests as lobar consolidation, which does not match the diffuse pattern observed in the HRCT.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis: In HIV-positive patients, tuberculosis may present in various forms including miliary patterns or cavitary disease, especially if the CD4 count is low, but the diffuse ground-glass appearance is more characteristic of PCP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/HIV/Opportunistic Infection in HIV/Chap

choices.text: It is produced by the removal of cerebral cortex and basal ganglia
Flexion of lower limbs and extension of upper limbs occurs
Rigidity is pronounced
It is characterized by flexion of upper limbs and extension of lower limbs

questions.text: Which of the following is true for decorticate rigidity? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. It is characterized by flexion of upper limbs and extension of lower limbs

 

Explanation

 

Decorticate animal is the one without cerebral cortex.

 

In man, decorticate condition is caused by intracranial hemorrhage, head injury, brain abscess or brain tumor. Decorticate condition is called decorticate rigidity

 

Decorticate rigidity is the abnormal postural changes that involve rigid extension of the lower limbs and flexion of the upper limbs at elbow joint across the chest. Wrists and fingers are also flexed. Posture may develop on one side or both sides of the body.

 

Reflexes at the neck level can be elicited

 

  • When the neck is turned to right, there is flexion of the lower and upper limbs on the opposite side. But, on the same side, there is extension of the limbs.
  • It may be due to the cutting or lesion of direct corticospinal tract. Some fibers of corticospinal tract are known to have inhibitory influence on the extensor muscles.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is produced by the removal of cerebral cortex and basal ganglia: Incorrect as decorticate rigidity typically does not involve the removal of the basal ganglia.

 

Option B. Flexion of lower limbs and extension of upper limbs occurs: Incorrect as this describes a reverse of the decorticate rigidity posturing.

 

Option C. Rigidity is pronounced: This statement is somewhat vague but could be considered true in the context of how muscle rigidity is indeed pronounced in decorticate rigidity. However, it does not specifically describe the characteristic posture associated with decorticate rigidity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decorticate rigidity is characterized by flexion of the upper limbs and extension of the lower limbs, often occurring in response to severe brain damage above the midbrain level. It is a distinctive postural manifestation of significant central nervous system disruption.

questions.text: The hormone acting on post ovulatory endometrium is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Progesterone

 

Post ovulation, there is a significant rise in progesterone levels, which is crucial for the transformation of the endometrium into a secretory phase. This phase is essential for preparing the endometrium for potential implantation of an embryo.

 

Phases of the Menstrual Cycle:

 

  1. Menstruation (0 - 4 days):
    • The shedding of the endometrial lining occurs if there is no pregnancy.
  2. Follicular Phase (10 - 14 days):
    • Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) stimulates the growth of ovarian follicles.
    • Estrogen levels rise, leading to the proliferation of the endometrium.
  3. Ovulation (14th day):
    • Luteinizing hormone (LH) surge leads to the release of an ovum from the dominant follicle.
  4. Luteal Phase (14 - 28 days):
    • The corpus luteum forms and secretes progesterone.
    • Progesterone causes the endometrium to develop secretory glands and prepare for implantation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Luteinizing Hormone: LH is primarily involved in triggering ovulation and the formation of the corpus luteum.

 

Option B. Follicle-Stimulating Hormone: FSH is crucial for the growth and maturation of ovarian follicles during the follicular phase.

 

Option D. Estrogen: Estrogen is significant during the follicular phase for the proliferation of the endometrium but is not the main hormone acting on the post-ovulatory endometrium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Progesterone is the hormone responsible for preparing the endometrium for implantation during the post-ovulatory phase.

 

Ref: Page no 94, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy was brought to the pediatric OPD with multiple abscesses over his face, chest, and back. The child has a history of recurrent respiratory infections. On examination, he has atopic excoriating skin and multiple cold abscesses on his back. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyper IgE syndrome

 

The clinical presentation of the boy with recurrent skin and respiratory infections, atopic excoriating skin, and notably, cold abscesses, strongly points towards Hyper IgE syndrome, also known as Job's syndrome. This condition is characterized by:

 

  • High levels of IgE: Elevated IgE is a hallmark of the syndrome and contributes to the immune dysregulation seen in these patients.
  • Recurrent infections: Due to defects in immune regulation, particularly affecting the response of neutrophils and other immune cells.
  • Dermatologic issues: Such as eczema and atopic dermatitis are common and often severe in these patients.
  • Genetic background: Hyper IgE syndrome is commonly caused by mutations in the STAT3 gene, which is critical for many aspects of immune system function, including the development and function of neutrophils.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyper IgM syndrome: Incorrect, characterized by elevated levels of IgM with low levels of other immunoglobulins, leading to a susceptibility to infections. It does not typically present with high IgE levels or eczema.

 

Option B. Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome: Incorrect, this is a condition that affects blood cells and immune response, characterized by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infections; however, it does not typically involve high levels of IgE or cold abscesses.

 

Option D. Carcinoid syndrome: Incorrect, typically presents with symptoms caused by secreted hormones, such as flushing, diarrhea, and heart valve problems, which are unrelated to the immune dysfunction seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyper IgE syndrome should be considered in patients presenting with a combination of high IgE levels, recurrent skin and respiratory infections, and dermatologic issues such as eczema. Managing this condition often involves addressing the skin care comprehensively and preventing infections through vigilant monitoring and appropriate use of antibiotics.

questions.text: The most common cause of HIV infection in a newborn is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perinatal transmission 

 

The most common cause of HIV infection in a newborn is through perinatal transmission. Perinatal transmission, also known as vertical transmission, occurs during labor and delivery. This can happen when the newborn is exposed to infected blood and cervicovaginal secretions in the birth canal.

 

Mechanisms of HIV Transmission in Infants:

 

  • In utero (During pregnancy): HIV can cross the placenta from the mother to the fetus.
  • During delivery (Perinatal): This is the most common mode of transmission and occurs when the baby is exposed to infected blood and secretions during the birthing process.
  • After birth by breastfeeding: This is a less common mode of transmission compared to perinatal transmission but still significant, especially in regions where breastfeeding is essential for infant nutrition.

 

Risk Factors for Vertical Transmission:

 

  • High maternal viremia (most important)
  • Preterm delivery (<34 weeks)
  • Vitamin A deficiency
  • Prolonged rupture of membranes (>4 hours)
  • Low birth weight
  • Low maternal CD4 count

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Breast milk: While breast milk can transmit HIV, it is less common compared to perinatal transmission during delivery.

 

Option C. Transplacental: HIV can be transmitted transplacentally during pregnancy, but this is not as common as perinatal transmission.

 

Option D. Exchange transfusion with infected blood: This is a rare cause of HIV infection in newborns compared to perinatal transmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of HIV infection in a newborn is perinatal transmission, occurring during labor and delivery.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acid is necessary for conversion of nor-epinephrine to epinephrine? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Methionine

 

Methionine is involved in the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine. It donate methyl group in the form of SAM.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tyrosine: It is the precursor amino acid for the synthesis of both norepinephrine and epinephrine in the catecholamine biosynthetic pathway. But it is not directly involved in their intercomversion,

 

Option B. Tryptophan: Tryptophan is not directly involved in the synthesis of norepinephrine or epinephrine. Tryptophan is an essential amino acid and serves as the precursor for serotonin, melatonin, and niacin (vitamin B3).

 

Option C. Phenylalanine: Phenylalanine is not directly involved in the synthesis of norepinephrine or epinephrine. It is an essential amino acid and serves as the precursor for tyrosine through the action of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methionine is necessary for the conversion of nor-epinephrine to epinephrine.

 

Norepinephrine is methylated by the enzyme N-methyl transferase (NMT) to epinephrine or adrenaline.

 

S-adenosyl methionine (SAM) is the methyl donor. It is mainly produced by adrenal medulla and adrenergic nerve endings. It is stored in chromaffin granules and released into blood.

questions.text: Which of the following neurons predominantly fire during forceful expiration?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ventral group of neurons

 

Ventral respiratory group of neurons, are located on each side of medulla found in the nucleus ambigus rostrally and the nucleus retroambigus caudally.

 

The function of this neuronal group differs from dorsal group by -

 

  1. The neurons of the ventral respiratory group remain almost totally inactive during normal quiet respiration.
  2. Does not participate in the basic rhythmical oscillation that controls respiration
  3. When the respiratory drive for increased pulmonary ventilation becomes greater than normal, respiratory signals spill over into the ventral respiratory neurons from the basic oscillating mechanism of the dorsal respiratory area
  4. Electrical stimulation of a few of the neurons in the ventral group causes inspiration, whereas stimulation of others causes expiration. Therefore, these neurons contribute to both inspiration and expiration. They are especially important in providing the powerful expiratory signals to the abdominal muscles during very heavy expiration. Thus, this area operates more or less as an overdrive mechanism when high levels of pulmonary ventilation are required, especially during heavy exercise.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dorsal group of neurons: Incorrect because the DRG is mainly active during quiet breathing and primarily controls inspiration.

 

Option C. Pneumotaxic center: Incorrect as the pneumotaxic center primarily modulates the switch between inhalation and exhalation to control the rate and pattern of breathing, rather than directly causing forceful expiration.

 

Option D. Chemoreceptors: Incorrect because chemoreceptors detect changes in the chemical composition of the blood (like CO2 and O2 levels) and influence the respiratory centers indirectly rather than actively firing during respiratory movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ventral Respiratory Group of neurons, particularly some subsets within this group, are actively involved in generating the neural signals required for forceful expiration, making them essential during increased respiratory demands such as during intense physical activity.

questions.text: An old lady complains of chronic backpain since a few months. X-ray is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?( NEET PG 2019 )
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteoporosis

 

The image shows Codfish Vertebra seen in Osteoporosis.

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration. So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.

 

Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

Etiology of Osteoporosis:

 

 

Imaging

 

  • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.
  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.

 

Treatment:

 

Drugs used in osteoporosis are:

 

  1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
  2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
  3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spondylolysis: Incorrect, as spondylolysis refers to a defect or fracture of the pars interarticularis of the vertebrae, not typically associated with the changes seen in the X-ray provided.

 

Option C. Spondylolisthesis: Incorrect, this condition involves the forward slippage of one vertebra over the one beneath it, which would show distinct alignment changes not described in the X-ray findings.

 

Option D. Osteopetrosis: Incorrect, as osteopetrosis is a condition characterized by the abnormal density and sclerosis of bone, quite the opposite of what is observed in osteoporosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Osteoporosis is a condition marked by a decrease in bone density and mass, leading to structural weakening of the bone and increased risk of fractures. Diagnostic imaging such as X-rays can show characteristic changes like "Codfish Vertebra" and is further confirmed by measuring bone mineral density through a DEXA scan. Treatment focuses on inhibiting bone resorption and/or stimulating bone formation through various pharmacological agents.

choices.text: Stop oral methotrexate and start parenteral methotrexate
Add sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine
Continue corticosteroids and methotrexate
Start only anti-TNF alpha agents

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis is being treated with methotrexate and low-dose corticosteroids for the past 4 months. However, the disease is still progressing. What would be your recommendation for the further management of this patient? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Add sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine

 

Adding sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine to the treatment regimen for a patient with rheumatoid arthritis who is not responding adequately to methotrexate and low-dose corticosteroids is a sound strategy. This approach follows the principle of combining different disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) to achieve better disease control. Both sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine are DMARDs that work by different mechanisms to reduce inflammation and slow disease progression in rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stop oral methotrexate and start parenteral methotrexate: While switching to parenteral administration can increase the effectiveness of methotrexate for some patients, it might not be sufficient alone if the disease is still progressing.

 

Option C. Continue corticosteroids and methotrexate: Continuing the same treatment without modification is not advisable if the disease is actively progressing, as this indicates that the current regimen is insufficient.

 

Option D. Start only anti-TNF alpha agents: While anti-TNF agents are effective for many patients, they are typically used after trying combination DMARD therapy, especially in cases not severe enough to warrant immediate biologic therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a patient with rheumatoid arthritis does not respond adequately to initial therapy with methotrexate and corticosteroids, the addition of other DMARDs such as sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine can be beneficial.

 

Drugs:

 

  • Methotrexate: Start 10mg/week → max 25mg/week along with Folic acid twice/week
  • Check ocular fundus before HCQ initiation
  • Leflunomide, sulfasalazine other group of drugs.
  • Sulfasalazine is safe in pregnancy !!
  • Symptomatic relief with NSAID and short course corticosteroids.

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatoid arthritis/ Chap 358

questions.text: Painful arc syndrome is seen in:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mid-abduction

 

IMPINGEMENT SYNDROME

 

  • It is soft tissues entrapment.
  • Tendinitis of the rotator cuff is the major cause of a painful shoulder.
  • The rotator cuff consists of the tendons of the supraspinatus, infraspinatus, subscapularis, and teres minor muscles, and inserts on the humeral tuberosity.
  • The supraspinatus tendon is the most often affected, probably because of its repeated impingement between the humeral head and the undersurface of the anterior third of the acromion and coracoacromial ligament above as well as the reduction in its blood supply that occurs with abduction of the arm. This phenomenon is described as impingement syndrome.
  • The process begins with edema and hemorrhage of the rotator cuff which evolves to fibrotic thickening and eventually to rotator cuff degeneration with tendon tears and bone spurs.
  • Subacromial bursitis also accompanies this syndrome.
  • Symptoms usually appear after injury or overuse, especially with activities involving elevation of the arm with some degree of forward flexion.
  • Impingement syndrome occurs in persons participating in baseball, tennis, swimming, or occupations that require repeated elevation of the arm.
  • Severe pain is experienced when the arm is actively abducted into an overhead position. The arc between 60° and 120° (mid-range abduction) is especially painful. This is also described as “painful arc syndrome”.
  • NSAIDs, local glucocorticoid injection, and physical therapy may relieve symptoms.
  • Surgical decompression of the subacromial space may be necessary in patient refractory to conservative treatment

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Initial abduction: Incorrect, as the pain typically does not start at the beginning of abduction but becomes noticeable as the arm reaches mid-range.

 

Option C. Full range of abduction: Incorrect, although the entire range might be uncomfortable, the specific "painful arc" is usually observed in the mid-range.

 

Option D. Overhead abduction: Incorrect, as the term "painful arc syndrome" specifically refers to pain experienced in the mid-range of abduction, not necessarily when the arm is fully overhead.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Painful arc syndrome, a clinical manifestation of impingement syndrome, is observed during mid-range shoulder abduction, typically between 60° and 120°. This condition is often seen in individuals engaging in activities that involve repeated arm elevation, and management may include NSAIDs, corticosteroid injections, physical therapy, or, in refractory cases, surgical intervention to decompress the subacromial space.

questions.text: Which joint allows for the side-to-side movement of the head, enabling a person to look to the right and left?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Atlanto-axial

 

  • The movements at the atlanto-axial joint allow a person to look left and right.
  • The atlanto-axial joints consist of two lateral joints located on either side between the bottom of the atlas bone and the top of the axis bone, which are flat joints.
  • Additionally, there is a central joint between the dens (a protrusion from the axis bone) and the front arch and transverse ligament of the atlas, which is a pivot joint.
  • This central joint has two distinct synovial cavities - one in the front and one in the back.
  • Rotatory movements occur at all three joints and revolve around a vertical axis.
  • The dens acts as a pivot around which the atlas rotates (carrying the skull with it), allowing the head to rotate side to side.
  • The alar ligaments restrict movement. Atlanto-axial rotation has a normal range of about 40°.

 

Atlanto-Axial joint

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atlanto-occipital joint: This joint is formed between the first cervical vertebra (the atlas or C1) and the occipital bone of the skull. It primarily permits the "nodding" motion of the head, as in signaling "yes". This joint allows for flexion and extension of the head, but not significant rotation. It's the joint that lets you tilt your head upward or downward.

 

Option C. C2-C3 joint: This joint is between the second and third cervical vertebrae. While it does allow for some degree of rotation, it does not provide the primary rotational movement to look right or left. The range of motion at this joint is less compared to the atlanto-axial joint, and it's more involved in flexion, extension, and some lateral bending.

 

Option D. C3-C4 joint: This joint is between the third and fourth cervical vertebrae. Like the C2-C3 joint, the C3-C4 joint also provides some degree of rotation but not the primary movement. Its main movements are flexion, extension, and lateral bending of the neck. The lower down the cervical spine you go, the less rotational capacity there typically is at each subsequent joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atlanto-axial joint is formed between the first cervical vertebra (the atlas or C1) and the second cervical vertebra (the axis or C2). The dens or odontoid process, fits into the atlas, allowing for a pivot-like rotation. This is the joint responsible for allowing the rotation of the head from side to side, as in signaling "no" or looking right and left. It provides the majority of the rotational capability of the head.

questions.text: According to IMNCI, a 6-month-old child is said to have pneumonia if the child has fast breathing with a respiratory rate more than: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 50

 

In the Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI) guidelines, fast breathing is a key indicator for diagnosing pneumonia in children. The breathing rate cutoffs are age-specific:

 

  • For children less than 2 months old: > 60 breaths per minute.
  • For children aged 2 to 12 months: > 50 breaths per minute.
  • For children aged 12 to 60 months: > 40 breaths per minute.

 

Therefore, for a 6-month-old child, a respiratory rate greater than 50 breaths per minute is considered indicative of pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to IMNCI, a 6-month-old child is considered to have pneumonia if the respiratory rate is more than 50 breaths per minute.

questions.text: A 22-year-old pregnant lady presents with fever and is put on antibiotics. Fever is still not brought under control. On further investigation, she is diagnosed to have septic pelvic thrombophlebitis. Which among the following is the next course of treatment for her? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antibiotics + Heparin

 

Explanation:

 

Antibiotics + heparin:

 

Septic pelvic thrombophlebitis (SPT) is a rare postpartum infective complication characterized by persistent high-grade fever despite broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy. It typically occurs after delivery or abortion and is often seen in women with risk factors like cesarean section, prolonged labor, or pelvic infection.

 

The fever in SPT is caused by a septic thrombus in the pelvic veins—most commonly the ovarian vein—that harbors bacteria and incites a sustained inflammatory response. Since antibiotics alone cannot fully penetrate the infected thrombus, the addition of anticoagulation (usually low molecular weight heparin) is essential. Heparin helps in lysing the thrombus, preventing further propagation and improving antibiotic penetration.

 

Clinical improvement is usually seen within 48–72 hours of initiating combined therapy with antibiotics and heparin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stop antibiotics and start heparin:  Incorrect because infection is still present—antibiotics are needed to control the infective component.  Stopping antibiotics would worsen sepsis.

 

Option C. Surgical embolectomy:  Too invasive and not first-line.  Reserved for rare cases with septic emboli or failure to respond to medical management.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: Not indicated unless there’s uncontrolled pelvic infection not responding to medical therapy or associated endomyometritis with uterine necrosis.  SPT is usually confined to pelvic veins, not requiring removal of the uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best management for pregnant women with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) to prevent recurrent pregnancy loss includes low-dose aspirin and low molecular weight heparin (LMWH).

 

Ref: Page no 2951, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: You discover that there is evidence of cardiac malformation in a fetus during a routine US scan at 16 weeks. What is the minimum level of fasting blood sugar at which you can suspect overt diabetes? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 126 mg/dL

 

Overt diabetes in a patient is diagnosed based on specific blood glucose levels. The criteria for diagnosing overt diabetes are:

 

  • Fasting blood sugar: ≥ 126 mg/dL
  • Random blood sugar: ≥ 200 mg/dL
  • HbA1c: ≥ 6.5%

 

During pregnancy, maternal hyperglycemia, especially during the first trimester when organogenesis occurs, increases the risk of fetal congenital malformations, including cardiac malformations. This is particularly true for women with pre-gestational diabetes, not gestational diabetes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 106 mg/dL: This is incorrect. A fasting blood sugar level of 106 mg/dL does not meet the threshold for diagnosing overt diabetes.

 

Option C. 116 mg/dL: This is incorrect. A fasting blood sugar level of 116 mg/dL is higher than normal but still below the threshold for diagnosing overt diabetes.

 

Option D. 130 mg/dL: This is incorrect. Although higher than the threshold, the minimum level to suspect overt diabetes is 126 mg/dL, not 130 mg/dL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Overt diabetes in pregnancy is diagnosed with a fasting blood sugar level of ≥ 126 mg/dL, and maternal hyperglycemia.

questions.text: Cardiac oedema and neuropathy are seen in which of the following vitamin deficiencies? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thiamine

 

Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency is associated with cardiac edema and neuropathy. The deficiency of thiamine can manifest in two main forms:

 

  • Wet beriberi: This form of thiamine deficiency primarily affects the cardiovascular system. It is characterized by symptoms such as tachycardia, cardiomegaly, cardiac failure, and edema. This condition is commonly observed in populations with diets heavily based on polished rice, such as in refugee camps.
  • Dry beriberi: This form affects the nervous system and includes symptoms such as peripheral neuropathy, optic atrophy, ataxia, and irritability.

 

Thiamine deficiency can also lead to complications such as lactic acidosis and Wernicke encephalopathy in adults. The diagnosis can be established by assessing erythrocyte transketolase activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biotin: Biotin deficiency is rare and can be observed in individuals who consume large amounts of raw eggs (which contain avidin that binds biotin) for several months. Symptoms include anorexia, vomiting, dry scaly dermatitis, glossitis, and hypercholesterolemia. It can also occur in patients receiving long-term parenteral nutrition without biotin supplementation.

 

Option C. Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6): Deficiency in pyridoxine is associated with neonatal seizures and other symptoms such as dermatitis, glossitis, and depression, but not specifically with cardiac edema and neuropathy.

 

Option D. Riboflavin (Vitamin B2): Deficiency in riboflavin, known as ariboflavinosis, presents with photophobia, glossitis, angular stomatitis, seborrheic dermatitis, corneal vascularization, and cataracts, but not with cardiac edema and neuropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency is characterized by cardiac edema and neuropathy, manifesting as wet beriberi (cardiovascular symptoms) and dry beriberi (neurological symptoms).

questions.text: What is the maneuver depicted in the image given below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trotter’s method

 

The image shows Trotter's method in which the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood and breathe quietly from the mouth. It is the first step to control epistaxis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epley's maneuver: Is used in the treatment of BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo).

 

 

Option C. Mc Govern technique: A feeding nipple with a large hole provides a good oral airway. It is used as an emergency management may be required in bilateral choanal atresia to provide an airway.

 

 

Option D. Valsalva maneuver: A technique where the patient forcefully exhales while keeping the mouth and nose closed. This increases intrathoracic pressure and is used in various medical situations, including adjusting ear pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trotter’s method is an effective first-line intervention for controlling epistaxis. It emphasizes maintaining an upright, forward-leaning posture to minimize blood swallowing and facilitate proper drainage, essential for patient comfort and safety during a nosebleed episode.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No.  183, 199

choices.text: 200 mg

questions.text: The maximum dose of PGF2 alpha in postpartum hemorrhage is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 mg

 

Explanation:

 

Prostaglandin F2 alpha (PGF2α), also known as carboprost, is used for the treatment of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) due to uterine atony. The therapeutic regimen and maximum dosage are crucial for effective management and patient safety.

 

  • Dose and Administration: The approved dose for treating uterine atony with PGF2α is 0.25 mg administered intramuscularly (IM).
  • Maximum Dose: The maximum cumulative dose is 2 mg. This is achieved by administering a total of 8 doses of 0.25 mg each.
  • Dosing Interval: These doses can be repeated at intervals of 15 to 90 minutes, depending on the clinical response and the patient's condition.

 

Contraindications

 

  • Bronchial Asthma: PGF2α can cause bronchoconstriction, which makes it contraindicated in patients with bronchial asthma.
  • Suspected Amniotic Fluid Embolism: Due to its potential to cause pulmonary airway and vascular constriction, it is also contraindicated in cases of suspected amniotic fluid embolism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.25 mg: This is the single dose administered IM but not the cumulative maximum dose.

 

Option C. 20 mg: This dose is excessively high and not clinically recommended or safe.

 

Option D. 200 mg: This dose is not applicable for human use and is far beyond the safe and recommended limits.

 

Educational Objective

 

The maximum dose of prostaglandin F2 alpha in the management of postpartum hemorrhage is 2 mg, administered in 0.25 mg increments intramuscularly.

 

Ref: Page no 480, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of this patient from the ECG shown below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ventricular tachycardia

 

The ECG displays a rhythm with broad QRS complexes at a high rate, consistent with ventricular tachycardia (VT). VT is characterized by three or more consecutive ventricular beats at a rate of more than 100 beats per minute. The presence of such a pattern, particularly with a stable, repetitive form as seen in the ECG, strongly points to VT rather than other types of arrhythmias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal ECG: This option is incorrect as the ECG clearly shows an abnormal rhythm with broad QRS complexes, indicative of an arrhythmia originating below the AV node.

 

Option B. Ventricular fibrillation: Ventricular fibrillation is characterized by irregular, chaotic electrical activity without identifiable QRS complexes, P waves, or T waves. The rhythm shown here is too organized and regular to be VF.

 

Option D. Misplaced leads: Misplaced leads causes positive p in aVR with normal intervals - R wave progression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ventricular tachycardia is identified by regular, broad QRS complexes at a rapid rate, distinct from the irregular pattern of ventricular fibrillation and the organized, narrower complexes typically seen with supraventricular rhythms and correct lead placement. Identifying VT on an ECG is critical due to its potential severity and the need for prompt treatment.

questions.text: A bus conductor presents with dilated, tortuous veins of 4 mm in the foot. What is the stage of clinical classification according to CEAP (Clinical-etiology-anatomy-pathophysiology for chronic venous disorders)? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. C2

 

Explanation:

 

The CEAP classification system for chronic venous disorders categorizes the severity of venous disease based on clinical signs, etiology, anatomy, and pathophysiology. In this system, the "C" (Clinical) classification is particularly useful for describing the visible and palpable signs of venous disease.

  • C0: No visible or palpable signs of venous disease.
  • C1: Telangiectasias or reticular veins.
  • C2: Varicose veins. This stage is characterized by dilated, tortuous veins that are generally more than 3 mm in diameter, such as the 4 mm veins described in the patient's case.
  • C3: Edema related to venous disease.

 

Given the description of dilated, tortuous veins of 4 mm, the patient's condition corresponds to C2 in the CEAP classification, indicating the presence of varicose veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C0: C0 indicates no visible or palpable signs of venous disease, which does not apply to this patient who has visible varicose veins.

 

Option B. C1: C1 indicates the presence of telangiectasias or reticular veins, which are smaller than 3 mm in diameter. This stage does not describe the 4 mm varicose veins observed in this patient.

 

Option D. C3: C3 is used to classify edema related to chronic venous disorders. This does not match the presentation of dilated, tortuous veins without mentioned edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of dilated, tortuous veins larger than 3 mm, such as the 4 mm veins observed in the patient's foot, corresponds to stage C2 in the CEAP classification system for chronic venous disorders, indicating varicose veins.

questions.text: What is the most common chemistry of gallstones among the following options? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Crystalline cholesterol monohydrate

 

Explanation:

 

Gallstones are crystalline formations that occur in the gallbladder due to the precipitation of substances found in bile. The most common type of gallstones are cholesterol stones, which account for about 80% of all gallstone cases. These stones primarily consist of crystalline cholesterol monohydrate.

 

Types of Gallstones:

 

  • Cholesterol Stones: These are the most prevalent type, made primarily of crystalline cholesterol monohydrate. They are often yellow-green and can vary in size from small grains to large stones.
  • Pigment Stones: Comprising about 20% of gallstones, pigment stones are made of bilirubin and can be either black or brown. These are more likely to form in individuals with liver disease or hemolytic disorders.
  • Mixed Stones: These stones contain both cholesterol and pigment components, and may also include calcium bilirubinate, which is a part of some pigment stones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Crystalline cholesterol dihydrate: This is not a common form of gallstones. Cholesterol stones typically form in the monohydrate crystalline structure rather than dihydrate.

 

Option C. Amorphous cholesterol dihydrate: Gallstones are rarely composed of amorphous cholesterol, and the dihydrate form is not typical. The monohydrate crystalline form is the most common.

 

Option D. Amorphous cholesterol monohydrate: Gallstones are generally crystalline in nature rather than amorphous. Crystalline cholesterol monohydrate is the most common form found in gallstones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common chemistry of gallstones is crystalline cholesterol monohydrate, which constitutes about 80% of all gallstone cases.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image:  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Acanthosis nigricans

 

  • Acanthosis nigricans is the illness depicted in the image.
  • It is characterized by thickened, gray-brown velvety plaques seen in flexural areas such as the back of the neck, axillae, inframammary creases, waist, and groin.
  • The release of epidermal growth factors in the affected area is the causal mechanism.
  • Acanthosis Nigricans may be benign or linked to a malignancy.

 

 

Acanthosis nigricans can also be seen in the following:

 

  • Multiple seborrhoeic keratoses
  • Drugs like nicotinic acid (Use for hyperlipidaemia treatment)
    • Other conditions associated with metabolic syndrome include polycystic ovarian syndrome, sleep apnea & non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.
    • The condition is managed by dietary & lifestyle modifications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pityriasis rotunda

 

  • Description: This is a rare skin condition characterized by large, round patches of dry, scaly skin as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option B. Melasma

 

  • Description: Melasma is characterized by brown to gray-brown patches, mainly on the face (cheeks, bridge of the nose, forehead, chin, and above the upper lip). It's often called the "mask of pregnancy."

 

Option C. Dermatomyositis

 

  • Description: An inflammatory muscle disease, dermatomyositis presents with skin rash and muscle weakness. The rash is often reddish or purple, seen on the eyelids, knuckles, elbows, knees, and sometimes the chest and back.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acanthosis nigricans is marked by a velvety darkening of the skin in body folds.
  • There's a notable link between obesity, acanthosis nigricans, and metabolic syndrome, with the latter condition often being a visible indicator of insulin resistance.
  • Recognizing acanthosis nigricans is vital as it can be a marker of underlying systemic issues that may require comprehensive medical evaluation.

 

References: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 147, Page nos 147.14-147.15

Williams Gynecology 3rd edition Page no 391

questions.text: What is the diagnosis in the following radiograph? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spondylolisthesis

 

  • The images show the cervical vertebrae where, at the lower cervical spine (C4-C7), there is an anterior slippage of one vertebral body over the one below it. 
  • In the left image, C5 appears to be shifted anteriorly relative to C6. 
  • This slippage is referred to as spondylolisthesis.
  • Spondylolisthesis involves forward displacement of one vertebra over another.
  • Pathology:
    • The pars interarticularis is disrupted on both sides (spondylolysis), separating the posterior neural arch from vertebral body; gap is later filled by fibrous tissue.
    • The vertebral body undergoes anterior dislocation under stress.
  • Radiological Features:
    • Lateral view: Forward shift of the upper part of spinal column on the stable vertebra below; elongation of the arch or defective facets may be seen.
    • Oblique views are needed to clearly demonstrate fracture of pars interarticularis (Beheaded Scottie dog sign)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteoporosis. Osteoporosis is a systemic condition characterized by reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration. Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse), and codfish appearance. It typically appears as generalized radiolucency (bones look "thinner" or "washed out") and potentially vertebral compression fractures. 

 

 

Option C. Spondylolysis. Spondylolysis is characterized by presence of bony defect or fracture at pars interarticularis, which can result in spondylolisthesis. Most common vertebra having spondylolysis is L5. It is difficult to definitively diagnose spondylolysis on a plain lateral cervical X-ray without oblique views or a CT.  

 

 

Option D. Discitis. This is an or infection of the intervertebral disc and adjacent vertebral bodies. Radiographically, it would typically show disc space narrowing. This is not the primary finding observed in these images. Discitis is a serious but uncommon infection or inflammation of the intervertebral disc space. Radiographic findings include the narrowing of disc space, irregular endplates, and sometimes erosions or sclerosis of the vertebral bodies.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image shown in the given question shows spondylolisthesis of C6 vertebra over C7 vertebra.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of Oseltamivir and zanamivir? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neuraminidase inhibition

 

Both Oseltamivir and Zanamivir are antiviral medications used to treat influenza. They work by inhibiting the enzyme neuraminidase, which is critical for the release of new influenza virus particles from infected cells. By inhibiting this enzyme, these drugs limit the spread of the virus within the host.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DNA polymerase inhibition: This mechanism is typically seen in antiviral agents used to treat herpesviruses or other DNA viruses, not influenza viruses which are RNA viruses. Oseltamivir and Zanamivir are not DNA polymerase inhibitors.

 

Option B. Protein synthesis inhibition: These drugs do not act by inhibiting protein synthesis. Agents like tetracyclines or macrolides, which are antibiotics, usually have this mechanism of action.

 

Option C. Nucleotide analogue: While nucleotide analogues are commonly used to treat certain viral infections (e.g., acyclovir for herpes or antiretrovirals for HIV), Oseltamivir and Zanamivir are not nucleotide analogues. They do not incorporate into the viral genome to disrupt replication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oseltamivir and zanamivir are neuraminidase inhibitors used to treat influenza. By inhibiting the neuraminidase enzyme, these drugs prevent the release of new viral particles from infected cells, limiting the spread of the virus within the host.

choices.text: Parkinson Disease
Alzheimer's disease

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is most commonly associated with Down's syndrome: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alzheimer’s disease

 

Individuals with Down’s syndrome are at a significantly higher risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease, often in their 30s and 40s, due to the presence of three copies of chromosome 21, which contains the APP gene involved in the production of amyloid precursor protein—a key factor in Alzheimer’s pathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parkinson Disease: Not specifically associated with Down's syndrome.

 

Option C. Schizophrenia: No significant correlation between Down's syndrome and schizophrenia.

 

Option D. Huntington's Disease: No direct association with Down's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conditions most commonly associated with Down's syndrome:

 

  • Congenital heart disease (in about 35% of cases)
  • Gastrointestinal anomalies (in about 10%)
  • Chronic serous otitis media (in >50%)
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Alzheimer's disease (in the 30's and 40's)
  • Epilepsy (in about 10%)
  • Ocular disorders
  • Reduced fertility
  • Reduced life span (Often due to complications like infections)

questions.text: Nasal polyps are commonly associated with: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Intrinsic asthma

 

Intrinsic asthma, also known as non-allergic asthma, is often associated with nasal polyps. This type of asthma does not have an allergic or atopic component and tends to develop in adulthood. Intrinsic asthma is characterized by a non-IgE mediated pathway involving eosinophils and neutrophils, often triggered by non-allergic factors such as viral infections, stress, or exercise. Nasal polyps in this context are linked to chronic inflammation of the sinuses and nasal passages, common in non-allergic forms of asthma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Brittle asthma: This is a term used to describe a severe form of asthma where patients experience frequent, severe exacerbations. While serious, it does not specifically correlate with the presence of nasal polyps more than other types of asthma.

 

Option C. Extrinsic asthma: Known as allergic asthma, it is mediated by IgE and typically involves allergen triggers like pollen, dust mites, and molds. Nasal polyps are less commonly associated with this subtype compared to intrinsic asthma.

 

Option D. Exercise-induced asthma: This condition, characterized by bronchoconstriction triggered by physical activity, is not typically associated with nasal polyps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Pulmonology/Asthma/Chap 287

questions.text: Identify the lesion of vocal cord in the image given below: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laryngeal papilloma

 

The image depicts laryngeal papilloma.

 

Laryngeal papillomatosis (juvenile papillomatosis)

 

  • Juvenile papillomatosis is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children.
  • It is viral in origin and is caused by human papilloma virus type 6 and 11.
  • It is presumed that affected children got the disease at birth from their mothers who had vaginal human papillomavirus disease.
  • Papilloma’s mostly affect supraglottic and glottic regions of the larynx but can also involve subglottis, trachea and bronchi. DNA virus particles have been found in the cells of the basement membrane of respiratory mucosa and may account for widespread involvement and recurrence.
  • Patients, often a child, between the age of 3 and 5 years present with hoarseness or aphonia with respiratory difficulty or even stridor.
  • Diagnosis is made by flexible fiberoptic laryngoscopy and later confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy.
  • Papillomas are known for recurrence but rarely undergo malignant change.
  • Treatment consists of microlaryngoscopy and CO2 laser excision avoiding injury to vocal ligament. Other modalities of tumor removal are with cold steel instruments or  debrider or coblation or radiofrequency. Aim of therapy is to maintain a good airway, preserve voice and avoid recurrence.
  • Adjuvant medical therapies include Interferon alpha-2a and 13-cis-retinoic acid has been used.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Reinke's edema - Characterized by swelling of the vocal cords due to fluid accumulation, not similar to the warty growths of papillomas.

 

Option B. Malignancy - Would typically appear more irregular and could involve more invasive growth patterns.

 

Option C. Tracheomalacia - A condition related to the softening of the tracheal walls, not relevant to laryngeal lesions.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Laryngeal papilloma is a significant pediatric condition caused by HPV, manifesting as benign, wart-like growths within the larynx. While these tumors are prone to recurrence, they rarely undergo malignant transformation, making careful ongoing monitoring and management essential.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 345

choices.text: Rupture of valve
Calcification and fibrosis
Hypertrophy of ventricular wall
Hypertrophy of the atrial wall

questions.text: A 47-year-old female patient with a long-standing history of rheumatic heart disease was admitted to hospital due to severe breathlessness. She died on the 3rd day following admission. The mitral valve shows the following findings on autopsy. What is the cause of these findings? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calcification and Fibrosis

 

The illustration depicts rheumatic heart disease and mitral stenosis with a fish mouth or buttonhole appearance. Calcification and fibrosis are the causes.

 

RHD is primarily identified by mitral stenosis, for which it is essentially the primary cause, and deforming fibrotic valvular disease.

 

The leaflet thickening, commissural fusion and shortening, and thickening and fusing of the tendinous cords are the three primary anatomic alterations of the mitral valve in chronic RHD.

 

"Fish mouth" or "buttonhole" stenosis are caused by calcification and fibrous bridging over the valvular commissures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rupture of valve: Not indicated in the image or history provided.

 

Option C. Hypertrophy of ventricular wall: While ventricular wall hypertrophy may occur due to increased workload from valvular heart disease, it is not visible on this image of the valve.

 

Option D. Hypertrophy of the atrial wall: Similar to ventricular hypertrophy, atrial wall hypertrophy may occur in response to increased pressure from stenosed valves but is not the direct cause visible in the valve image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with a history of rheumatic heart disease, the mitral valve often undergoes significant morphological changes due to fibrosis and calcification, leading to stenosis with a characteristic "fish mouth" appearance. Understanding these changes is crucial for diagnosing and managing the progression of the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of tubercular otitis media? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Earache

 

Earache is not a feature of tubercular otitis media.

 

Tuberculosis of the ear

 

  •  Aetiology - Secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis.
  •  Pathology - The process is slow and insidious. Tubercles appear in the submucosal layers of middle ear cleft and caseate. There is painless necrosis of the tympanic membrane. Multiple perforations may form which coalesce to form a single large perforation. Middle ear and mastoid get filled with pale granulations.
  • Clinical features - Painless foul smelling ear discharge, multiple perforations, hearing loss. Mastoiditis, facial paralysis, postauricular fistula, osteomyelitis with formation of bony sequestra are often seen in these cases.
  •  Treatment - Antitubercular treatment + Mastoidectomy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple perforations - A characteristic feature of the disease, representing advanced tissue damage.

 

Option C. Pale granulation - These are typical findings within the affected structures.

 

Option D. Foul smelling ear discharge - A hallmark symptom of tubercular otitis media due to the extensive necrosis and infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Earache is notably absent in tubercular otitis media, differentiating it from other types of middle ear infections where pain is a common symptom. Recognizing the painless nature of this condition is crucial for prompt and accurate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A resident physician sustained a needlestick injury while collecting a blood sample from a patient with HIV. It has been decided to provide the physician with post-exposure prophylaxis. What would be the most suitable course of action among the options below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lamivudine+ Tenofovir+ Dolutegravir for 4 weeks 

 

Post Exposure Prophylaxis HIV

 

Preferably within 24 hours. Maximum within 72 hours.

 

Dose - Tenofovir (300 mg) + Lamivudine (300 mg) + Dolutegravir (50 mg) as 1 tablet/drug OD

 

Duration of PEP is 28 days, irrespective of Regimen type

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Annual Parasite Index
Annual Blood Examination Rate
Slide positivity rate
Slide falciparum rate

questions.text: Which parameters would you utilize to assess the efficiency of the malaria surveillance system under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programmer? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Annual Blood Examination Rate

 

Annual blood examination rate (ABER): (Index of operational efficiency)

 

 

 

ABER is a critical parameter used to assess the efficiency of the malaria surveillance system under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Program. It reflects the proportion of the population that is being tested for malaria and helps determine the operational efficiency of the surveillance system. High ABER indicates effective surveillance and control measures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Annual parasitic incidence (API): Sophisticated measure of malaria incidence in a community

 

 

Option C. Slide positivity rate (SPR):

 

 

Option D. Slide falciparum rate: specifically measures the proportion of slides that are positive for Plasmodium falciparum, the most severe form of malaria. It indicates the burden of P. falciparum in the population.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is not used as an immediate test in the screening of urinary tract infections (UTI)? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pour plate culture

 

Pour plate culture (quantitative test) is not used as an immediate test for screening of UTI. However, it is considered the best diagnostic test for confirmation of UTI due it's high sensitivity and specificity.

 

Other Options:

 

Screening Tests for UTI:

 

Option B. Griess Nitrite test: This test detects nitrites in the urine, which are generally produced by nitrate-reducing bacteria such as Escherichia coli, a common cause of UTIs. It is a quick and effective screening tool.

 

Option C. Leukocyte esterase test: This test identifies the presence of leukocyte esterase, an enzyme released by white blood cells (leukocytes). A positive result suggests inflammation or infection, common in UTIs.

 

Option D. Wet mount examination: This involves examining a sample of urine under a microscope to detect the presence of pus cells, bacteria, or other elements indicative of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The screening tests for UTI are as follows:

 

  • Wet mount examination: It is done to demonstrate pus cells in urine.
  • Leukocyte esterase test: It is a rapid and cheaper method, and detects leukocyte esterases secreted by pus cells present in urine.
  • Nitrate reduction test (Griess test): Nitrate reducing bacteria like E. coli give a positive result.
  • Catalase test: E. coli and other bacteria that produce the enzyme catalase give a positive result.

 

Quantitative Culture:

 

  • Standardized loop technique
  • Pour plate method

choices.text: Placental site trophoblastic tumor
Invasive mole

questions.text: Gestational trophoblastic neoplasm does not include? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Partial mole

 

Explanation:

 

Gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) includes a spectrum of conditions characterized by abnormal trophoblastic proliferation. These conditions are broadly classified into molar and non-molar trophoblastic diseases.

 

  • Hydatidiform Mole:
    • Complete Mole
    • Partial Mole
    • Invasive Mole
  • Non-Molar Trophoblastic Diseases:
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Placental Site Trophoblastic Tumor
    • Epithelioid Trophoblastic Tumor

 

Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia (GTN), on the other hand, includes only the malignant forms of trophoblastic disease:

 

  1. Invasive Mole
  2. Choriocarcinoma
  3. Placental Site Trophoblastic Tumor
  4. Epithelioid Trophoblastic Tumor

 

A partial mole is a type of hydatidiform mole and is considered benign. It is not included under GTN as it does not have malignant potential unless it transforms into an invasive mole, which is rare.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Choriocarcinoma: This is a malignant form of GTD and is classified under GTN.

 

Option C. Placental Site Trophoblastic Tumor: This is another malignant form of GTD and is included under GTN.

 

Option D. Invasive Mole: An invasive mole is a malignant transformation of a hydatidiform mole and is included under GTN.

 

Educational Objective

 

Partial moles are not classified as gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) because they are generally benign and non-malignant.

 

Ref: Page no 615, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Sweat chloride test chloride conc of 70 mEg/L

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in a child with cystic fibrosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyperkalemia

 

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a genetic disorder that affects multiple systems, primarily the respiratory and digestive systems, due to a defect in the CFTR gene.

 

This is not typically seen in cystic fibrosis. Instead, CF patients are more likely to experience hypokalemia due to the loss of electrolytes through sweat and the effects of contraction alkalosis.

 

Other Options:

 

The diagnosis and features of cystic fibrosis include:

 

Option A. Sweat chloride test chloride concentration of 70 mEq/L: The sweat chloride test is the gold standard for diagnosing CF. A chloride concentration greater than 60 mEq/L is indicative of CF.

 

Option B. Increased immunoreactive trypsinogen level: Newborn screening for CF often includes measuring immunoreactive trypsinogen levels, which are elevated in CF patients.

 

Option D. Contraction alkalosis: CF patients can present with contraction alkalosis due to loss of water and sodium, and renal waste of potassium and hydrogen ions. This is similar to the effects seen in patients taking loop diuretics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperkalemia is not typically seen in cystic fibrosis. Instead, patients with CF may present with hypokalemia and contraction alkalosis due to electrolyte losses.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for a woman with atrophic vaginitis with complaints of itching? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Topical estrogen

 

Explanation

 

Topical estrogen:

 

  • Atrophic vaginitis, also known as vaginal atrophy, is a condition that commonly affects postmenopausal women due to decreased estrogen levels. It leads to symptoms such as vaginal dryness, itching, and discomfort.
  • Local estrogen preparations are preferred over systemic hormone replacement therapy (HRT) for the treatment of postmenopausal vaginal atrophy. This is because local treatments directly target the affected area and have fewer systemic side effects.
  • The use of 1 g of conjugated estrogen cream intravaginally, applied each day for 1 to 2 weeks, generally provides symptomatic relief for women experiencing atrophic vaginitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Steroids: Steroids are not the treatment of choice for atrophic vaginitis. They do not address the underlying cause, which is the lack of estrogen.

 

Option C. Antihistamines only: Antihistamines may provide temporary relief from itching but do not treat the underlying cause of atrophic vaginitis, which is estrogen deficiency.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect as topical estrogen is the recommended treatment for atrophic vaginitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment of choice for atrophic vaginitis, particularly in postmenopausal women, is the application of topical estrogen to provide symptomatic relief and address the underlying estrogen deficiency.

 

Ref: Page 1469, Speroff’s Clinical Gynecology

questions.text: What is the dose of Ulipristal used in emergency contraception? (NEET PG  2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 30 mg

 

Explanation:

 

The dose of Ulipristal in emergency contraception is 30 mg to be taken within 72 hrs (can be taken upto 120hrs).

 

The following can be used as emergency contraceptives:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dose of Ulipristal for emergency contraception is 30 mg, to be taken within 72 hours (up to 120 hours) after unprotected intercourse.

 

Ref: Page no 630, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: What is the stain used for identifying cryptococcus? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mucicarmine

 

Mucicarmine staining is specifically used to identify Cryptococcus, particularly useful in highlighting the thick polysaccharide capsule that is characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans, a yeast-like fungus that can cause serious infections, especially in immunocompromised individuals. The mucicarmine stain binds to the acidic polysaccharides of the fungal capsule and stains it a bright red, making it distinctly visible against a light blue background. This staining technique is especially valuable in histopathological diagnosis of cryptococcal infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Giemsa stain: Primarily used for blood parasites and certain bacteria, it's not specific for fungal structures.

 

Option B. Ziehl-Nielsen stain: Used to identify acid-fast bacteria, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, not fungi.

 

Option C. Gram staining: While it can stain a variety of bacteria, it is generally not effective for encapsulated fungi like Cryptococcus due to its poor affinity for fungal polysaccharide capsules.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Skin accounts for 15% of total body weight
Dermis is made up of type 1 and type 3 collagen

questions.text: Which of the following is false about skin? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Dermis is derived from ectoderm

 

Dermis is derived from mesoderm and epidermis is derived from ectoderm.

 

  • The epidermis is derived from the ectoderm, which is one of the three primary germ layers that form during embryonic development.
  • The ectoderm gives rise to the skin, hair, nails, and the nervous system.
  • The epidermis itself is formed by the surface ectoderm, which begins to thicken and form a layer of cells called the basal layer.
  • On the other hand, the dermis is derived from the mesoderm, which is another one of the primary germ layers.
  • The mesoderm gives rise to a number of different structures in the body, including muscles, bones, and connective tissue.
  • The dermis itself is formed from the mesenchymal cells that migrate into the developing skin from the mesoderm.
  • These cells differentiate into fibroblasts, which then produce the extracellular matrix that forms the dermis.
  • During development, the epidermis and dermis layers interact and become tightly integrated.
  • As the epidermis differentiates, it sends signals to the underlying mesenchymal cells to produce the dermis, and the two layers eventually become fully functional together as the skin.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Skin accounts for 15% of total body weight: This statement is generally accurate. In adults, the skin weighs about 8-10 pounds and has a surface area of about 2 square meters. The skin is the largest organ of the body, and its weight can be roughly estimated to be around 15% of the total body weight, although this can vary based on individuals and their body compositions.

 

Option C. Epidermis is derived from ectoderm: This statement is true. The epidermis is the outermost layer of the skin and is indeed derived from the ectoderm during embryonic development. It's a stratified squamous epithelium that mainly consists of keratinocytes in progressive stages of differentiation, from the basal layer to the surface. The epidermis provides the body with a barrier against pathogens, UV radiation, and water loss.

 

Option D. Dermis is made up of type 1 and type 3 collagen: This statement is true. The dermis, which provides the skin's strength and elasticity, primarily consists of type 1 collagen, but it also contains a smaller amount of type 3 collagen, especially in the papillary dermis (the uppermost layer of the dermis). These collagens are essential for skin's resilience and durability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dermis is derived from the mesoderm, not the ectoderm.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis seen in the image below?  NEET PG 2019
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Candidal intertrigo

 

The condition shown in the image is Candidal intertrigo.

 

Various types of candidiasis:

 

  1. Candidal intertrigo:
    • Manifests with erythematous, non-scaly moist patches of opposing skin surfaces, with a little moist exudation starting deep in a fold.
    • When the web spaces of the toes or fingers are affected, marked maceration with a thick, white, horny layer is usually prominent.
    • Tiny, superficial, white pustular satellite lesions can be seen at the margins of the intertriginous patch.
  2. Candidal paronychia: Swelling of nail fold
  3. Candidal balanoposthitis: Seen in patients with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, associated with swelling of prepuce.
  4. Perlèche/ Angular stomatitis: Soreness and cracking at the angles of the mouth are seen in Perlèche. It is considered as an intertrigo where candida is the most common organism implicated.

 

 

Investigations:

 

  • KOH mount → Pseudo hyphae

 

Treatment:

 

  • Topical: Antifungal agents such as nystatin, ketoconazole, and clotrimazole are routinely used.
  • Oral: Fluconazole

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidal paronychia

  • This refers to an infection of the nail fold, leading to a painful and red swelling around the nail.
  • It can be due to bacterial or candidal infection.

 

Option C. Diabetic foot ulcer

  • This is an open sore or wound commonly located on the bottom of the foot in people with diabetes.
  • Factors leading to diabetic foot ulcers include neuropathy, peripheral arterial disease, foot deformities, and trauma.
  • The skin around the ulcer may be calloused or discolored but not typically macerated.

 

Option D. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS)

  • This is a serious skin disorder caused by the exotoxins of Staphylococcus aureus.
  • It primarily affects infants and young children.
  • It is characterized by blistering and the appearance that the top layer of skin is scalded or burned.
  • SSSS affects larger areas of the body and often starts with facial erythema, widespread redness, and blisters, which then rupture, leaving raw areas. Maceration of toe web spaces would not be a primary symptom.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candidal intertrigo can be identified by the classic presentation of erythema, maceration, and possible white exudate in skin folds, such as the web spaces between fingers, distinguishing it from conditions that affect the nail folds, feet, or involve widespread skin desquamation.

 

Reference:  Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 32, Page nos 32.61-32.63

choices.text: MHC class II presents peptide antigen to CD4 T cells
The action of MHC II occurs via endocytic pathway
MHC Class II presents endogenous antigens
MHC II is present on antigen presenting cells

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding MHC molecules? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MHC Class II presents endogenous antigens

 

MHC Class II molecules are specifically involved in presenting exogenous antigens, ( antigens foreign to the body eg antigens of bacteria, viruses etc)  not endogenous ( self-antigens). These exogenous antigens are typically derived from organisms outside the cell, such as bacteria or viruses that have been ingested by the cell via phagocytosis or endocytosis. MHC Class II then presents peptides from these processed antigens to CD4+ T cells, triggering an immune response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MHC class II presents peptide antigen to CD4 T cells: True, which is a key component of the immune response modulation.

 

Option B. The action of MHC II occurs via the endocytic pathway: True, this pathway involves the processing of phagocytosed material.

 

Option D. MHC II is present on antigen-presenting cells: True, which is essential for initiating the immune response by interacting with CD4+ T cells.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image given below: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Fornix

 

  • The image given shows a midsagittal section of the brain.
  • The structure marked is the Fornix.
  • The fornix is a C-shaped bundle of white matter located in the medial surface of the brain, just below the corpus callosum.
  • The fornix is an important part of the limbic system, and it is the hippocampus's largest single pathway, connecting it to various subcortical structures.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pineal gland: It is a small endocrine gland located in a midsagittal section, seen as a small structure located posterior to the third ventricle in the midline, projecting from the diencephalon. Its main hormone, melatonin, plays a critical role in the regulation of circadian rhythms, influencing sleep-wake cycles.

 

Option B. Falx cerebri: It is a dural fold that descends vertically in the longitudinal fissure, which divides the cerebral hemispheres. In a midsagittal view, it appears as a thin membrane running vertically between the left and right cerebral hemispheres. The falx cerebri attaches anteriorly to the crista galli of the ethmoid bone and posteriorly to the internal occipital protuberance.

 

Option D. Pituitary gland: It is often referred to as the "master gland", is an endocrine gland responsible for producing several critical hormones that regulate growth, blood pressure, and other functions. In the midsagittal view, the pituitary gland is located at the base of the brain, hanging down from a stalk (infundibulum) from the hypothalamus. This gland rests within a depression in the sphenoid bone called the sella turcica.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fornix is a C-shaped bundle of nerve fibers that acts as a major output tract from the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies and then onto the thalamus. In the midsagittal section, the fornix is seen as an arching structure that lies inferior to the corpus callosum, the massive fiber tract connecting the two cerebral hemispheres. The body of the fornix travels anteriorly and inferiorly, eventually dividing into left and right columns which curve downward in front of the thalamus.

questions.text: Which of the following is commonly associated with the condition shown below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pitting of nails

 

The given scenario suggests alopecia areata in which geometric fine stippled pitting (Superficial, Regular, Fine) of nail is the most likely expected finding as shown below.

 

 

Alopecia areata:

 

  • Alopecia areata is a chronic Autoimmune disease that causes non scaring patches of hair loss.
  • It is a T cell mediated inflammatory disease that occurs in genetically predisposed individuals. Pigmented hair is more frequently affected in alopecia areata.
  • Grey hair in older patients often includes both white and coloured hair. Only coloured hair will be impacted by the disease if it advances quickly, sparing white hair. This leads to a dramatic change in overall hair colour that is called going white overnight.

 

The following image sparing of white hair within patches of hair loss.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nail changes are common in alopecia areata, with nail pitting being the most frequent finding.
  • Nail pitting appears as small depressions on the nail surface.

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 89 page no 89.28-33

questions.text: Mrs. Patel is a 45-year-old woman who has recently been diagnosed with estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. Her doctor informs her that the cancer is hormone-dependent. The doctor recommends a treatment plan that includes surgery, radiation therapy, and hormone therapy. What is the drug used for estrogen dependent breast cancer? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tamoxifen

 

Explanation:

 

Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used to treat hormone receptor-positive breast cancers, particularly in premenopausal women. It is effective for estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer, which is hormone-dependent. Tamoxifen works by blocking the effects of estrogen in the breast tissue, thereby preventing cancer cells from growing and spreading.

  • Mechanism of Action: Tamoxifen competes with estrogen for binding to estrogen receptors in breast tissue. By blocking estrogen's effects, it inhibits the growth and proliferation of estrogen-dependent cancer cells.
  • Administration: Tamoxifen is taken orally, usually once a day for five years.
  • Side Effects: Common side effects include hot flashes, mood changes, vaginal dryness, and an increased risk of blood clots (DVT).

 

Uses of Tamoxifen:

  • Primary Prophylaxis: Used for the primary prophylaxis of breast cancer in high-risk women.
  • Risk Reduction: Reduces the risk of carcinoma in the contralateral breast.
  • Recurrence Prevention: Lowers the risk of recurrence of carcinoma in both ipsilateral and contralateral breasts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Estrogen: Estrogen is not used as a treatment for estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer because it would promote cancer cell growth. In fact, therapies aim to reduce or block estrogen to prevent cancer progression.

 

Option B. Clomiphene citrate: Clomiphene citrate is a medication used to induce ovulation in women with fertility issues. It is not used in the treatment of breast cancer.

 

Option D. Adriamycin (Doxorubicin): Adriamycin is a chemotherapy drug used to treat various types of cancer, including breast cancer. It works by interfering with the DNA in cancer cells, preventing them from dividing and growing. While effective in some cancer treatments, it is not specifically used for hormone therapy in estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tamoxifen is the drug used for treating estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer by blocking the effects of estrogen on breast tissue, thereby preventing the growth and spread of hormone-dependent cancer cells.

choices.text: Fetal lung fluid
Maternal plasma

questions.text: Major contributor for amniotic fluid post 20 weeks is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fetal urine

 

Explanation:

 

  • Fetal urine production begins from 8-11 weeks period of gestation
  • In the first trimester, amniotic fluid is generally composed of extracellular fluid secreted across the amnion via trans membranous flow; across the fetal vessels on placental surface via intramembranous flow; and via transcutaneous flow across fetal skin.
  • Fetal urine is the major contributor for amniotic fluid post 20 weeks.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fetal skin: While fetal skin does contribute to amniotic fluid in the first trimester through transcutaneous flow, it is not the major contributor post 20 weeks.

 

Option C. Fetal lung fluid: Fetal lung fluid contributes to the amniotic fluid but not as significantly as fetal urine post 20 weeks.

 

Option D. Maternal plasma: Maternal plasma contributes indirectly to amniotic fluid via transmembranous flow, but it is not the major contributor post 20 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fetal urine is the major contributor to amniotic fluid volume post 20 weeks of gestation.

 

Ref: Page no 34, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: It can be reduced by matching
It is associated individually with both cause and effect
It is distributed equally in both study and control groups
It is associated with the exposure of the study

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding a confounding factor? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is distributed equally in both study and control groups

 

  • Confounding factor: Any factor associated with both exposure and outcome, and has an independent effect in causation of outcome is a confounder.
  • It is found unequally distributed between the study and control groups

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It can be reduced by matching:  Matching is a technique used in study design to control for confounding by ensuring that study groups are comparable with respect to potential confounders.

 

Option C. It is distributed equally in both study and control groups:  This statement is incorrect. A confounding factor is typically unequally distributed between the study and control groups. If it were equally distributed, it would not confound the results.

 

Option D. It is associated with the exposure of the study:  A confounder is associated with the exposure and can influence the observed effect of the exposure on the outcome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Confounding can be removed by

 

1. Matching → MC used /simplest method

2. Randomization → 2nd Best Method

3. Restriction

4. Stratification

5. Statistical Modelling / Multivariate analysis (MVA)

6. Stratified Randomization → Overall Best Method

choices.text: Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle
Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle
Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle

questions.text: Which of these is the most common site of a branchial cyst? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle

Explanation:

 

The typical location for a branchial cyst is at the anterior border of the junction between the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle. Branchial cysts are developmental anomalies that arise from the remnants of the second branchial cleft. They are lined by squamous epithelium and contain thick, cloudy fluid that often includes cholesterol crystals. This location is key for identifying and diagnosing branchial cysts.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle: This location is typically associated with the external opening of a branchial fistula, not a branchial cyst.

 

Option C. Middle of the sternomastoid muscle: This is not the usual site for branchial cysts. Branchial cysts are more commonly found at the anterior border of the upper and middle third junction.

 

Option D. Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle: This area is not associated with the typical location of branchial cysts. The cysts are more commonly found anterior to the sternomastoid muscle.

 

Additional Information on Branchial Cysts:

  • Origin: Congenital or acquired remnants of the second branchial cleft.
  • Lining: Squamous epithelium.
  • Contents: Thick, cloudy fluid with cholesterol crystals, sometimes clear fluid making the cyst soft and shiny.
  • Branchial Fistula: The external opening of a branchial fistula is at the junction of the middle and lower third of the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid.

 

Educational Objective:
