The most common site for a branchial cyst is at the anterior border of the junction between the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle.

questions.text: What is the ideal time for nuchal translucency evaluation? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 11-14 weeks

 

Explanation

 

Nuchal Translucency (NT):

 

  • Definition: Nuchal translucency refers to the maximum thickness of the subcutaneous translucent area between the skin and soft tissue overlying the fetal spine at the back of the neck.
  • Significance: An increased NT measurement is associated with an increased risk for fetal aneuploidy (such as Down syndrome) and various structural anomalies including cardiovascular defects, hydrops fetalis, and cystic hygroma.

 

Timing:

 

  • NT is measured between 11 weeks and 13 weeks 6 days (or 11-14 weeks) of gestation. This time frame is critical as it ensures the accuracy of the measurement and its correlation with potential anomalies.

 

Measurement Criteria:

 

  • Crown-Rump Length (CRL): Should be between 45-84 mm.
  • Fetal Position: Fetus should be in the mid-sagittal plane and in a neutral position.
  • Image Quality: The image must be magnified, and the widest space should be measured.
  • Caliper Placement: The ‘+’ calipers must be placed on the inner borders of the nuchal space, ensuring the amnion is seen separately.

 

Screening Efficiency:

 

  • NT Alone: Provides a 65% detection rate for Down syndrome.
  • Combined Test: When combined with the Dual Marker test (beta hCG and PAPP-A), the detection rate for Down syndrome improves to 80%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 6-8 weeks: This is too early for accurate NT measurement.

 

Option C. 14-16 weeks: This is beyond the optimal time frame for NT evaluation, reducing the effectiveness of the screening.

 

Option D. 16-20 weeks: This period is too late for NT measurement, which should be performed in the first trimester.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ideal time for nuchal translucency evaluation is between 11-14 weeks of gestation.

 

 

Ref: Page no 860, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: It can cause increased sensitivity to sunlight
Female patients should avoid getting pregnant for 3 years after therapy
Acitretin has a half-life of about 50 hours

questions.text: A dermatologist wants to prescribe acitretin to a patient with psoriasis. Which of the following statements is false regarding the drug? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Contraindicated in persons with hyperlipidemia

 

The false statement regarding acitretin is that it is contra-indicated in persons with hyperlipidemia.

 

Although, acitretin can result in increase in serum LDL-cholesterol and triglycerides and decrease in HDL-cholesterol, this adverse effect is more likely in patients with disturbances of lipid metabolism, diabetes mellitus, obesity, increased alcohol intake, or a familial history of these conditions. Therefore, serum lipids must be more closely monitored in high-risk patients and during long-term treatment. Dietary modifications, reduction in dose, or drug therapy should be employed to control significant elevations of triglycerides. If, despite these measures, hypertriglyceridemia and low HDL levels persist, the discontinuation of acitretin should be considered. So, acitretin is not contra-indicated in these patients, but should be used cautiously.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acitretin can cause increased sensitivity to sunlight, and patients should be advised to use sun protection and avoid excessive sun exposure during therapy.

 

Option C. Female patients should avoid getting pregnant for 3 years after therapy: Female patients of childbearing age should avoid getting pregnant after therapy because acitretin is teratogenic and can cause fetal malformations. Effective contraception should be used during treatment and for at least 3 years after therapy.

 

Option D. Acitretin has a half-life of about 50 hours, which means it can take several weeks for the drug to be eliminated from the body after discontinuing therapy. This long half-life also means that accumulation of the drug can occur with repeated dosing, increasing the risk of toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acitretin is not contraindicated in persons with hyperlipidemia, although lipid levels should be monitored during therapy. The drug increases sensitivity to sunlight, requires women to avoid pregnancy for 3 years after therapy due to its teratogenicity, and has a long half-life of about 50 hours.

choices.text: Acute motor axonal neuropathy
Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy
Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy
Miller Fisher syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of Guillain-Barre syndrome? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy

 

Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) is the most common form of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) in the United States and Europe. It presents with rapidly ascending motor weakness and, at times, sensory disturbances in the form of paresthesia. The pathological hallmark of AIDP is the demyelination of peripheral nerves, leading to slow nerve conduction velocities as detected on electromyography.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN): While AMAN is more common in certain regions like East Asia, it is less prevalent than AIDP in most parts of the world. AMAN is characterized by the involvement of motor fibers without significant demyelination.

 

Option C. Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy (AMSAN): Similar to AMAN but involves both motor and sensory fibers. It is generally more severe but less common than AIDP.

 

Option D. Miller Fisher syndrome: A rare variant of GBS that is characterized by ataxia, areflexia, and ophthalmoplegia. It is considered a variant of GBS associated with anti-GQ1b antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

AIDP is the most common type of GBS presenting with ascending motor weakness with occasional distal sensory paresthesia due to demyelination of posterior column.

 

Axonal variants:

 

  • AMAN (Acute motor axonal neuropathy): GM1a, GD1a    
  • AMSAN (Acute motor & sensory axonal neuropathy): GM1a, GD1a         

 

Other variants

 

  • Acute motor conduction block neuropathy: GM1a, GD1a
  • Pharyngo-cervico-branchial variant: GT1a
  • Miller-Fischer variant: GQ1b >> GT1a
  • Acute ataxic neuropathy: GQ1b >> GT1a
  • Pure sensory ataxic variant: GD1b
  • Bickerstaff brainstem encephalitis (BBE): GQ1 >> GT1a

 

Reference - Adam and Viktor/Peripheral neuropathy/GBS page 1322

questions.text: Which of the following elicits maximum pain on injection? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Propofol

 

  • Propofol is notorious for causing pain upon injection.
  • The pain can be severe and is often described as a burning sensation.
  • Various techniques and adjuncts, like mixing with lidocaine or injecting into larger veins, have been recommended to minimize the pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ketamine: While ketamine can sometimes cause a burning sensation upon injection, it's not typically described as the most painful among anesthetic agents. However, when not combined with other medications, it can cause some discomfort upon injection.

 

Option C. Etomidate: Etomidate can cause pain on injection, but the pain is generally less severe compared to propofol.

 

Option D. Thiopentone: Thiopentone can cause some pain upon injection, but it's generally less painful than propofol. However, it can cause tissue necrosis if it is inadvertently injected outside of the vein (extravasation).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propofol is known to cause maximum pain on injection, often described as a severe burning sensation.

questions.text: What is shown in the given image? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sebaceous cyst

 

The image provided shows a sebaceous cyst, with the characteristic black punctum.

 

  • Sebaceous cysts are common benign lumps that form under the skin due to blockade of sebaceous glands, causing a buildup of oil and skin cells.
  • The most common locations for sebaceous cysts are the face, neck, chest, and back especially postauricular sulcus or below and behind the ear lobule.
  • They typically appear as small, painless lumps that are round or oval in shape.
  • Treatment for sebaceous cysts involves surgical removal of the cyst. This is usually done under local anesthesia, and involves making a small elliptical incision in the skin and removing the cyst and its contents.
  • It is important to excise the cyst in its entirety as failure to do so usually results in recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermoid Cyst:

 

  • A dermoid cyst is a benign, slow-growing cystic lesion that can occur in various parts of the body, including the head and neck.
  • These cysts are often present from birth (congenital) and can contain a variety of tissues, including hair, teeth, and sometimes sebaceous (oil-producing) material.
  • Dermoid cysts are typically painless unless they become infected or inflamed.
  • Treatment involves surgical removal to prevent complications or for cosmetic reasons.

 

Option C. Meningioma:

 

  • A meningioma is a typically benign tumor that originates from the meninges, the membranes that cover the brain and spinal cord.
  • Meningiomas are slow-growing and may not cause symptoms initially.
  • When symptoms occur, they can include headaches, seizures, changes in vision or hearing, and neurological deficits.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed through imaging studies like MRI and CT scans, and treatment may involve surgery or radiation therapy depending on the tumor's location and size.

 

Option D. Postauricular Fistula:

 

  • A postauricular fistula, also known as a auricular sinus or pit, is a small hole or pit located in front of or behind the ear.
  • It is a congenital condition, meaning it is present from birth.
  • These pits can sometimes become infected, leading to symptoms like pain, swelling, and discharge.
  • Surgical removal may be considered if there are recurrent infections or other complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sebaceous cysts are common benign lumps that form under the skin due to blockade of sebaceous glands, causing a buildup of oil and skin cells.

questions.text: Which of the following ions is involved in peripheral oxygen sensing chemoreceptors?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Potassium

 

Explanation

 

Potassium is involved in peripheral oxygen sensing chemoreceptors.

 

Chemoreceptors are made up of two types of cells, type I or glomus cells and type II or sustentacular cells. Glomus cells have afferent nerve endings, which are stimulated by hypoxia. Type II cells are glial cells and provide support for type I cells.

 

Type I glomus cells (carotid and aortic body) have O2-sensitive K+ channels. Conductance of these channels is reduced proportionally to the degree of hypoxia resulting in K+ efflux → depolarization of cell and causes Ca+ influx →Excitation of afferent nerve ending.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcium: Calcium is also involved but primarily in response to the depolarization initiated by changes in potassium ion conductance. It is not the initial ion involved in oxygen sensing.

 

Option C. Sodium: Sodium ions are not directly involved in the oxygen-sensing mechanism of peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Option D. Chlorine: Chlorine ions are not involved in the oxygen-sensing functions of peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Potassium ions are crucial for the function of peripheral oxygen-sensing chemoreceptors, where they regulate the membrane potential and responsiveness of the cells to hypoxia. This process is vital for the body's ability to detect and respond to low oxygen levels, ensuring adequate oxygenation and cellular function.

choices.text: Components of MELD (Model for end stage liver disease) scoring system are creatinine, bilirubin, INR, serum sodium (mEq/L).
Components of CTP (Child Turcotte Pugh) score are albumin, bilirubin, INR, ascites, encephalopathy.
Components of CTP (Child Turcotte Pugh) are creatinine, bilirubin, and INR.
MELD score is used to assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation.

questions.text: Which among the following is false? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Components of CTP (Child Turcotte Pugh) are creatinine, bilirubin, and INR

 

Statement C is false. The Child Turcotte Pugh (CTP) score does not include creatinine as a component. Instead, CTP uses the following parameters to assess the severity of liver disease: bilirubin, albumin, INR, ascites, and encephalopathy. This score is traditionally used to evaluate the prognosis in chronic liver disease, primarily cirrhosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Components of MELD scoring system are creatinine, bilirubin, INR, serum sodium (mEq/L): This statement is true. The MELD score has been updated to include serum sodium along with creatinine, bilirubin, and INR to improve its accuracy in predicting mortality risk in liver transplant candidates.

 

Option B. Components of CTP score are albumin, bilirubin, INR, ascites, encephalopathy: This is accurate and reflects the correct components of the CTP score.

 

Option D. MELD score is used to assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation: This is true. The MELD score is widely used to prioritize patients for liver transplantation based on their risk of death from liver disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MELD-Na components mnemonic “CBI”

 

C - Creatinine

B - Bilirubin

I - INR + Sodium

 

CTP score mnemonic BANANa

 

  • Bilirubin Albumin INR Ascites eNcephalopathy

 

Reference - Harrison/Cirrhosis/Chap 344

choices.text: Opening of calcium channels

questions.text: According to myogenic hypothesis of renal autoregulation, the afferent arterioles contract in response to stretch-induced by? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Opening of calcium channels

 

Explanation

 

Renal autoregulation is important to maintain the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Blood flow to kidneys remains normal even when the mean arterial blood pressure varies widely between 60 mm Hg and 180 mm Hg. This helps to maintain normal GFR.

 

Two mechanisms are involved in renal autoregulation:

 

  1. Myogenic response
  2. Tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF)

 

1. MYOGENIC RESPONSE

 

Whenever, the blood flow to kidneys increases,  →  stretches the elastic wall of the afferent arteriole →  Stretching of the vessel wall increases the flow of calcium ions from extracellular fluid into the cells →  The influx of calcium ions leads to the contraction of smooth muscles in afferent arteriole, which causes constriction of afferent arteriole →  So, the blood flow is decreased.

 

 

2. TGF

 

The macula densa, a plaque of specialized tubular epithelial cells located in the distal tubule, monitors the NaCl concentration of the tubular fluid and sends an as of yet unidentified signal to control glomerular hemodynamics. In this mechanism, called tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF), an increase in NaCl concentration at the macula densa constricts the glomerular afferent arteriole and thus decreases the single-nephron GFR. Along with the myogenic response, TGF significantly contributes to renal autoregulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NO: Incorrect, as nitric oxide generally causes vasodilation, not the contraction associated with the myogenic response.

 

Option B. Noradrenaline: Incorrect, although noradrenaline can affect blood vessel tone, it is not directly involved in the myogenic response mechanism of renal autoregulation.

 

Option D. Adenosine: Incorrect, adenosine is more involved in tubuloglomerular feedback rather than the myogenic mechanism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In renal autoregulation, the myogenic hypothesis states that the afferent arterioles contract in response to increased blood pressure, which stretches the arteriole walls. This contraction is mediated by the opening of calcium channels, leading to an influx of calcium ions and subsequent constriction of the arteriole, thereby helping to stabilize GFR across varying blood pressures.

choices.text: Both (a) and (b)

questions.text: In which trimester does acute fatty liver manifest most commonly during pregnancy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Third trimester

 

Explanation:

 

Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) is a life-threatening medical disorder that primarily affects the liver during pregnancy. It most commonly manifests in the late second and third trimesters. AFLP is characterized by the accumulation of microvesicular fat within hepatocytes, leading to liver dysfunction. The diagnosis of AFLP is made using the Swansea criteria, which require six or more of the following clinical features for diagnosis:

 

  • Vomiting
  • Abdominal pain
  • Polydipsia, polyuria
  • Encephalopathy
  • Coagulopathy (raised PT, aPTT)
  • Increased bilirubin
  • Increased uric acid levels
  • Increased creatinine
  • Leukocytosis
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Raised liver enzymes
  • Raised serum ammonia levels
  • Ascites or bright liver on ultrasound
  • Microvascular steatosis on liver biopsy

 

Risk Factors:

 

  • Maternal obesity
  • Male fetus
  • Primigravida
  • Multiple pregnancy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. First trimester: AFLP is very rare in the first trimester, as it typically manifests later in pregnancy.

 

Option B. Second trimester: While AFLP can begin in the late second trimester, it is more commonly seen in the third trimester.

 

Option D. Both (a) and (b): AFLP does not commonly manifest in the first trimester and is primarily a condition of the late second and third trimesters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute fatty liver of pregnancy most commonly manifests in the third trimester and is diagnosed using the Swansea criteria, requiring six or more specific clinical features.

 

Ref: Page no 2684, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient comes with complaints of progressive weakness as the day progresses. He is found to have antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. Which is the most common ocular finding in this disease? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Ptosis

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of a diagnosis of Myasthenia gravis.

 

  • Myasthenia gravis (MG) is a neuromuscular disorder that affects the cranial muscles, including the lids and extraocular muscles (EOMs).
  • Ptosis and diplopia are common initial complaints in MG.
  • Ptosis is the most common ocular feature in MG.
  • The cranial muscles are typically involved early in the course of MG.
  • If weakness remains restricted to the EOMs for 3 years, it is likely that it will not become generalized.
  • Patients who only experience weakness in the EOMs for 3 years are said to have ocular MG.

 

Tensilon test:

 

In Myasthenia, there is improvement of ptosis with IV inj. of Edrophonium (Tensilon).

 

 

Lagophthalmos and Exophthalmos are signs of Thyroid Eye Disease.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Diplopia: Common in MG but less frequent than ptosis.

 

Option B. Lagophthalmos: Inability to close the eyelids completely, typically associated with thyroid eye disease or facial nerve palsy, not common in MG.

 

Option C. Exophthalmos: Protrusion of the eyeball, commonly seen in thyroid eye disease, not MG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid) is the most common ocular finding in Myasthenia Gravis, a neuromuscular disorder characterized by antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.

questions.text: Identify the type of knot seen in the image given below:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Reef knot

 

The image shows a reef knot, also called as square knot:

  • It is the most Basic Surgical Knot
  • Two Throws in “Opposite Directions”

 

Other Surgical knots

 

Granny Knot

  • Two Throws in the Same Direction
  • Not as Strong as Square Knot – Can Slip

 

 

 

 

Option C: Surgeon’s Knot

  • Initial Throw is Pulled Through Twice
  • Second Throw in Opposite Direction
  • More Stable than a Square Knot

 

 

Option A: Surgical Slip Knot (Double Half-Hitch)

  • Keeping Tension on One End the Initial Knot is Thrown Twice in the Same Direction and then Pulled Tight
    • Essentially a “Purposeful” Granny Knot
  • Following Throws in Opposite Directions to Lock
  • Allows Initial Tightening of the Knot to Ensure Tightness

 

Other Options :

 

 

 

Educational Objective: The reef knot has

 

  • Two Throws in “Opposite Directions”

questions.text: Which vaccine among the options is not recommended for use during pregnancy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Varicella

 

The Varicella vaccine is contraindicated in pregnant women because it is a live attenuated vaccine. Live vaccines contain weakened forms of the virus, which can potentially cross the placenta and infect the fetus, leading to congenital infection or other complications. The primary concern is that the live virus, although weakened, may still pose a risk to the developing fetus.

 

Live vaccines are generally avoided during pregnancy to minimize any potential risks to the fetus. Pregnant women are advised to receive inactivated vaccines, which do not contain live pathogens and are considered safer for both the mother and the unborn child.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis A:  The Hepatitis A vaccine is an inactivated (killed) vaccine. It is generally considered safe during pregnancy and can be administered if the benefits outweigh the risks, especially if the woman is at high risk for Hepatitis A infection.

 

Option B. Hepatitis B:  The Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant vaccine, which does not contain live virus. It is safe to use during pregnancy and is recommended for pregnant women who are at risk of Hepatitis B infection.

 

Option C. Rabies:  The Rabies vaccine is an inactivated vaccine. It is considered safe during pregnancy and should be administered if there is a risk of rabies exposure, as the disease itself is fatal if not treated promptly.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Alpha 1-antitrypsin is the major inhibitor of the enzyme: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Elastase

 

Alpha 1-antitrypsin is the major inhibitor of the enzyme neutrophil elastase.

 

On serum electrophoresis, alpha-1-antitrypsin (-1-AT), also known as alpha 1-protease inhibitor, is a glycoprotein that typically makes up the alpha1-globulin fraction of the plasma proteins.

 

It is typically produced in the liver and found in macrophages, circulating blood, and tissue fluids.

 

The name "Alpha1-protease inhibitor" comes from the fact that alpha1AT's primary role in the body is to inhibit proteases. The proteases, particularly the elastases, come from neutrophils.

 

The anti-elastase activity of alpha1-AT prevents neutrophil elastase from digesting lung parenchyma, despite its ability to do so.

 

In the proteinase inhibitor (Pi) locus on chromosome 14, co-dominantly expressed genes that code for 1-antitrypsin are located. The Pi locus has a wide variety of alleles and is highly polymorphic.

 

Those who have the alpha1-AT deficit develop panacinar pulmonary emphysema.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catalase: Not primarily inhibited by A1AT; it is an antioxidant enzyme.

 

Option B. Collagenase: Also not a primary target of A1AT; these enzymes break down collagen in connective tissue.

 

Option D. Phospholipase: Not inhibited by A1AT; involved in the hydrolysis of phospholipids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alpha 1-antitrypsin's critical role is to inhibit neutrophil elastase, thus protecting connective tissue from inflammatory damage, particularly in the lungs and liver.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the structure marked in the image below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Median nerve

 

The marked structure is second lumbrical which is supplied by the median nerve.

 

The lateral two lumbricals are supplied by the median nerve and the medial two are supplied by the ulnar nerve. Function of these muscles is flexion at the metacarpophalangeal joints and extension at both the interphalangeal joints.

 

Median Nerve supplies the following intrinsic muscle of hand-

 

  • Thenar Muscles: Abductor pollicis brevis, flexor pollicis brevis, and opponens pollicis. (Note: The adductor pollicis is innervated by the ulnar nerve.)
  • Lumbricals: The median nerve innervates the first and second lumbricals, which flex the metacarpophalangeal joints of the index and middle fingers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior Interosseous Nerve (PIN): 

  • This nerve doesn't directly supply any of the intrinsic muscles of the hand. It's mainly responsible for innervating the extensor muscles of the forearm.

 

Option C. Anterior Interosseous Nerve (AIN): 

  • The AIN is a branch of the median nerve but doesn't directly supply the intrinsic muscles of the hand. Instead, it supplies deep muscles in the forearm, including flexor pollicis longus and the radial half of flexor digitorum profundus.

 

Option D. Ulnar Nerve: This nerve supply the following intrinsic muscle of hand

 

  • Hypothenar Muscles: Abductor digiti minimi, flexor digiti minimi brevis, and opponens digiti minimi.
  • Interossei: Both the dorsal and palmar interossei are innervated by the ulnar nerve. They are responsible for abduction and adduction of the fingers, respectively.
  • Third and Fourth Lumbricals: These lumbricals flex the metacarpophalangeal joints of the ring and little fingers.
  • Adductor Pollicis: This muscle, as mentioned before, is involved in thumb adduction and is innervated by the ulnar nerve.
  • Other Hand Muscles: Deep head of the flexor pollicis brevis and all the palmaris brevis muscles are also supplied by the ulnar nerve.

 

 

 

MCP = Metacarpophalangeal; IP = Interphalangeal; FDP = Flexor Digitorum Profundus.

questions.text: The most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chorioretinitis

 

  • The most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis is chorioretinitis.
  • Congenital toxoplasmosis is an infection caused by the parasite Toxoplasma gondii that occurs when a pregnant woman becomes infected and passes the infection on to her developing fetus. The severity of the infection can vary depending on the timing of the infection during pregnancy and the degree of immune response mounted by the fetus.
  • It is acquired perorally from ingesting food that contains oocysts; transplacentally, during vaginal delivery; or rarely, parenterally.
  • Chorioretinitis is the most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis, occurring in up to 80% of affected infants. It is a type of eye inflammation that affects the retina and can lead to vision impairment or blindness if left untreated.
  • Other common manifestations of congenital toxoplasmosis include hydrocephalus (accumulation of fluid in the brain), hepatosplenomegaly (enlargement of the liver and spleen), and thrombocytopenia (low platelet count), but these are less common than chorioretinitis.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hydrocephalus: Accumulation of fluid in the brain can occur in congenital toxoplasmosis but is less common than chorioretinitis.

 

Option C. Hepatosplenomegaly: Enlargement of the liver and spleen is another possible manifestation but not as common as chorioretinitis.

 

Option D. Thrombocytopenia: Low platelet count can occur but is less common compared to chorioretinitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chorioretinitis is the most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis, affecting up to 80% of infected infants and potentially leading to vision impairment or blindness.

questions.text: All of the following structures are derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Linea semilunaris

 

Linea semilunaris is derived from the aponeurosis of the internal oblique muscle.

 

The linea semilunaris is a curved tendinous line located on either side of the rectus abdominis muscle, representing the lateral border where the flat abdominal muscles' aponeuroses come together.

 

It is not derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique alone. Instead, it is formed where the aponeurosis of the external oblique, the internal oblique, and the transversus abdominis meet and fuse before they envelop the rectus abdominis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pectineal Ligament: Also known as Cooper's ligament, the pectineal ligament is a fibrous band that runs parallel and posterior to the inguinal ligament, extending from the pubic tubercle to the pectineal line of the pubis. While it is closely related to structures formed by the aponeurosis of the external oblique, it is not directly derived from it.

 

Option B. Inguinal Ligament: The inguinal ligament is directly derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle. It is the inferior edge of the external oblique aponeurosis, stretching between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic tubercle. This ligament acts as a boundary between the anterior abdominal wall and the thigh, and structures like the spermatic cord in males and the round ligament in females pass beneath it to enter the inguinal canal.

 

Option C. Lacunar Ligament: Also called Gimbernat’s ligament, the lacunar ligament is a crescent-shaped fold of the aponeurosis of the external oblique that attaches to the pectineal line of the pubis. It's positioned medial to the inguinal ligament, and its formation is related to the deepening of the inguinal canal during development. It contributes to the posterior margin of the superficial inguinal ring and represents the lateral border of the femoral canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ligaments derived from external oblique aponeurosis are:

questions.text: Gastric lavage can be performed in case of poisoning by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Carbolic acid

 

Gastric lavage can be performed in case of carbolic poisoning. It is a corrosive acid, but it hardens the Gl mucosa thus anesthetizing its nerve endings and allows for gastric lavage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sulphuric acid: A concentrated inorganic acid that can cause severe corrosion and softening of the stomach wall, making gastric lavage dangerous due to the risk of perforation.

 

Option B. Strychnine: A convulsive poison that increases the risk of aspiration during seizures, making gastric lavage unsafe.

 

Option D. Kerosene oil: A volatile hydrocarbon that poses a significant risk of aspiration pneumonitis if gastric lavage is performed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contraindications to gastric lavage:

 

  1. Corrosive poisons such as concentrated inorganic acids (e.g. sulfuric acid, nitric acid etc.) corrode and soften the stomach wall, making it prone for perforation (exception carbolic acid which hardens the stomach wall and gastric lavage is done safely).
  2. Risk of aspiration: Convulsive poisons, Comatose patients, Volatile poisons (hydrocarbons like kerosene)
  3. Upper gastrointestinal tract diseases: Example oesophageal varices
  4. Hypothermia
  5. Hemorrhagic diathesis

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient is referred to a neurologist with complaints of facial flushing and sweating while eating or even just thinking about food. The patient reports that this has been happening for several months and is becoming increasingly bothersome. Upon further questioning, the patient also reports a history of parotid gland surgery for a benign tumor several years ago. Which nerve is involved in Frey's syndrome? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Auriculotemporal nerve

 

Explanation:

 

Frey's syndrome is a rare condition that occurs as a complication of parotid gland surgery or other trauma to the area. It is characterized by facial flushing and sweating in the region of the face associated with the parotid gland, particularly when eating or thinking about food. The underlying cause of Frey's syndrome is damage to the auriculotemporal nerve (a branch of the mandibular nerve, V3). This damage results in abnormal nerve regeneration and cross-connection between the parasympathetic fibers that stimulate salivation and the sympathetic fibers that control sweating.

 

  • Mechanism: The auriculotemporal nerve contains both sensory fibers and parasympathetic secretomotor fibers that supply the parotid gland. Following injury or surgery, these fibers can aberrantly regenerate, causing parasympathetic fibers to innervate sweat glands of the overlying skin, leading to sweating and flushing upon salivation.

 

Treatment Options:

 

  • Topical Antiperspirants: These can help reduce sweating by blocking sweat glands.
  • Oral Medications: Medications that reduce sweating may be prescribed.
  • Botulinum Toxin Injections: These injections can block the action of sweat glands, providing relief from symptoms.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Facial Nerve: The facial nerve controls facial expressions and can be injured during parotid surgery, leading to facial palsy. However, it is not involved in Frey's syndrome.

 

Option B. Oculomotor nerve: The oculomotor nerve controls eye movements and pupil constriction and is not involved in the innervation of the parotid gland or the region affected in Frey's syndrome.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal nerve: The glossopharyngeal nerve is involved in taste sensation from the posterior third of the tongue and parasympathetic innervation to the parotid gland. However, it is not directly involved in the facial flushing and sweating characteristic of Frey's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frey's syndrome is caused by damage to the auriculotemporal nerve, leading to abnormal sweating and flushing of the face associated with eating or thinking about food. This condition is a common complication of parotid gland surgery.

questions.text: All of the following are AIDS defining illnesses except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Oral Candidiasis

 

Oral candidiasis, while commonly associated with HIV infection, is not itself an AIDS-defining illness. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) list of AIDS-defining illnesses includes more severe manifestations such as candidiasis of the esophagus, trachea, bronchi, or lungs, but not oral candidiasis. This fungal infection is often seen in patients with HIV as a marker of immune suppression but does not qualify as an indicator of AIDS on its own.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Encephalopathy attributed to HIV: This is an AIDS-defining condition, as it represents a direct effect of HIV on the brain resulting in cognitive impairment and motor dysfunction.

 

Option B. Invasive cervical cancer: This is considered an AIDS-defining illness due to the high risk and prevalence of this cancer in individuals with advanced HIV, reflecting a significant degree of immunosuppression.

 

Option C. Mycobacterium tuberculosis of any site: Tuberculosis, whether pulmonary or extrapulmonary, is an AIDS-defining illness due to its severity and frequency in the context of HIV-induced immune suppression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Infectious Disease/Chap 202

questions.text: Premature ejaculation is a disorder of which phase of the normal sexual cycle? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Orgasm

 

This phase involves the release of sexual tension. Premature ejaculation and anorgasmia are disorders of this phase.

 

Premature ejaculation is a disorder of the orgasm phase of the sexual response cycle. It involves ejaculation that occurs earlier than desired, often with minimal sexual stimulation.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Desire: This phase refers to the interest in engaging in sexual activity. Disorders of this phase might manifest as hypoactive sexual desire disorder or sexual aversion disorder.

 

Option B. Arousal: This phase is characterized by physiological changes such as erection in men and vaginal lubrication in women. Erectile dysfunction is a disorder of this phase in men.

 

Option D. Pain: This isn't a phase of the sexual response cycle. However, dyspareunia refers to pain during intercourse and can be a clinical condition.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Premature ejaculation is a disorder of the orgasm phase of the sexual response cycle. It is characterized by a pattern of persistent or recurrent ejaculation with minimal sexual stimulation before or immediately after the vaginal penetration.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 579.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a feature in cerebral palsy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Flaccid paralysis

 

Flaccid paralysis is not a feature of cerebral palsy (CP). It is a feature of lower motor neuron disease.

 

Cerebral palsy is characterized by abnormalities in muscle tone and movement, including -

 

  • Hypertonia (increased muscle tone),
  • Hypotonia (decreased muscle tone),
  • Ataxia (lack of muscle coordination) is also commonly observed in individuals with cerebral palsy.
  • A deficit in the motor, language, and social milestones
  • Microcephaly is a feature of cerebral palsy because of the insult to the developing brain.
  • It is an upper motor neuron disease characterized by rigidity and scissoring gait.
  • Spastic CP is the commonest type (65%)

 

Seen in conditions such as Guillain-Barré syndrome, transverse myelitis, poliomyelitis, and traumatic neuritis, but not typically in cerebral palsy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypotonia: Can be present in cerebral palsy, characterized by low muscle tone.

 

Option B. Microcephaly: Often associated with cerebral palsy due to brain injury or developmental issues.

 

Option C. Ataxia: Characterized by poor balance and coordination, is a common feature of certain types of cerebral palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flaccid paralysis is not a feature of cerebral palsy; it is indicative of lower motor neuron disease. Cerebral palsy is characterized by various forms of muscle tone abnormalities and movement disorders.

choices.text: Hartmann's operation is done in elderly debilitated patients
Adenocarcinoma is a rare variant of rectal carcinoma
Early morning spurious diarrhea and tenesmus can occur
Growth confined to the rectal mucosa is stage A of modified Duke's staging

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding rectal carcinoma? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Adenocarcinoma is a rare variant of rectal carcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

Adenocarcinoma is the most common variant of rectal carcinoma, accounting for over 95% of cases. This type of cancer originates from the glandular cells lining the rectum. Therefore, stating that adenocarcinoma is a rare variant is incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hartmann's operation is done in elderly debilitated patients: This statement is true. Hartmann's operation is a surgical procedure often performed in elderly or debilitated patients with rectal carcinoma. The operation involves resection of the diseased segment of the colon, closure of the remaining rectal stump (forming a "Hartmann's pouch"), and creation of an end colostomy with the proximal colon. It is a suitable option for patients who may not tolerate a more extensive surgical procedure.

 

Option C. Early morning spurious diarrhea and tenesmus can occur: This statement is true. Patients with rectal carcinoma commonly experience symptoms such as diarrhea and tenesmus (a sensation of incomplete evacuation after bowel movements). These symptoms can occur at any time of the day, including early morning, due to the irritation and obstruction caused by the tumor.

 

Option D. Growth confined to the rectal mucosa is stage A of modified Duke's staging: This statement is true. According to the modified Duke's staging system for colorectal cancer, stage A refers to cancer that is confined to the mucosa of the rectum. This early stage indicates that the tumor has not yet penetrated deeper layers or spread beyond the rectum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of rectal carcinoma, accounting for over 95% of cases, making it incorrect to describe it as a rare variant.

questions.text: NADPH is used in? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fatty acid synthesis

 

NADPH is essential for fatty acid synthesis. During this process, NADPH provides reducing equivalents necessary for the conversion of acetyl-CoA into long-chain fatty acids. This reduction step is crucial for building the carbon chains that make up fatty acids, and NADPH acts as a reducing agent in this pathway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ketone Synthesis: NADPH is not directly involved in ketone synthesis. Ketones are typically synthesized from fatty acids during a state of prolonged fasting or low carbohydrate intake.

 

Option C. Gluconeogenesis: NADPH plays a role in gluconeogenesis, which is the synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors. NADPH is required for certain enzymatic reactions in this pathway, such as the reduction of oxaloacetate to malate.

 

Option D. Glycolysis: NADPH is not directly involved in glycolysis. Glycolysis primarily uses NAD+ (Nicotinamide Adenine Dinucleotide) rather than NADPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NADPH generating reactions

 

  1. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase in the hexose monophosphate shunt pathway (Glucose-6-phosphate → 6-phospho-glucono lactone)
  2. 6-phospho gluconate dehydrogenase in the shunt pathway (6-phospho gluconate → 3-keto-6-phospho gluconate)
  3. Cytoplasmic isocitrate dehydrogenase
  4. Malic enzyme (malate to pyruvate).

 

NADPH utilizing reactions

 

  1. Ketoacyl-ACP dehydrogenase (Beta-ketoacyl-ACP → beta hydroxy acyl ACP) (De novo synthesis of fatty acid - Step 4)
  2. Alpha, beta unsaturated acyl ACP → Acyl ACP (De novo synthesis of fatty acid - Step 6)
  3. HMG CoA reductase (HMG CoA → mevalonate (Cholesterol synthesis)
  4. Met-hemoglobin → Hemoglobin
  5. Folate reductase (Folate → dihydrofolate → tetrahydrofolate)
  6. Phenyl alanine hydroxylase (Phenylalanine → tyrosine)

choices.text: Volume expired after normal inspiration
Volume that remains after forced expiration
Expiratory reserve volume + residual volume
Tidal volume + inspiratory reserve volume

questions.text: Which of the following represents functional residual capacity? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Expiratory reserve volume + residual volume

 

Explanation

 

The functional residual capacity equals the expiratory reserve volume(1000-1100ml) + residual volume(1100-1200ml). This is the amount of air that remains in the lungs at the end of normal expiration (about 2300 milliliters).

 

Vital capacity - Total volume of air that can be expired after normal inspiration

 

            = Tidal volume + inspiratory reserve volume

 

Expiratory capacity – tidal volume + ERV

 

Residual volume (1100-1200) - Volume that remains after forced expiration

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Volume expired after normal inspiration: Incorrect as this description fits more closely with tidal volume, which is the normal volume of air displaced between normal inhalation and exhalation when extra effort is not applied.

 

Option B. Volume that remains after forced expiration: Incorrect as this specifically defines residual volume (RV), not the combination of ERV and RV.

 

Option D. Tidal volume + inspiratory reserve volume: Incorrect, this combination describes the vital capacity, which is the total volume of air that can be exhaled after a maximal inhalation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is the sum of the Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) and the Residual Volume (RV). It represents the volume of air remaining in the lungs at the end of a normal exhalation, ensuring continuous gas exchange between breaths.

questions.text: What is the fear of heights known as?(NEET PG  2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acrophobia

 

This is the fear of heights.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acarophobia: This is the fear of itching or of the insects that cause itching.

 

Option B. Algophobia: This is the fear of pain.

 

Option C. Agoraphobia: This is the fear of open spaces or of being in crowded, public places like markets, or the fear of leaving a safe place, often associated with panic attacks.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acrophobia refers to the fear of heights.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 403.

choices.text: Descending paralysis is seen
Plasmapheresis is a treatment method

questions.text: All are true about Typical Guillain-Barre syndrome except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Descending paralysis is seen

 

Guillain-Barre Syndrome (GBS) is typically characterized by ascending paralysis, starting from the lower extremities and moving upward, not descending paralysis. This pattern begins with weakness in the legs that spreads to the upper limbs and the face, associated with the demyelination of peripheral nerves. The condition is indeed inflammatory and primarily affects the peripheral nervous system, leading to demyelination and sometimes axonal damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inflammatory condition: True, GBS is an acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy.

 

Option C. Plasmapheresis is a treatment method: True, plasmapheresis is used to remove antibodies from the blood that are thought to be involved in the immune attack on the peripheral nerves.

 

Option D. Demyelinating disorder: True, GBS involves the demyelination of peripheral nerves, leading to muscle weakness and paralysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GBS produces neuro-radiculopathy due to demyelination causing ascending paralysis.

 

Causes of Descending paralysis (Mnemonic: Bipolar disorder [BPD]):

 

B: Botulism

P: Porphyria, Polio

D: Diphtheria

questions.text: Which of the following has a poor prognosis with exposure and response prevention in OCD? ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hoarding

 

Among the OCD subtypes, hoarding has shown to be more resistant to treatment with ERP. This might be because individuals with hoarding disorder often do not recognize their behavior as problematic and may lack insight into the disorder.

 

Exposure and response prevention (ERP) is a type of cognitive-behavioral therapy that is effective for many individuals with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). However, certain subtypes or themes of OCD might respond less effectively to ERP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pathological doubt: While challenging, ERP can be tailored to address pathological doubt by creating exposures that trigger doubt without seeking reassurance.

 

Option B. Magical thinking: ERP can also be adapted for magical thinking by exposing the individual to the feared situation or thought without engaging in the ritualistic behavior.

 

Option D. Contamination obsession: Contamination fears are typically one of the subtypes that respond quite well to ERP, as the therapist can create direct exposures involving the feared contaminant.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hoarding disorder is characterised by acquiring and not being able to discard things that are considered to have little or no use. This will lead to cluttering of house, to an extent that it becomes unsafe to live. This disorder is driven by fear of losing something important. Treatment includes SSRIs and CBT.  Hoarding disorder tends to have a poorer prognosis with exposure and response prevention compared to other subtypes.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 431.

questions.text: Which among the following options describes the chest X-ray image? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coeur en sabot

 

Chest X-ray image describes "Coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart, which is seen in tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

 

 

  • "Coeur en sabot" is due to cardiac apex elevation as a result of right ventricular hypertrophy. The cardiac silhouette has been likened to that of a boot ("Coeur-en sabot").
  • The hilar areas and lung fields are relatively clear because of diminished pulmonary blood flow or the small size of the pulmonary arteries.
  • The aorta is usually large.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Egg on side appearance: Egg on string appearance is seen in transposition of great arteries (TGA)

 

Option C. Egg on string appearance: Scimitar sign is seen in Scimitar syndrome which is also known as partial anomalous pulmonary venous return.

 

Option D. Snowman sign: Snowman sign is seen in supracardiac TAPVC

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart on a chest X-ray is characteristic of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), which results from right ventricular hypertrophy, leading to the distinctive cardiac silhouette.

questions.text: BCYE medium is used to culture? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Legionella

 

BCYE medium (buffered charcoal yeast extract agar) is used to culture Legionella pneumophila. Legionella pneumophila has fastidious growth requirements and grows on complex media such as BCYE medium with L-cysteine and antibiotic supplements (e.g, polymyxin B, cefazolin, vancomycin). The charcoal acts as a detoxifying agent. It grows slowly, and the colonies may take 3-6 days to appear.

 

Other Options

 

Option A: Leptospira is cultured on EMJH (Ellinghausen, McCullough, Johnson and Harris) medium

 

Option B: Bacillus cereus is cultured on PEMBA (Polymyxin pyruvate egg-yolk mannitol-bromothymol blue) agar, which includes Polymyxin, pyruvate, egg yolk, mannitol, and bromothymol blue to differentiate it from other organisms.

 

Option C: Campylobacter is cultured on selective media such as Skirrow's, Campy BAP or Butzler's agar.

 

Educational Objective

 

BCYE medium is essential for the successful isolation and culture of Legionella species, particularly Legionella pneumophila, from environmental and clinical specimens. This medium meets the specific nutritional requirements and provides a protective environment for the growth of this pathogen.

choices.text: Failure of migration of desquamated epithelium along posterior metal wall
Widening of meatus and facial nerve palsy might be seen

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true about keratosis obturans? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

All of the above statements are true regarding keratosis obturans.

 

  • Collection of a pearly white mass of desquamated epithelial cells in the deep meatus is called keratosis obturans. This, by its pressure effect, causes absorption of bone leading to widening of the meatus so much so that facial nerves may be exposed and paralyzed.
  • Presenting symptoms may be pain in the ear, hearing loss, tinnitus and sometimes ear discharge. It may sometimes be associated with bronchiectasis and chronic sinusitis.
  • On examination, the ear canal may be full of pearly white mass of keratin material disposed in several layers. Removal of this mass may show widening of bony meatus with ulceration and even granuloma formation.

 

 

Treatment

 

Keratotic mass is removed either by syringing or instrumentation, similar to the techniques employed for impacted wax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keratosis obturans is characterized by the accumulation of epithelial cells in the ear canal, leading to potential structural damage and associated symptoms. Its management requires careful removal of the buildup and monitoring for complications such as facial nerve palsy. Awareness of its association with bronchiectasis and sinusitis is crucial for comprehensive patient care.

questions.text: In a patient with lipoprotein lipase deficiency, which of the following is increased following a fatty meal? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chylomicron

 

Chylomicron levels are increased following a fatty meal in individuals with lipoprotein lipase deficiency. Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is responsible for breaking down triglycerides in chylomicrons. In its absence, chylomicrons accumulate in the bloodstream, leading to elevated chylomicron levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. LDL: LDL (Low-Density Lipoprotein) levels may be elevated as well in individuals with lipoprotein lipase deficiency, but this increase is primarily associated with genetic factors and not directly related to a fatty meal.

 

Option C. HDL: HDL (High-Density Lipoprotein) levels are typically not significantly affected by lipoprotein lipase deficiency.

 

Option D. Apo A: Apolipoprotein A (Apo A) is a component of HDL and is not directly increased following a fatty meal in individuals with lipoprotein lipase deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frederickson’s classification of hyperlipoproteinemia

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with a history of repeated sinopulmonary infections caused by encapsulated organisms. Which of the following is most likely to be deficient in this case? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgG2

 

IgG2 deficiency is the most likely culprit in cases where a child suffers from recurrent sinopulmonary infections specifically caused by encapsulated bacteria. IgG2 plays a critical role in the immune system's ability to fight off encapsulated organisms such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Neisseria meningitidis. These organisms are particularly adept at evading non-specific immune responses due to their polysaccharide capsules, making specific antibody-mediated immunity crucial.

 

Transplacental Transport of IgG: IgG is unique among the immunoglobulins as it is transported from mother to fetus across the placenta, providing passive immunity to the newborn. IgG1 is transported most efficiently across the placenta, providing early defense against infection in neonates. IgG2, despite being critical for defense against encapsulated bacteria, has less transplacental movement, which can influence the susceptibility to infections in early infancy before the infant's own immune system fully matures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgG1: Predominantly responsible for protecting against bacterial infections, including pathogens like diphtheria and tetanus.

 

Option C. IgG3: Often associated with a stronger response to viral infections.

 

Option D. IgG4: Less common and typically related to responses against parasitic infections, though IgG4-related disease can also manifest as fibroinflammatory conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In children presenting with recurrent infections caused by encapsulated bacteria, IgG2 deficiency should be considered as a possible underlying cause. Early identification and management of specific immunoglobulin deficiencies are crucial to prevent recurrent infections and their complications in young children.

questions.text: IL-1 is activated by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Caspase – 1

 

Caspase- 1 activates the biologically active form of IL-1.

 

Pyroptosis is a type of controlled cell death distinct from apoptosis and necrosis that is mediated by IL-1. It takes part in the removal of microbially and necrotically affected cells.

 

Caspase-1 and the inflammasome complex are both activated.

 

  • IL-1 production causes fever, inflammation, and leukocyte recruitment.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Options B. Caspase - 3, C. Caspase - 9 and  D. Caspase – 8: These caspases are primarily involved in the apoptosis pathway, not in the activation of IL-1. Caspase-3 and caspase-9 are part of the apoptotic cascade that leads to programmed cell death without inflammation. Caspase-8 is involved in extrinsic apoptosis signaling and can overlap with inflammatory pathways but does not directly activate IL-1.

 

Educational objective:

 

Caspase-1 is critical for the activation of IL-1, directly linking it to the inflammatory response and distinguishing it from other caspases primarily involved in apoptotic pathways. This mechanism underscores the specific role of the inflammasome and pyroptosis in immune defense and inflammatory regulation.

questions.text: Cowdry Type A inclusions are seen in? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes simplex

 

Cowdry type A inclusions are seen in the vesicles of Herpes Simplex infection

 

The classic Cowdry type A inclusion appears as a light purple, homogeneous intranuclear structure surrounded by a clear halo. The inclusions stain with antibodies to HS, permitting a rapid, specific diagnosis of HSV infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rabies: Incorrect, as Rabies is associated with Negri bodies, which are specific cytoplasmic inclusions.

 

Option C. Molluscum contagiosum: Incorrect, as this condition is linked to Henderson-Peterson bodies, which are intracytoplasmic inclusions.

 

Option D. Adenovirus: Incorrect for Cowdry Type A inclusions; however, Cowdry type C basophilic inclusions are seen in Adenovirus infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inclusion bodies produced in viral infection:

questions.text: Cilastatin is administered to prolong the action of which of the following drugs? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Imipenem

 

Imipenem is a carbapenem that is broken down by the enzyme dehydropeptidase in the kidney. Cilastatin is therefore administered along with it, which is an inhibitor of dehydropeptidase, thereby it prolongs the action of Imipenem.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meropenem: Meropenem is another carbapenem antibiotic, but it is not significantly degraded by renal dehydropeptidase I and does not require co-administration with cilastatin.

 

Option C. Cefazolin: Cefazolin is a first-generation cephalosporin antibiotic that is not affected by renal dehydropeptidase I and does not require cilastatin for its administration.

 

Option D. Piperacillin: Piperacillin is a broad-spectrum penicillin antibiotic, and its activity is not influenced by renal dehydropeptidase I, thus not requiring cilastatin for its administration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cilastatin is specifically administered with imipenem to inhibit renal dehydropeptidase I, preventing the breakdown of imipenem and thereby prolonging its action in the body.

questions.text: The first organ to undergo Rigor mortis amongst the following options is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Myocardium

 

  • Nysten’s law deals with the progression of rigor mortis
  • It first affects the involuntary muscles starting with the myocardium
  • The order of appearance in voluntary muscles is:
    • Upper eyelids
    • Neck muscles,
    • Jaw
    • Facial muscles
    • Chest
    • Upper limbs
    • Abdomen
    • Lower limbs
    • Finger and toes
  • Order of disappearance is also the same.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to Nysten's law, rigor mortis first affects the myocardium (heart muscle) among the listed options.

 

Rigor mortis follows the “rule of 12”- 12 hrs. to set in, remains for 12 hrs., and passes off in 12 hrs.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿The entire life cycle takes about 15 days
﻿﻿﻿Male parasite burrows into the epidermis

questions.text: A 30-year-old female developed pruritic papules with excoriated plaques in the interdigital web spaces. Later the lesion spread to the groin and under-surface of the breasts. The lady gives a history of intense pruritus which is more severe at night. Given below is the organism responsible for this condition. Identify the wrong statement about the same? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Male parasite burrows into the epidermis

 

This statement is incorrect because it is the female mite, not the male, that burrows into the skin. The male mites mainly stay on the surface of the skin and do not create burrows like the females do.

 

The clinical background is probably suggestive Scabies. The given image depicts Itch mite also called Sarcoptes scabiei. The female parasite burrows into the stratum corneum layer of the epidermis and lays eggs in the burrow.

 

A single female may lay about 30 eggs at a rate of 2 to 3 per day, and ultimately dies at the end of the burrow.

 

The life cycle has 4 stages: Egg, Larva, Nymph, and Adult. The adult mites live for 1 to 2 months. 

 

Itching is a hypersensitivity reaction to the eggs and dead parasite in the epidermis.

 

Permethrin cream - 5% is the treatment of choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Life history has 4 stages: The lifecycle of Sarcoptes scabiei consists of the egg, larva, nymph, and adult stages, correctly described in the statement.

 

Option B. Larvae have 3 pairs of legs: The larvae of the scabies mite indeed have three pairs of legs, distinguishing them from the adult mites.

 

Option C. The entire life cycle takes about 15 days: The lifecycle from egg to mature mite, under ideal conditions, typically spans around 15 days, making this statement accurate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The female Sarcoptes scabiei mite is responsible for burrowing into the skin and laying eggs, which leads to the intense itching and characteristic rash seen in scabies. Recognizing the specific behavior of the female mite in the transmission and lifecycle of scabies is crucial for effective diagnosis and management of the condition.

questions.text: Which of the following is autosomal dominant? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Achondroplasia

 

Achondroplasia is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a mutation of the fibroblast growth factor receptor-3 (FGFR-3) gene.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duchene muscular dystrophy – XLR

 

Option A. Cystic fibrosis & Option C. Sickle cell anemia – Autosomal recessive

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which among the following IV anaesthetic causes least myocardial depression and maximum hemodynamic stability? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Etomidate

 

  • Among the options given, Etomidate is unique in that it causes minimal cardiovascular depression.
  • This makes it particularly useful in patients with compromised cardiac function or hemodynamic instability
  • Etomidate is an imidazoline derivative used for IV anaesthesia induction, and it offers several advantages:
    • Low risk of myocardial depression
    • Hemodynamic stability on bolus injection

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Propofol: Propofol can cause myocardial depression, leading to a decrease in blood pressure. It also produces vasodilation which can further lower blood pressure.

 

Option C. Thiopentone: Thiopentone can cause myocardial depression, leading to a decrease in cardiac output and blood pressure. It also has a vasodilatory effect which can further compromise hemodynamics.

 

Option D. Ketamine: Unlike most other anesthetics, Ketamine typically has a stimulatory effect on the cardiovascular system. It often increases heart rate and blood pressure due to its sympathetic stimulatory effects. However, in patients with depleted catecholamines or in certain pathological conditions, it might not exhibit this stimulatory effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propofol and Thiopentone are known to cause myocardial depression, Etomidate is recognized for its minimal cardiovascular depression, and Ketamine typically stimulates the cardiovascular system, but with certain exceptions.

choices.text: Identified 5th intercostal space anterior to mid axillary line to place the tube
Inserted tube along the lower border of upper rib
Directed tube posteriorly to prevent injury

questions.text: A first year surgery resident, on rotation at a hospital, is tasked with inserting an intercostal drainage tube in a 65-year-old patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) who was admitted with a severe exacerbation of their symptoms. The surgery resident has previously performed the procedure under supervision, but this is their first time doing it on their own. Which of the following steps is incorrect? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Inserted tube along the lower border of upper rib

 

Explanation:

 

An intercostal drainage (ICD) tube should be inserted along the upper border of the lower rib, not the lower border of the upper rib. This is to prevent damage to the neurovascular bundle, which runs along the lower border of each rib (comprising the intercostal vein, artery, and nerve). Inserting the tube along the lower border of the upper rib increases the risk of injuring these critical structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Identified 5th intercostal space anterior to mid axillary line to place the tube: The 5th intercostal space anterior to the mid-axillary line is a commonly selected site for the insertion of an ICD. This location is within the "triangle of safety," which is bounded by the lateral border of the pectoralis major anteriorly, the latissimus dorsi posteriorly, and the horizontal level of the nipple below. This area minimizes the risk of injuring important structures, including the long thoracic nerve and vessels.

 

Option C. Directed tube posteriorly to prevent injury: Directing the tube posteriorly initially helps ensure that it enters the pleural space without injuring the lung. Once inside the pleural cavity, the direction of the tube may be adjusted based on the specific indication for the ICD, such as draining an effusion versus a pneumothorax.

 

Option D. Incised and digitally explored: After making a skin incision, blunt dissection and digital exploration are performed to ensure that there are no obstructions or adhesions and to create a safe pathway for the tube. Digital exploration helps confirm that the tube enters the pleural space properly and safely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When inserting an intercostal drainage tube, it is crucial to place the tube along the upper border of the lower rib to avoid damaging the neurovascular bundle that runs along the lower border of the upper rib.

choices.text: Green labels are for those who need to be transported on priority
Moribund patients receive the lowest priority
Most commonly used system is three color code system

questions.text: During disaster management, triage is conducted to ensure proper treatment of casualties. What are the accurate aspects of the triage process carried out at the site of the disaster? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Moribund patients receive the lowest priority

 

In Triage, these patients are given different color coding as mentioned below –

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In disaster triage, moribund patients receive the lowest priority, allowing medical resources to be focused on patients with a higher chance of survival.

questions.text: Where would you place the pulse oximeter to measure pre-ductal oxygen saturation in an infant who was born 3 minutes ago? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fetal right upper limb

 

To assess preductal oxygen saturation in a newborn, the recommended area to place the pulse oximeter is the right upper limb. The right upper limb is preductal, meaning it receives blood directly from the aorta before it passes through the ductus arteriosus. This positioning is crucial for detecting any discrepancies between preductal and postductal oxygen saturation levels such as in patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

 

If the preductal oxygen saturation is more than 5% higher than the postductal saturation (measured at the foot), it suggests the presence of a right-to-left shunt.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal left upper limb: Although the left upper limb can be used, the right upper limb is preferred for preductal saturation measurement to ensure accuracy in detecting shunts.

 

Option B. Fetal left lower limb: The left lower limb is postductal, making it unsuitable for measuring preductal oxygen saturation.

 

Option D. Fetal right lower limb: The right lower limb is also postductal and not suitable for measuring preductal oxygen saturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To measure preductal oxygen saturation in a newborn, place the pulse oximeter on the right upper limb. This helps in detecting any right-to-left shunt, such as in patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

choices.text: More common in females
Pain along V2 and V3 division of trigeminal nerve
No objective signs of sensory loss

questions.text: All are true about patients with trigeminal neuralgia except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Deep seated pain

 

Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by sudden, severe, electric shock-like or stabbing pain that is typically superficial and localized to the face. It most often affects the V2 (maxillary) and V3 (mandibular) divisions of the trigeminal nerve. The pain associated with trigeminal neuralgia is not deep-seated but rather feels as if it is on the surface of the face, which makes option C incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. More common in females: This is true. Trigeminal neuralgia is generally more common in females than in males.

 

Option B. Pain along V2 and V3 division of the trigeminal nerve: This is also true. While trigeminal neuralgia can affect any of the three branches of the trigeminal nerve, the maxillary (V2) and mandibular (V3) branches are more commonly affected than the ophthalmic (V1) branch.

 

Option D. No objective signs of sensory loss: This is correct. Trigeminal neuralgia typically does not show any objective signs of sensory loss or neurological deficit on examination, which can make diagnosis challenging.

 

Educational Objective:


Trigeminal neuralgia is marked by sharp, superficial pain that may affect the V2 and V3 divisions of the trigeminal nerve. It is important to recognize that the pain is superficial and not deep-seated. This condition more commonly affects females and presents without objective sensory loss.

 

Reference - Harrison/Trigeminal neuralgia

questions.text: A patient is brought to the hospital, with complaints of seizures and the MRI image of the brain is given below. The disease is most probably caused by? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cysticercosis cellulose

 

The given clinical scenario and MRI brain showing scolex within multiple cystic lesions are suggestive of neurocysticercosis caused by the larval form of T. solium called Cysticercosis cellulose.

 

Neurocysticercosis is the most common central nervous system parasitic infection.

 

The clinical features of neurocysticercosis include:

 

  • ﻿﻿Epilepsy
  • ﻿﻿Increased intracranial tension
  • ﻿﻿Hydrocephalus
  • ﻿﻿Psychiatric disturbances
  • ﻿﻿Meningoencephalitis
  • ﻿﻿Transient paresis
  • ﻿﻿Behavioral disorders
  • ﻿﻿Aphasia
  • ﻿﻿Visual disturbances.

 

The CT and MRI findings seen in neurocysticercosis are:

 

  • ﻿﻿Scolex within a cyst
  • ﻿﻿Cystic lesions with or without ring enhancement
  • ﻿﻿Nodular calcifications
  • ﻿﻿Focal enhancing lesions
  • ﻿﻿Multilobulated cystic lesions in the subarachnoid space.

 

Note: About 70% of adult-onset epilepsy is due to neurocysticercosis.

 

Albendazole is the drug of choice for neurocysticercosis. Glucocorticoid therapy is usually begun before initiating albendazole (antiparasitic drug). This is continued for several days after the institution of therapy to reduce the incidence of side effects from inflammatory reactions to dead and dying cysticerci of Taenia solium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. T. saginata: Incorrect. Known as the beef tapeworm, it does not typically lead to cysticercosis as its larvae (Cysticercus bovis) primarily infect cattle.

 

Option C. Cysticercosis bovis: Incorrect. This term is not applicable to human disease and refers to the larval stage of T. saginata found in cattle.

 

Option D. T. asiatica: Incorrect. This is a species of tapeworm similar to T. saginata and is associated with pigs, but like T. saginata, it is not commonly linked to neurocysticercosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neurocysticercosis is identified with imaging studies, particularly in patients presenting with new-onset seizures and specific MRI findings of cystic lesions with scolex, is critical for timely diagnosis and appropriate management, including antiparasitic and supportive therapy.

questions.text: All of the following are features of Crohn's disease except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lead pipe appearance

 

The lead pipe appearance is a radiological term typically associated with ulcerative colitis, not Crohn's disease. It describes the appearance of the colon on imaging studies, where the colon becomes tube-like with a loss of haustral folds due to chronic inflammation and fibrosis. This feature reflects the continuous, uniform involvement characteristic of ulcerative colitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transmural involvement: This is a hallmark of Crohn's disease, where inflammation can affect the entire depth of the intestinal walls from mucosa to serosa.

 

Option C. Rectal sparing: Often seen in Crohn's disease, where inflammation may skip the rectum, unlike ulcerative colitis, which almost always involves the rectum.

 

Option D. Perianal fistula: Commonly associated with Crohn's disease due to the deep transmural inflammation that can lead to complications such as fistulas and abscesses, particularly around the anal area.



Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/IBD

questions.text: Which of the following tests relies on the principle that prior knowledge of events or activities will influence a suspect's physiological responses? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Brain Mapping

 

Brain mapping is based on the principle that if a suspect has prior knowledge of an event or activity, it will be reflected in their brain wave responses. This technique involves measuring electrical brain wave responses (P300) to familiar stimuli, such as words, phrases, or pictures, presented on a computer screen. The P300 wave is an event-related potential (ERP) component elicited in the process of decision-making and is used to detect the recognition of familiar information. When a suspect recognizes the stimuli related to the event or activity, their brain produces a distinct response that can be measured and analyzed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Truth Serum: Truth serum refers to drugs used to make a person more likely to divulge truthful information. These drugs work by depressing the central nervous system to the point where the subject is less capable of resisting questioning and less likely to lie. It does not rely on physiological responses to prior knowledge.

 

Option B. Polygraph: The polygraph test measures physiological responses such as heart rate, blood pressure, and skin conductivity to determine if a person is lying. It is based on the theory that deceptive answers will produce physiological changes due to the emotional responses associated with lying, such as fear or anxiety. However, it does not specifically rely on the prior knowledge of events or activities.

 

Option C. Hypnosis: Hypnosis involves putting a subject into a trance-like state where they may be more open to suggestions and potentially recall forgotten details. It does not rely on physiological responses related to prior knowledge and is not primarily used for detecting deception based on prior knowledge of events.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brain mapping detects recognition of familiar stimuli through brain wave responses, reflecting a suspect's prior knowledge of events or activities

questions.text: Most common heart defect in congenital rubella syndrome is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PDA

 

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is the most common congenital heart disease associated with rubella, followed by pulmonary artery stenosis (PS).

 

 

Heart disease in congenital rubella: PDA > PS > VSD > ASD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ASD: ASD is the common congenital heart disease in down syndrome

 

Option B. VSD: VSD is the common congenital heart disease in infant of diabetic mother

 

Option D. PS: PS (pulmonary stenosis) is the common congenital heart disease in noonan and Alagille syndrome

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common heart defect in congenital rubella syndrome is Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA), followed by Pulmonary Stenosis (PS).

questions.text: Common precursor amino acid for urea, creatine and nitric oxide is? ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arginine

 

Arginine is the common precursor for urea, creatine and nitric oxide.

 

Arginine serves as the common precursor for all three compounds. It plays a central role in the urea cycle, where it is converted into ornithine, eventually leading to the production of urea. Additionally, arginine is a precursor for creatine synthesis, which is important for energy metabolism in muscles. It is also a precursor for nitric oxide, which has various physiological functions, including vasodilation and neurotransmission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycine: Glycine is not the common precursor for these three compounds. It is involved in various metabolic pathways but not directly related to the synthesis of urea, creatine, or nitric oxide.

 

Option C. Aspartate: Aspartate is not the common precursor for urea, creatine, and nitric oxide. It is primarily involved in the urea cycle as a component of reactions leading to the synthesis of arginine and urea.

 

Option D. Alanine: Alanine is not the common precursor for these compounds. It has roles in various metabolic pathways, but it is not directly involved in the synthesis of urea, creatine, or nitric oxide.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ornithine and citrulline are derivatives of arginine, and are essential for urea synthesis.
  • Creatine is synthesized from 3 amino acids: glycine, arginine and methionine (GAME)
  • Arginine is the precursor of nitric oxide which is an important signal molecule in the body.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a dietary fiber? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Milk

 

Explanation

 

Major components of dietary fiber are cellulose, hemicelluloses, D-glucans, pectin, lignin and gums. Cellulose, hemicelluloses and pectin are partially degradable, while other components are indigestible. Dietary fiber also contains minerals, antioxidants and other chemicals that are useful for health.

 

Sources of dietary fiber are fruits, vegetables, cereals, bread and wheat grain (particularly its outer layer).

 

Diet with high dietary fiber has health benefits since dietary fiber:

 

  1. Delays emptying of stomach
  2. Increases formation of bulk and soft feces and eases defecation
  3. Contains substances such as antioxidants and other useful substances

 

Diet with high fiber content tends to be low in energy and it may be useful in reducing the body weight.

 

Some components of dietary fiber also reduce blood cholesterol level and thereby decrease the risk for coronary heart disease and gallstones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cellulose: A primary form of dietary fiber found in the cell walls of plants.

 

Option B. Inulin: A type of soluble fiber found in many plants, used by some as a prebiotic to promote gut health.

 

Option C. Pectin: Another soluble fiber, pectin is commonly found in fruits and used to help gel liquids, also aiding in digestion and cholesterol reduction.
