Educational Objective:

questions.text: Confusion assessment test is used in:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delirium

 

The Confusion Assessment Method (often referred to as CAM) is a diagnostic tool specifically designed to identify delirium.

 

CAM is used primarily for the detection of delirium, especially in hospitalized or elderly patients. It evaluates features like acute onset and fluctuating course, inattention, disorganized thinking, and altered level of consciousness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dementia: While CAM can help differentiate delirium from dementia, it is not specifically designed for the diagnosis of dementia.

 

Option C. Schizophrenia: CAM is not used in the diagnosis or assessment of schizophrenia.

 

Option D. Depression: CAM is not used in the diagnosis or assessment of depression.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) is a tool specifically developed to detect delirium. Bedside examinations such as mini mental status examination (MMSE) are used to provide a measure of cognitive impairment.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 701.

questions.text: What is the chromosome number of a partial hydatidiform mole? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 69 XXY

 

Partial hydatidiform moles are characterized by being triploid, meaning they have three sets of chromosomes. The chromosome number for a partial mole is typically 69, which can be either 69XXX or 69XXY.

 

  • Formation of Partial Mole:
    • Partial moles occur when two sperm fertilize a single ovum (egg). This process is called diandry.
    • As a result, both maternal and paternal genetic components are present in a partial mole.
    • The most common karyotypes for partial moles are 69XXX and 69XXY.
  • Complete Mole Characteristics:
    • Complete moles are diploid, meaning they have two sets of chromosomes.
    • They form either by:
      • One sperm fertilizing an empty or inactivated ovum and then undergoing duplication, a process known as androgenesis, or
      • Two sperm (dispermy) fertilizing an empty or inactivated ovum.
    • The chromosome number for complete moles is typically 46XX or 46XY.
    • Only the paternal genetic component is present, with no maternal contribution.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 46 XX: This karyotype is typical for a complete mole, not a partial mole.

 

Option B. 45 XY: This karyotype is not typical for either complete or partial moles.

 

Option C. 69 XY: This option is incorrect as partial moles can be 69XY, but 69XXY is more specific and typical.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Partial hydatidiform moles are triploid, typically having a chromosome number of 69, which can be 69XXX or 69XXY.

 

Ref: Page no 616, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: The X-ray of a 5-year-old child is given below. Clinical examination, and hematological and urinary tests were normal. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Langerhans cell histiocytosis

 

  • The history and the provided imaging, which shows a single punched-out lytic lesion without a sclerotic rim and with a beveled edge look, point to Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH).
  • LCH is a rare disorder involving clonal proliferation of Langerhans cells, abnormal cells deriving from bone marrow and capable of migrating from skin to lymph nodes. This condition particularly affects children and can present with single or multiple lytic bone lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multiple myeloma:  A diagnosis of multiple myeloma is made by the typical triad of symptoms, which includes a marrow plasmacytosis of more than 10%, radiologic evidence of lytic bone lesions, and the presence of serum and/or urine M component.

 

 

Option C. Metastasis: In children, metastatic lesions in the skull are uncommon and typically originate from primary neuroblastoma or sarcoma but would present with different clinical features and possibly multiple lesions.


Option D. Primary hyperparathyroidism:  Patients with this condition have high levels of the parathyroid hormone, as well as hypercalcemia, hypophosphatemia, and hypercalciuria.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Langerhans cell histiocytosis is the most probable diagnosis given the age of the child, the radiographic appearance of the skull lesion, and the absence of systemic symptoms or biochemical abnormalities typically associated with the other conditions listed.

choices.text: Decreased number of Lactobacilli
Increased glycogen metabolism in the epithelium
pH > 6.8
Epithelial thinning

questions.text: Which of the following is true about vaginal changes in a normal pregnancy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased glycogen metabolism in the epithelium

 

  • Vaginal epithelium increases the metabolism of glycogen in pregnancy.
  • It leads to decrease in pH and makes the vaginal epithelium more acidic
  • This is because of increased lactobacilli

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased number of Lactobacilli: The number of lactobacilli are increased in the reproductive age group especially in pregnancy

 

Option C. pH > 6.8: Vaginal pH in pregnancy is acidic

 

 

Option D. Epithelial thinning: Estrogen increases the vaginal thickness in pregnancy. The vagina becomes thin in the absence of estrogen (like in menopause)

 

Educational Objective:

 

During pregnancy, the vaginal epithelium increases glycogen metabolism, leading to a more acidic environment that promotes the growth of Lactobacilli and helps protect against infections.

 

Ref: Page no 20, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: An infant present with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. Which of the following is accumulated in the brain in cerebrohepatorenal syndrome?  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Long chain fatty acid

 

Long-chain fatty acids are the substances that accumulate in the brain of individuals with cerebrohepatorenal syndrome, contributing to the neurological symptoms such as hypotonia and seizures. This accumulation disrupts normal brain function and leads to the characteristic clinical features of the syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose: Glucose is a normal energy source for the brain and is not typically accumulated in the brain in this syndrome.

 

Option C. Lactic acid: While lactic acid can accumulate in some metabolic disorders, it is not the primary substance that accumulates in cerebrohepatorenal syndrome.

 

Option D. Triglycerides: Triglycerides are a form of fat storage and are not typically accumulated in the brain in this syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zellweger syndrome or Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome is due to defective oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA). Peroxisomal enzymes are produced; but their entry into peroxisome is denied. This leads to insufficient oxidation of VLCFA. Accumulation of VLCFA in CNS causes profound neurologic impairment and death in childhood.

questions.text: Apparent volume of distribution of a drug is very high (6L/kg). Which of the following is true regarding the distribution of that drug? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sequestered in body tissues

 

  • A Vd (volume of distribution) of 6 L/kg means approx. 420 L (6 x 70) in a 70 Kg person. It is much higher than blood volume of 5L.
  • A high Vd suggests that the drug is extensively distributed beyond the blood and into the tissues. This often implies that the drug has a high affinity for tissues, effectively getting "sequestered" or stored there.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Highly bound to plasma proteins: A drug that is highly bound to plasma proteins would typically have a lower Vd because it is mostly confined to the bloodstream. Plasma protein binding keeps the drug within the vascular space, preventing its distribution into tissues.

 

Option B. Confined to vascular compartment: A low Vd would suggest that the drug is primarily in the vascular compartment, including plasma and blood cells. A high Vd of 6L/kg indicates the opposite, suggesting that the drug is widely distributed in tissues rather than confined to the vascular compartment.

 

Therefore, a high Vd suggests that the drug is stored or sequestered in various body tissues, making option C the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A high volume of distribution (Vd) suggests that the drug is widely distributed throughout the body and sequestered in various tissues, rather than being confined to the bloodstream or vascular compartment.

choices.text: History of lower transverse cesarean section in last two pregnancies

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for the induction of labor? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heart disease

 

Explanation:

 

  • Cardiovascular diseases are not a contraindication for vaginal delivery. In fact, NVD is preferred in heart disease patients. The second stage of labour is cut short with the use of instrumental vaginal delivery like forceps or ventouse assisted vaginal delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pelvic tumor: Pelvic tumor if diagnosed may interfere with normal labor and needs to be evaluated before deciding the mode of delivery

 

Option B. Herpes infection:  Active herpes is an absolute contra-indication to a normal delivery due to the high viral shedding in the lesions and increased risk of neonatal herpes.

 

Option D. History of lower transverse cesarean section in last two pregnancies: History of 2 or more previous cesareans is also a contra-indication to a vaginal delivery and hence induction is not done

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cardiovascular diseases are not a contraindication for vaginal delivery, and NVD is preferred in heart disease patients.

 

Ref: Page no 332, Dc Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: What constitutes the primary administrative unit in India? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) District

 

  • The principal unit of administration in India is the district, which is administered by a Collector.
  • The district is the basic unit of administration in India and is responsible for implementing various government schemes and programs at the grassroots level. It is headed by a District Collector or Deputy Commissioner, who is responsible for maintaining law and order, revenue administration, and developmental activities in the district.
  • Under districts are the sub-divisions, tehsils or talukas, municipalities or corporations, villages, panchayats, etc.
  • According to 2023 data, there are 766 districts in India

 

Educational Objective:

 

The district serves as the principal administrative unit in India, playing a vital role in governance and implementation of government policies at the grassroots level.

choices.text: FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for neurosyphilis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL) test

 

The investigation of choice for neurosyphilis is VDRL.

 

The CSF-VDRL test is highly specific and, when reactive, is considered diagnostic of neurosyphilis.

 

Involvement of the CNS in syphilis is detected by examination of CSF for:

 

  • Mononuclear pleocytosis (>5 white blood cells/uL).
  • Increased protein concentration (>45 mg/dL).
  • CSF VDRL reactivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. FTA-ABS (Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test): This test is highly sensitive for detecting the presence of antibodies to Treponema pallidum and is used to confirm a syphilis infection but is not specific for neurosyphilis as it can be positive due to past or present infection anywhere in the body.

 

Option C. RPR (Rapid Plasma Reagin test): Similar to VDRL, used as a screening test for syphilis based on the detection of non-treponemal antibodies indicative of an active infection, but not specific for neurosyphilis.

 

Option D. TPI (Treponema pallidum immobilization test): This is an older, highly specific test that is not commonly used today.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The CSF-VDRL test, despite its low sensitivity, remains the gold standard for the diagnosis of neurosyphilis due to its high specificity when positive. It is crucial in the diagnostic process for patients with suspected syphilis infection of the central nervous system, helping guide appropriate treatment and management.

questions.text: A child in your unit is diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition (SAM). According to the WHO criteria, SAM is defined best by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Weight for height less than -3SD

 

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is best defined as weight for height less than median minus -3SD

 

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children of ages 6 to 59 months is defined by the WHO as any of the following:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Weight for age less than -2SD: This defines moderate acute malnutrition (MAM), not severe acute malnutrition (SAM).

 

Option B. Weight for height less than +2SD: This would indicate overnutrition or obesity, not malnutrition.

 

Option C. Weight for age less than +3SD: This is not relevant to malnutrition and could indicate overnutrition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is defined by the WHO as weight-for-height (or length) below -3 SD of the WHO Child Growth Standards, presence of bilateral pitting edema, or mid-upper arm circumference less than 11.5 cm.

questions.text: In which of the following is the disc diffusion method for antibiotic susceptibility testing applied? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kirby-Bauer method

 

The disc diffusion method for antibiotic susceptibility testing is applied in the Kirby-Bauer method.

 

To perform Kirby-Bauer's disc diffusion method, a suitable standard dilution of a broth culture of the test bacterium is inoculated on the surface of a solid medium (Cation-adjusted Mueller-Hinton agar) as a lawn culture. After drying, various antibiotic discs are placed on its surface. Zones of inhibition around the disc are recorded and interpreted according to the zone diameters available in the tables of the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) guidelines. The results obtained are qualitative (resistant, sensitive, or partially sensitive).

 

Laboratory testing for antibiotic sensitivity can be done by:

 

  • Diffusion method- Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method, Stokes disc diffusion method
  • Dilution method- broth dilution method, agar dilution method
  • Combination of diffusion and dilution method- E-test (Epsilometer)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Agar dilution method: This method involves incorporating different concentrations of antibiotics into agar plates. It's primarily a quantitative technique that provides the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of antibiotics.

 

Option C. Broth dilution method: Similar to the agar dilution method but performed in a liquid medium. This method also determines the MIC of antibiotics.

 

Option D. PCR based assay: This molecular method detects the presence of specific antibiotic resistance genes but does not directly test the susceptibility of bacteria to antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method is a straightforward and widely used technique for assessing bacterial antibiotic susceptibility, providing vital information for the appropriate selection of antibiotics in clinical settings. It is essential for effective antimicrobial stewardship and the management of bacterial infections.

questions.text: In a patient with Wilson's disease, which of the following is decreased in urine?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3-methylhistidine

 

3-methylhistidine is decreased in urine in Wilson's disease. This decrease is associated with the abnormal buildup of copper in the liver, leading to decreased excretion of 3-methylhistidine in the urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tyrosine: Tyrosine levels may not be significantly affected in Wilson's disease. The primary concern in this condition is related to copper metabolism rather than amino acids like tyrosine.

 

Option B. Phosphorous: Phosphorus levels are typically not significantly altered in Wilson's disease. The main diagnostic markers for this disorder are related to copper levels.

 

Option C. Serine: Serine levels may not be significantly altered in Wilson's disease. The primary metabolic disturbance in this condition is related to copper accumulation rather than amino acids like serine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wilson's hepatolenticular degeneration is an inherited autosomal recessive condition.

 

  • The basic defect is a mutation in a gene encoding a copper binding ATPase in cells, which is required for excretion of copper from cells. So, copper is not excreted through bile, and hence copper toxicity.
  • Increased copper content in hepatocyte inhibits the incorporation of copper to apo-ceruloplasmin. So ceruloplasmin level in blood is decreased.
  • Clinical Features
    • Accumulation in liver leads to hepatocellular degeneration and cirrhosis.
    • Deposits in brain basal ganglia leads to lenticular degeneration and neurological symptoms.
    • Copper deposits as green or golden pigmented ring around cornea; this is called Kayser-Fleischer ring.
  • Treatment consists of a diet containing low copper and injection of D-penicillamine, which excretes copper through urine. Since zinc decreases copper absorption, zinc is useful in therapy.
  • Amino acids are excreted in the urine in either conjugated (mostly) or in free form. The amount of conjugated amino acids in urine is far more than free form in Wilson’s disease. Methyl Histidine largely exists in free form and does not increase in amount on hydrolysis of acids in urine, hence the urinary levels of 3-methylhistidine are low in patients with Wilson disease.

choices.text: Increase in partial pressure of oxygen (pa02)

questions.text: Which of the following is the main factor for the ductal closure postnatally? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increase in partial pressure of oxygen (pa02)

 

The increase in partial pressure of oxygen (paO2) is the main factor controlling the closure of the ductus arteriosus postnatally. Oxygen acts as a potent smooth muscle constrictor. When a newborn begins to breathe and cries, oxygen enters the lungs during inspiration, leading to an increase in paO2. This increased oxygen tension causes the smooth muscle in the ductus arteriosus to constrict, leading to its closure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase in systemic vascular resistance: While systemic vascular resistance does increase after birth due to the cessation of placental circulation, it is not the primary factor responsible for ductal closure.

 

Option C. Increase in circulating prostaglandin levels: Prostaglandins, particularly PGE2, help keep the ductus arteriosus open. After birth, the levels of circulating prostaglandins decrease, contributing to ductal closure, but an increase in prostaglandins would not cause closure.

 

Option D. Decrease in pulmonary venous resistance: Pulmonary vascular resistance decreases after birth as the lungs expand and fill with air, allowing blood to flow more easily through the pulmonary circulation. However, this is not the direct cause of ductal closure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The increase in partial pressure of oxygen (paO2) postnatally is the most important factor for the closure of the ductus arteriosus.

questions.text: Which of the following is a water soluble contrast? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Iohexol

 

Explanation:

 

lohexol is a non-ionic, water-soluble iodinated contrast medium, used in various radiographic studies including CT scans, angiography, and myelography. It is known for its low osmolality and good safety profile, making it suitable for intravascular use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Barium: While barium sulfate is a contrast agent, it is not water-soluble and is primarily used for gastrointestinal studies.

 

Option C. Bromium: Not typically used as a contrast agent in medical imaging.

 

Option D. Calcium: Not used as a contrast agent. In medical imaging, calcium deposits may be identified by their radiographic appearance, but calcium itself is not administered as a contrast medium.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the anti-apoptotic factor among the following: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bcl-2

 

The anti-apoptotic factor among the following is BcI-2.

 

Apoptosis is a process of programmed cell death that occurs in multicellular organisms. It is a highly regulated process that involves a complex network of proteins and signaling pathways. Among the proteins involved in apoptosis are two families of proteins known as the Bcl-2 family and the caspase family.

 

The Bcl-2 family of proteins includes both pro-apoptotic and anti-apoptotic members. The pro-apoptotic members include Bax, Bak, and others, while the anti-apoptotic members include Bcl-2, Bcl-XL, and others. The balance between pro-apoptotic and anti-apoptotic members of the Bcl-2 family is important in determining whether a cell will undergo apoptosis or not.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. P-53: P-53 is a tumor suppressor protein known for its role in preventing cancer. It can induce apoptosis but is generally considered a promoter of cell cycle arrest and DNA repair in response to DNA damage, rather than being anti-apoptotic.

 

Option B. K-ras: K-ras is an oncogene that, when mutated, contributes to cancer progression by promoting cellular proliferation and survival, not directly inhibiting apoptosis.

 

Option D. BAK: BAK, like Bax, is a pro-apoptotic member of the Bcl-2 family. It promotes apoptosis by facilitating mitochondrial outer membrane permeabilization, which is a critical step in the activation of the apoptotic pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bcl-2's anti-apoptotic properties make it a key player in cellular survival and stress response. Its ability to inhibit key steps in the apoptotic process distinguishes it from other proteins like P-53, K-ras, and BAK, which have different roles in the regulation of cell death and proliferation.

questions.text: Which of the following would be prescribed for simple myopic astigmatism?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. -1.00 DC X 180 degree

 

  • The correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism is -1.00 DC × 180 degrees.
  • Simple myopic astigmatism means that one principal meridian of the eye is in focus on the retina, while the other principal meridian is in front of the retina.
  • There are three components to the prescription of glasses for astigmatism: 
    1. The power of the spherical component (convex or concave dioptre sphere),
    2. The power of the cylinder (convex or concave dioptre cylinder),
    3. The axis (orientation) of the cylinder.

 

For example: -1.00 DC × 180 degree

 

This prescription indicates that the individual has simple astigmatism, which means one meridian of the eye is in focus while the other is not. In this case, the unfocused meridian is myopic (nearsighted) and requires correction with a concave cylinder lens. The strength of the cylinder lens is -1.00 diopters (DC). The axis of the cylinder is oriented at 180 degrees, which represents the meridian that is most affected by astigmatism.

 

Types of astigmatism:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. +1.00 DS: This represents a convex spherical lens for hypermetropia (farsightedness) and is not used for astigmatism correction.

 

Option C. -1.00 DS: This represents a concave spherical lens for simple myopia (nearsightedness) but does not correct astigmatism.

 

Option D. -1.00 DS -1.00 DC X 180 degree: This represents a prescription for compound myopic astigmatism, where both meridians are myopic, one corrected by the spherical component and the other by the cylindrical component.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Simple myopic astigmatism requires correction with a cylindrical lens that corrects the myopic meridian, typically specified with the cylinder power and the axis. The correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism in this case is -1.00 DC X 180 degrees.

choices.text: Trinucleotide mutation in FMR-1 gene
Mental retardation
Large everted ears

questions.text: All of the following are features of fragile X syndrome except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Micro-orchidism

 

Macro-orchidism (large testicles) are seen in fragile X syndrome, not micro-orchidism.

 

Fragile X syndrome is caused by a trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome. This expansion leads to a deficiency in the FMRP protein, which is important for neural development and function. Males with fragile X syndrome often have macro-orchidism, which can be observed during childhood and becomes more apparent during puberty. Other physical features of fragile X syndrome may include a long and narrow face, prominent forehead and chin, and large ears that are often everted. Intellectual disability and behavioral problems are also common features of the syndrome.

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Ito cells
Endothelial cells

questions.text: Which part of the liver stores vitamin A?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ito cells

 

Explanation

 

  • Ito cells are the cells that store vitamin A in the liver. These cells, also known as hepatic stellate cells, are located in the space of Disse, which is between the hepatocytes and the endothelial cells in the liver.
  • Ito cells play a role in liver function and pathology, and are involved in the regulation of extracellular matrix synthesis and degradation, as well as in the response to liver injury. They are also responsible for the storage and release of vitamin A in the liver.
  • Kupffer cells, also known as stellate macrophages and Kupffer-Borowicz cells; are specialized macrophages located in the liver that form part of the mononuclear phagocyte system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hepatocytes: Incorrect, while hepatocytes are the main functional cells of the liver and perform numerous metabolic, synthetic, and detoxifying functions, they are not the primary storage sites for vitamin A.

 

Option C. Endothelial cells: Incorrect, these cells line the blood vessels of the liver and are involved in filtration and blood flow regulation within the organ, not in vitamin storage.

 

Option D. Kupffer cells: Incorrect, Kupffer cells are the liver's resident macrophages, involved in immune responses and the breakdown of red blood cells, not in storing vitamins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ito cells (hepatic stellate cells) are the primary storage sites for vitamin A in the liver. Their role extends beyond vitamin storage to include critical functions in the regulation of the extracellular matrix and the liver's response to injury.

choices.text: Pain and temperature loss in the same side
Pain and temperature loss in the opposite side
Loss of tactile and proprioception on the same side
Loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side

questions.text: Lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of pons causes which of the following?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side

 

Explanation

 

Lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of pons causes loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side.

 

The first order neurons carry sensory information regarding touch, proprioception or vibration from the peripheral nerves to the medulla oblongata by two different pathways 

 

  • Signals from the upper limb (T6 and above) – travel in the fasciculus cuneatus (the lateral part of the dorsal column). They then synapse in the nucleus cuneatus of the medulla oblongata.
  • Signals from the lower limb (below T6) – travel in the fasciculus gracilis (the medial part of the dorsal column). They then synapse in the nucleus gracilis of the medulla oblongata.

 

The second order neuron begin in the cuneate nucleus or gracilis. The fibres receive the information from the preceding neuron, and delivers it to the third order neuron in the thalamus. Within the medulla oblongata, these fibres decussate (cross to the other side of the CNS). They then travel in the contralateral medial lemniscus to reach the thalamus.

 

Lastly, the third order neuron transmit the sensory signals from the thalamus to the ipsilateral primary sensory cortex of the brain. They ascend from the ventral posterolateral nucleus of the thalamus, travel through the internal capsule and terminate at the sensory cortex.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pain and temperature loss in the same side: Incorrect, as the medial lemniscus does not primarily carry pain and temperature sensations; these are transmitted by the spinothalamic tract.

 

Option B. Pain and temperature loss in the opposite side: Incorrect for the same reason as above.

 

Option C. Loss of tactile and proprioception on the same side: Incorrect because the crossing of fibers in the medulla means that a lesion in the medial lemniscus at the pons affects the opposite side of the body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of the pons causes loss of tactile sense and proprioception on the opposite side of the body due to the decussation (crossing over) of second-order neurons in the medulla, which then ascend contralaterally in the medial lemniscus to the brain.

questions.text: During evaluation of PUO, a patient's chest X-ray is as seen below. What is your diagnosis?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Miliary tuberculosis

 

Explanation:

 

The given chest X-ray depicts miliary tuberculosis.

 

Miliary tuberculosis:

 

  • Bilateral randomly distributed nodules on HRCT.
  • Hematogenous spread.

 

Miliary pattern D/D:   

 

  • Healed varicella
  • TPE/ Loeffler’s syndrome
  • Hemosiderosis
  • Silicosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pulmonary edema: Typically presents with bilateral opacities, predominantly in the perihilar regions, and may show Kerley B lines, none of which are visible in this X-ray.

 

Option C. Necrobiotic nodules: Commonly associated with conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, presenting as larger, well-defined nodules, which is not the case here.

 

Option D. Tuberculoma: Typically appears as a solitary, well-defined round lesion, often with a calcified center, not the diffuse pattern observed here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Miliary tuberculosis is characterized by fine, diffuse nodules throughout the lungs, resulting from widespread dissemination of the tuberculosis bacteria. This is a serious condition requiring immediate medical attention and treatment.

questions.text: On performing a pulmonary function test, reduction in FEV1/FVC is characteristic of: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Obstructive disease

 

A reduction in the FEV1/FVC ratio (Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second / Forced Vital Capacity) is characteristic of obstructive lung diseases. This ratio is a key indicator used to differentiate between obstructive and restrictive lung patterns on pulmonary function tests. In obstructive diseases, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), asthma, and bronchiectasis, there is a disproportionate reduction in FEV1 relative to FVC due to airflow limitation and air trapping.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Restrictive disease: In restrictive lung diseases, both FEV1 and FVC are reduced proportionally, often leading to a normal or even increased FEV1/FVC ratio. Restrictive diseases include conditions such as pulmonary fibrosis and other interstitial lung diseases.

 

Option C. Normal lung function: Normal lung function would typically show an FEV1/FVC ratio within the normal range, which is generally above 0.7 in healthy adults.

 

Option D. Interstitial lung disease: This condition is a type of restrictive lung disease where there is a reduction in lung volumes, but the FEV1/FVC ratio is typically normal or increased, not reduced.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • FEV1/FVC reduction implies obstruction.
  • FEV1/FVC Increased or normal – Restrictive lung disease
  • Decrease in Maximum Mid-expiratory flow (MMEF) i.e., FEV25%-75% - Small airway disease

questions.text: Which cardiac chamber enlargement is seen in the case of mitral stenosis on chest X-ray initially? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Left atrium

 

In the case of mitral stenosis (MS), the obstruction at the mitral valve leads to increased pressure in the left atrium as it works harder to pump blood through the narrowed valve. This increased pressure causes the left atrium to dilate. This dilation can be identified on a chest X-ray as enlargement of the left atrial silhouette. The left atrium enlargement is often the earliest and most prominent cardiac chamber change seen in mitral stenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right atrium: Right atrium enlargement generally occurs later in the course of mitral stenosis as a consequence of the elevated pressure being transmitted back through the lungs to the right side of the heart.

 

Option C. Left ventricle: The left ventricle is typically not directly affected by mitral stenosis, as this condition primarily impacts the left atrium. Left ventricular enlargement would be more characteristic of conditions affecting the left ventricular outflow or volume overload.

 

Option D. Right ventricle: Right ventricular enlargement may eventually occur if the disease progresses to the point of causing pulmonary hypertension, which then puts a strain on the right ventricle. However, this is a later development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitral stenosis primarily leads to enlargement of the left atrium as the initial response to increased pressure upstream of the stenotic mitral valve. Recognition of this early sign on a chest X-ray can be crucial for diagnosing and managing mitral stenosis effectively.

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/VHD

questions.text: Which of the following is a synthetic PGE1 derivative used as an abortifacient? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Misoprostol

 

Misoprostol is a synthetic prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) derivative that is commonly used for inducing labor and as an abortifacient. It is used either alone or in combination with other medications like mifepristone for medical abortion. It can be administered orally, vaginally, or sublingually.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dinoprost: Dinoprost is a naturally occurring prostaglandin F2-alpha (PGF2α), not a PGE1 derivative. It is also used in obstetrics but is not a synthetic PGE1 derivative.

 

Option B. Dinoprostone: Like Dinoprost, Dinoprostone is another form of prostaglandin but it is a naturally occurring PGE2. It is also used in obstetrics to ripen the cervix and induce labor, but it is not a synthetic PGE1 derivative.

 

Option D. Carboprost: Carboprost is a synthetic analogue of prostaglandin F2-alpha (PGF2α). It is used to induce abortion and treat postpartum hemorrhage but is not a synthetic PGE1 derivative.

 

Therefore, the synthetic PGE1 derivative used as an abortifacient is Misoprostol, making option C the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Misoprostol is the synthetic PGE1 derivative used as an abortifacient. It is effective in inducing labor, facilitating medical abortion, and treating postpartum hemorrhage by promoting uterine contractions and cervical ripening.

questions.text: Which of the following has the least conduction velocity? (NEET PG  2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Postganglionic sympathetic fibers

 

Postganglionic sympathetic fibers, also known as type C fibers, are known for their small diameter and lack of myelin sheath, characteristics that contribute to their slow conduction velocity compared to other nerve fiber types. These fibers are involved in the sympathetic nervous system, carrying impulses from the autonomic ganglia to the target organs. The absence of myelin significantly reduces their conduction speed because myelin acts as an insulator that enhances the speed of nerve impulse conduction through saltatory conduction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Somatic motor fibers: These fibers, typically myelinated and larger in diameter, conduct impulses much faster. They are involved in controlling voluntary muscle movements.

 

Option C. Pre-ganglionic autonomic fibers: Generally myelinated though smaller than somatic motor fibers, pre-ganglionic fibers also conduct impulses faster than postganglionic sympathetic fibers.

 

Option D. Touch and pressure fibers: These sensory fibers are usually myelinated and conduct impulses at high speeds, facilitating rapid response to sensory stimuli.

 

Additional Information:

 

  • Conduction Velocity Factors: The speed at which a nerve fiber conducts an electrical impulse is influenced by its diameter and whether or not it is myelinated. Larger diameter and myelination both contribute to faster conduction velocities.
  • Type C Fibers: These are the smallest and slowest conducting fibers due to their lack of myelination. They typically transmit nociceptive (pain) and sympathetic autonomic signals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among the options given, postganglionic sympathetic fibers (Type C fibers) have the least conduction velocity due to their small diameter and lack of myelin, which make them slower in transmitting nerve impulses compared to myelinated fibers.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the point from A to C in the given flowchart depicting the natural history of a disease? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lead time

 

Lead time is defined as the interval between the point a condition is detected through screening and the Time it would normally have been detected due to appearance and reporting of signs and symptoms.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Screening time:  This term refers to the period during which screening tests are conducted to detect disease in asymptomatic individuals.

 

Option C. Lag time:  This term is generally used to describe a delay between the onset of an event and its detection or measurement. In the context of disease, lag time could refer to the delay between symptom onset and diagnosis.

 

Option D. Generation time:  This term is typically used in epidemiology to describe the time interval between the infection of a host and the subsequent transmission of the disease to another host. It does not relate to the timeline of diagnosis within an individual patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lead time is the interval between the detection of a disease through screening and its usual time of diagnosis due to symptom presentation.

 

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening (leading the time of diagnosis)

 

Early detection of disease due to screening (B rather than C) will ensure earlier institution of treatment, thus better prognosis.

questions.text: A young female presented with vaginal itching and green frothy genital discharge. Strawberry vagina is seen on examination. What will be the drug of choice?  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Metronidazole

 

This is the description of vaginal discharge caused by Trichomonas vaginalis.

 

Salient features:

 

  • It is transmitted by sexual intercourse, with an incubation period of 4-21 days.
  • It typically results in vaginal soreness, frequent urination, and a copious, frothy, yellow-green discharge in females with a pH > 4.5.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  1. Direct Immunofluorescent antibody staining – Most sensitive
  2. Wet mount – Motile flagella seen
  3. Culture - Feinberg-Whittington media

 

Treatment:

 

  • D.O.C. – Metronidazole (2 gm Oral)
  • An alternate dose is metronidazole 500 mg orally twice a day for 7 days.
  • Prophylaxis to all sexual partners.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Azithromycin

  • Primary uses: It is an antibiotic used primarily to treat bacterial infections like chlamydia, respiratory tract infections, and certain types of skin infections. It's a drug of choice for chlamydia and can also be used in the treatment of gonorrhea (often in combination with ceftriaxone).

 

Option C. Doxycycline

  • Primary uses: It's an antibiotic that is frequently used to treat bacterial infections such as chlamydia, non-gonococcal urethritis, and pelvic inflammatory disease. It's also a drug of choice for Lyme disease and is used for the prophylaxis of malaria in certain regions.

 

Option D. Oral fluconazole

  • Primary uses: It's an antifungal drug that's used primarily to treat and prevent fungal infections, especially Candida infections. It's the drug of choice for vaginal candidiasis (yeast infection). It's also used for systemic candida infections, cryptococcal meningitis, and prophylaxis in immunocompromised patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metronidazole is the treatment of choice for Trichomoniasis, which presents with vaginal itching, green frothy discharge, and a "strawberry vagina" on examination, distinguishing it from bacterial and fungal causes of vaginal symptoms that would require different treatments.

 

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Chapter 33, Page nos 33.35 and 33.36

Question Level – Intermediate 

Question Id-7463 Unique Key-Q3304541

questions.text: Which of the following murmur increases on standing? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. HOCM

 

The murmur of Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy (HOCM) typically increases on standing. This is due to the decreased venous return and preload that occur with standing, which result in a reduction in the size of the left ventricular cavity. The smaller cavity size exacerbates the outflow obstruction under the aortic valve, thereby intensifying the murmur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitral Regurgitation (MR): The murmur associated with MR typically decreases when standing due to the decreased venous return and reduced volume load on the left ventricle, which lessens the regurgitant flow across the mitral valve.

 

Option C. Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD): The murmur of a VSD generally decreases on standing due to reduced left to right shunting caused by decreased venous return.

 

Option D. Mitral Stenosis (MS): The murmur of mitral stenosis also decreases on standing. The reduction in preload lessens the flow through the narrowed mitral valve, subsequently reducing the intensity of the murmur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among the options listed, the murmur of Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy is unique in that it increases on standing, due to the specific hemodynamic changes that accentuate the outflow obstruction. This characteristic can be a crucial diagnostic clue in the clinical assessment of murmurs.

 

Reference - Harrison/Physical examination of CVS/Chap 239

questions.text: Most effective antiemetic for chemotherapy-induced vomiting is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Granisetron

 

Granisetron is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist that is highly effective for preventing chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV). These drugs have become the standard of care for managing moderate to highly emetogenic chemotherapy agents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Domperidone: Domperidone is a dopamine receptor antagonist used for the treatment of nausea and vomiting, but it is generally not as effective as 5-HT3 receptor antagonists like Granisetron for managing chemotherapy-induced vomiting.

 

Option B. Tegaserod: Tegaserod is primarily used for treating irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) with constipation and is not an antiemetic. It acts as a 5-HT4 receptor agonist to promote gastrointestinal motility.

 

Option D. Doxylamine: Doxylamine is an antihistamine that can be used for nausea and vomiting during pregnancy, often in combination with pyridoxine (vitamin B6). It is not the most effective option for chemotherapy-induced vomiting.

 

Therefore, the most effective antiemetic for chemotherapy-induced vomiting is Granisetron, making option C the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granisetron, a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist, is the most effective antiemetic for preventing chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV). It is the standard of care for managing nausea and vomiting associated with moderate to highly emetogenic chemotherapy agents.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best treatment for idiopathic thrombocytic purpura? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Splenectomy

 

Splenectomy is considered the best long-term treatment option for patients with chronic ITP who do not respond to medical therapies such as steroids or immunoglobulins. The procedure involves removing the spleen, which is a site of platelet destruction in ITP. Removing the spleen often results in a permanent increase in platelet count, though it is typically reserved for patients who are refractory to first-line treatments.

 

Approach to ITP:

 

If severe ITP @ presentation: Transfusion+ steroids

 

  • Intracranial/GI Bleed
  • PC < 5k
  • Large oral bleed/Retinal bleed

 

Low dose steroids recommended in all cases of ITP.

 

If steroid unresponsive, decision depends on duration:

 

  1. Persistent (3-12 months): Rituximab vs TPO-RA (Romiplostim (S. C.), Eltrombopag (Oral)
  2. Chronic (>12 months): Rituximab vs Splenectomy vs TPO-RA

 

If still persistent/refractory, possible options are:

 

  • Fostamatinib: SyK (Tyrosine kinase inhibitor)
  • MMF/Cyclophosphamide/Azathioprine
  • Autologous stem cell transplant

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV immunoglobulins: Used as a first-line treatment, especially for acute cases of ITP or in severe cases to quickly raise the platelet count, but not as a long-term solution.

 

Option B. Steroids: Common first-line treatment for ITP that can effectively increase platelet count in many patients, though many eventually relapse upon discontinuation or become steroid-dependent.

 

Option D. Blood transfusion: Generally not a primary treatment for ITP since the issue is not the quantity of produced platelets but their premature destruction; transfusions might be used in acute, severe bleeding scenarios but do not address the underlying autoimmune process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Splenectomy is often considered the best treatment option for chronic or refractory idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura, particularly when other treatments such as steroids and IV immunoglobulins fail to maintain a safe platelet count or cause side effects that are difficult to manage.

 

Reference: ASH 2021 summary

choices.text: Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body
Increase in the rate of discharge of the γ efferent neuron
Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool
Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock

questions.text: According to Herrington classification, the decerebrate rigidity is characterized by all except? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body

 

Explanation

 

Decerebrate rigidity is the rigid extension of all the limbs due to decerebration. This type of rigidity is well pronounced in the extensor muscles. The term decerebrate rigidity was coined by Sherrington in 1897.

 

Reason for decerebrate rigidity:

 

  • Release of the centers, situated below the section, from higher inhibitory controls. The inhibitory area is 4S. It is situated in the motor cortex of cerebrum, just anterior to area 4 and behind area 6. In this area, Betz cells are absent.
  • From here, the fibers are projected to spinal cord via reticular formation. So, in decerebration the discharge from neurons of area 4S cannot reach spinal motor neurons. This leads to exaggeration of spinal motor neurons resulting in rigidity.
  • Decerebrate rigidity is also produced by stopping the blood flow to the forebrain. It is done by occlusion of the common carotid artery and the basilar artery at the center of the pons.

 

Decerebrate rigidity is characterized by

 

  1. γ motor neuron discharge rate increased.
  2. Motor neuron pool excitability increased.
  3. Decerebration produces no phenomenon similar to spinal shock.
  4. Antigravity extensor muscles are involved in decerebrate injury

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase in the rate of discharge of the γ efferent neuron: Correct as part of the characterization of decerebrate rigidity. The increased discharge rate of the γ efferent neurons enhances the muscle spindle responses, contributing to increased muscle tone.

 

Option C. Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool: Correct, this increased excitability leads to the hyperactivity of motor neurons, particularly those controlling the extensor muscles.

 

Option D. Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock: Correct, unlike spinal shock, which involves a temporary reduction or loss of reflex activity below the level of a spinal cord injury, decerebration does not produce a similar transient reduction in reflexes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decerebrate rigidity is characterized by an increase in extensor muscle tone due to enhanced activity of the γ motor neurons and increased excitability of the motor neuron pool, without inducing effects similar to spinal shock. Rigidity does not occur in all muscles of the body but is more pronounced in antigravity extensor muscles.

questions.text: The commonest indication for liver transplantation in children is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biliary atresia

 

Liver transplantation is a crucial life-saving procedure for children with liver failure. The most common indication for liver transplantation in children is biliary atresia. Biliary atresia is a condition characterized by a blockage in the bile ducts outside the liver, leading to progressive liver damage and cirrhosis.

 

For infants diagnosed with biliary atresia, a surgical procedure known as hepatoportoenterostomy (Kasai procedure) is performed to establish bile drainage. However, if the Kasai procedure is not successful in restoring bile flow, liver transplantation becomes necessary, often within the first year of life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alagille syndrome: This syndrome, characterized by butterfly-shaped vertebrae and congenital heart disease (often pulmonary stenosis), results in infantile cholestasis due to a syndromic paucity of intralobular bile ducts. It is a less common indication for liver transplantation compared to biliary atresia.

 

Option C. Caroli disease: This is a rare congenital disorder characterized by dilation of the intrahepatic bile ducts. While it can lead to liver failure, it is not the most common indication for liver transplantation in children.

 

Option D. Hepatocellular carcinoma: This is a rare cause of liver transplantation in children. While liver tumors can necessitate transplantation, they are less common compared to biliary atresia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Biliary atresia is the most common indication for liver transplantation in children due to the progressive liver damage and cirrhosis caused by bile duct obstruction.

questions.text: True regarding mitochondrial genome?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Maternal inheritance

 

  • The mitochondrial genome is inherited maternally, which means it is passed down from the mother to her offspring. This is because mitochondria are typically inherited from the cytoplasm of the egg cell. Sperm contributes very little, if any, mitochondria to the zygote, and paternal mitochondria are usually degraded after fertilization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Low Rate of Mutation: False Mitochondrial DNA is known to have a relatively high mutation rate compared to nuclear DNA. This higher mutation rate is partly due to the lack of protective histones and efficient DNA repair mechanisms in mitochondria. As a result, mutations in mitochondrial DNA can accumulate over time.

 

Option C. Single-stranded DNA: False Mitochondrial DNA is double-stranded, just like nuclear DNA. It forms a circular double-stranded DNA molecule. This structure is distinct from the single-stranded DNA found in some viruses and certain cellular processes.

 

Option D. Paternal Inheritance: False Mitochondrial DNA is not inherited from the father; it is exclusively maternally inherited. Paternal mitochondria are generally not passed on to the offspring during fertilization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial DNA and RNA:

 

  1. There is a dichotomy on the mitochondrial metabolism. Some of the mitochondrial protein synthesis is under the control of mitochondrial DNA; but important proteins of the outer membrane of the mitochondria are synthesized under the influence of nuclear DNA.
  2. The mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is circular, has about 16,500 nucleotides. The mtDNA has information for synthesis of 2 ribosomal RNAs, 22 tRNAs and 13 proteins. All of them are components of electron transport chain. It has 37 genes that encode 13 protein subunits of the respiratory chain (total of 67 i.e., about 20%). However, most of mitochondrial proteins are encoded by nuclear DNA and synthesized in the cytoplasm.
  3. Maternal inheritance: Since, the mitochondria are inherited cytoplasmically, the mtDNA is inherited from the mother. Mother transmits mtDNA through oocyte.
  4. There are hundreds of copies of mtDNA in each cell (nuclear DNA has only 2 copies).
  5. Heteroplasmy is defined as the presence of normal and mutant mtDNA in different proportions in different cells. During cell division, mtDNA replicates and they segregate to the daughter cells. If a mutation occurs in mtDNA, the daughter cells may inherit the mutant or normal mtDNA.
  6. High mutation rate: 5-10 times that of nuclear DNA
  7. Age-related accumulation of mutations in mtDNA may be responsible for age-related decrease in cellular OXPHOS function, and progression of other degenerative diseases.
  8. Defects in mitochondrial genome will lead to mitochondrial myopathies.

choices.text: Inherited defect in PIG-A
Deficiency of CD 55 and CD 59

questions.text: Which of the following is true about paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Deficiency of CD 55 and CD 59

 

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is characterized by a deficiency in the proteins CD55 and CD59, which normally protect red blood cells from immune attack. This deficiency is caused by a mutation in the PIG-A gene on the X chromosome, which is acquired (not inherited) and results in the failure to attach these protective proteins to the cell membrane. Without these proteins, red blood cells become susceptible to destruction by the complement system, a part of the immune system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inherited defect in PIG-A: This statement is incorrect. The defect in the PIG-A gene associated with PNH is acquired, not inherited.

 

Option B. Extravascular hemolysis: PNH primarily causes intravascular hemolysis, not extravascular. This is because the unregulated activation of the complement system leads to the lysis of red blood cells within the circulatory system.

 

Option D. Microcytic anemia: PNH typically results in normocytic anemia, not microcytic anemia. The anemia in PNH is due to the destruction of red blood cells by the complement system, which affects cells of normal size.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The true hallmark of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is the deficiency of CD55 and CD59 on the surface of blood cells, leading to increased vulnerability to lysis by the complement system and resulting in intravascular hemolysis. This understanding is critical for the correct diagnosis and management of PNH.

 

Reference - Harrison/PNH/Chapter 100

questions.text: Based on the agglutination test shown below, what is the blood group?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. O positive

 

The agglutination test is a blood test used to determine an individual's blood type. In the case of O positive blood, the test involves mixing a sample of the person's blood with two different types of antibodies: anti-A and anti-B.

 

The person's blood cells do not agglutinate in the presence of either antibody, it indicates that the person's blood type is O positive. This means that the person's blood cells do not contain either the A or B antigen, but do contain the Rh factor antigen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. B positive: Incorrect because there is no agglutination in the B panel, indicating the absence of B antigens.

 

Option B. A positive: Incorrect as there is no agglutination in the A panel, indicating the absence of A antigens.

 

Option D. AB positive: Incorrect because there is no agglutination in both A and B panels, which would be required for AB blood type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The absence of agglutination with anti-A and anti-B antibodies and the presence of agglutination with anti-Rh antibodies confirms the blood group as O positive. This means the individual's red blood cells lack A and B antigens but contain the Rh factor.

questions.text: Which lymphoma is strongly associated with overexpression of BCL2? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Follicular lymphoma

 

Follicular lymphoma is associated with overexpression of BCL2.

 

Normal cells include the BCL2 gene, however this gene's mutant version with the recognizable translocation t (14;18) (q32; q21) was originally identified in B-cell lymphoma, hence the term BCL.

 

Numerous other human malignancies, including those of the breast, thyroid, and prostate, also exhibit it.

 

Due to a mutation in the BCL2 gene, more living cells are undergoing mitosis, which contributes to the formation of tumors by removing the apoptosis-inhibitory control on cancer cells.

 

The most prevalent chromosomal translocation in human lymphomas, the t(14;18)  (q32;q21) is found in up to 30% of diffuse large B-cell lymphomas and over 85% of follicular lymphomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Burkitt lymphoma: Characterized by the c-MYC gene translocation, not BCL2 overexpression.

 

Option C. Diffuse large-cell lymphoma: While BCL2 can be overexpressed due to the same translocation, it is more typically associated with follicular lymphoma.

 

Option D. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL): CLL can also exhibit overexpression of BCL2, but this is generally due to other genetic mechanisms rather than the t(14;18) translocation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follicular lymphoma is primarily associated with the overexpression of BCL2 due to the t(14;18) chromosomal translocation. This genetic alteration is a critical factor in the pathogenesis of follicular lymphoma, enabling lymphoma cells to evade apoptosis and sustain tumor growth. Understanding the role of BCL2 in various lymphomas helps in differentiating among them and tailoring appropriate therapeutic strategies.

choices.text: An HLA identical matched unrelated donor who is blood type O-
His HLA identical 50-year-old brother who is otherwise healthy and is blood type O+

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia with a blood type O negative blood group presents to the transplant clinic to discuss proceeding with an allogeneic stem cell transplant. Which of the following would be an optimal donor? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. His HLA identical 50-year-old brother who is otherwise healthy and is blood type O+

 

  1. Due to the decreased risk of graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) with related transplants, related donor transplants are still favored over unrelated donor transplants.
  2. Rh incompatibility has no impact on the success of transplants (Rh antigen is only found on the surface of RBCs, not on the parenchymal cells of the graft).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Syngeneic transplantation (donation from identical twins) has been shown to increase the risk of relapse in cases of hematologic malignancies and is therefore not a source of donor that is advised.

 

Option B: Umbilical cord transplant is not usually recommended.

 

Option C: While ABO compatibility is vital when selecting a donor, this is merely a slight ABO discrepancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with acute myeloid leukemia, the optimal donor choice would generally be an HLA identical sibling, despite any ABO blood type differences, due to the lower risk of complications and better overall survival outcomes. Blood type discrepancies, especially in Rh factor, are manageable in the context of stem cell transplants.

 

Reference - Harrison/Transplant/Chap 104

choices.text: Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice

questions.text: Which statement is incorrect about the pathology shown?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice

 

The given X-ray shows eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region with distinct margins with soap bubble appearance indicative of Giant cell tumour (GCT). Treatment of GCT includes Curettage or Excision with bone grafting.

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • Histology: Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue. The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of giant cells - a feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumor from other tumors that may contain giant cells.

 

Clinical Features

 

  • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling.
  • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases.
  • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.

 

Radiological Features

 

  • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region with distinct margins, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance.

 

Treatment

 

  • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
  • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

Educational Objective

 

Giant Cell Tumor (GCT) of bone typically manifests as an eccentric lytic lesion in the epiphyseal region of long bones with distinct margins. The mainstay of treatment for GCT is surgical intervention, either through curettage or excision followed by bone grafting, rather than chemotherapy. This surgical approach helps ensure complete removal of the tumor and helps prevent recurrence.

questions.text: Which part of scaphoid is most susceptible to avascular necrosis? (NEET PG  2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Proximal 1/3rd

 

SCAPHOID FRACTURE

 

  • Salient features: 

    • It is the most commonly fractured bone in the carpus, in adult as well as children. 

    • Most commonly in males between the ages of 15 and 30. 

    • Fullness and tenderness in anatomical snuff box. 

    • Proximal pressure along the axis of the thumb may be painful.

  • Most common location:              

    • Adults and adolescents: Middle third (Waist) fractures (70%) > proximal pole fracture (20%) > distal pole fracture (10%). 

    • Children: Distal pole avulsion type fracture.

  • Pathogenesis of AVN:

    • Most of the blood supply to the scaphoid enters distally, so blood supply of scaphoid diminishes proximally. 

    • This accounts for the fact that 1% of distal third, 20% of middle third, 40% of proximal third and 100% of proximal pole fractures result in avascular necrosis or non-union of the proximal fragment.

    • Thus, the proximal third of the scaphoid is most susceptible to avascular necrosis (AVN) due to its precarious retrograde blood supply. 

    • Fracture in the waist (middle third) can disrupt this blood flow to the proximal fragment, leading to AVN.

  • Diagnosis: 

    • A wrist sprain that is sufficiently severe to require radiographic examination initially should be treated as a possible fracture of the scaphoid, and radiographs should be repeated in 2 weeks even though initial radiographs may be negative.

    • Recent fracture shows only in the oblique view.

    • MRI can diagnose occult fractures.

    • MRI, especially with gadolinium enhancement, also is useful in assessing the vascularity of a fractured scaphoid.

  • Treatment:

    • Nondisplaced, Stable Scaphoid Fractures: Scaphoid Glass Holding Cast.

    • Displaced, Unstable Scaphoid Fractures: Headless Screw (Herbert) is used

    • Complication: Non-union > Avascular Necrosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Distal 1/3rd. Distal 1/3rd portion of the scaphoid is a well vascularized area, so fracture to this part is often undisplaced or minimally displaced, thus they heal faster with conservative management. This portion of scaphoid is fractured in 10% of cases. AVN of this part occurs in 1% cases. 

 

Option B. Middle 1/3rd. Middle 1/3rd or the waist of scaphoid is most commonly fractures, accounting for 70% of cases. But the chances of AVN at this portion are around 20%. 

 

Option D. Scaphoid tubercle. Avulsion fracture of scaphoid tubercle are rare. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The proximal 1/3rd portion of the scaphoid have less chances of fracture (20%) but have higher chances of AVN (40%).

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents to the OPD. She had itchy lesions on her arm as shown with a family history of asthma. What could be the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Atopic dermatitis

 

  • The image displays scratch marks and excoriations caused by pruritic lesions at a flexural site. The patient has a personal history of chronic and recurrent course, and there is also a family history of atopy, specifically asthma. These findings suggest a diagnosis of atopic dermatitis (AD) or atopic eczema (AE).

 

Atopic dermatitis (AD):

 

  • It is a chronic inflammatory condition that tends to persist or exhibit chronic relapses.
  • In infants, the first site of involvement is often the face.
  • Flexural distribution is observed in both the childhood and adult phases of the condition, while in the infantile phase, extensor distribution is more typical.

 

Atopic eczema can be divided into 3 phases:

 

  1. Infantile
  2. Childhood
  3. Adult

 

 

Atopic eczema infantile variant with face affected:

 

 

  • Atopic dermatitis typically presents with erythematous papules or papulovesicular lesions, often appearing in early childhood.
  • As the condition progresses, the lesions may evolve into excoriated and lichenified areas. Atopic dermatitis is commonly associated with secondary infections and skin dryness.
  • In the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis, the UK refinement of the Hanifin & Rajka criteria is employed.

 

UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (Eczema).

 

  • An itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child)
  • Plus, three or more of the following
    1. Onset below age 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
    2. History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
    3. History of a generally dry skin
    4. Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any atopic disease in a first degree relative in children under 4 years)
    5. Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/ forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

 

Clinical features of AD include:

 

  • Dennie-morgan fold under lower eyelid
  • Allergic shiners – periorbital pigmentation
  • Allergic salute – horizontal groove on dorsum of nasal bridge

 

 

Fig: Dennie-morgan fold

 

Complications of AD:

 

  • Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism to cause secondary infections in the lesions of atopic dermatitis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Seborrheic dermatitis:

 

  • This is a chronic condition that primarily affects sebum-rich areas of the body such as the scalp, face, and central chest.
  • It's characterized by yellowish, greasy scales and underlying erythema as shown in the image below.

 

 

 

  • While it can be itchy, its distribution and features are different from the description given.
  • There is no direct association between seborrheic dermatitis and a family history of asthma.

 

Option C. Allergic contact dermatitis:

  • This results from direct skin contact with allergens. It's an immunological response to a substance the individual has become sensitized to.
  • The lesions would be more correlated with contact to specific allergens, and it's not typically chronic or recurrent unless there is repeated exposure to the same allergen.
  • The distribution would be more in line with areas that contacted the allergen, rather than the typical flexural pattern described.

 

Option D. Erysipelas:

  • Erysipelas is an acute bacterial skin infection, typically caused by Group A Streptococcus.
  • It presents as a well-demarcated, raised, erythematous, and tender skin lesion, often accompanied by systemic symptoms like fever.
  • This condition is acute, not chronic or recurrent as described in the scenario.
  • There's no association with a family history of asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atopic dermatitis is a chronic, pruritic inflammatory skin disease commonly associated with flexural distribution of eczematous lesions and a family history of atopic conditions, such as asthma.

 

References:

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume 2 Chapter 41 page no 41.1, 41.2, 41.13-19

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume 3 Chapter 149 page no 149.21

Online resources:

https://www.jaad.org/article/S0190-9622(13)01095-5/fulltext

Question Level – Intermediate

choices.text: Leydig cells
Sertoli cells
Seminiferous tubules

questions.text: Testosterone production is mainly contributed by?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Leydig cell

 

Explanation

 

Testosterone production is mainly contributed by Leydig cells.

 

  • In puberty, the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis plays a major role in regulating testosterone levels and gonadal function.
  • The hypothalamus secretes GnRH, which travels down the hypothalamohypophyseal portal system to the anterior pituitary, which secretes luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).
  • LH and FSH are two gonadotropic hormones that travel through the blood and act on receptors in the gonads.
  • LH, in particular, acts on the Leydig cells to increase testosterone production. Testosterone limits its own secretion via negative feedback.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sertoli cells: Incorrect as Sertoli cells are primarily involved in the nourishment and support of developing spermatozoa, not in the production of testosterone.

 

Option C. Seminiferous tubules: Incorrect because while these structures within the testes are involved in sperm production, the cells directly responsible for testosterone production are the Leydig cells, not the tubules themselves.

 

Option D. Epididymis: Incorrect as the epididymis is involved in the storage, maturation, and transport of sperm cells, not hormone production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Testosterone production is mainly contributed by Leydig cells in the testes, which are specifically stimulated by luteinizing hormone (LH) from the anterior pituitary gland. This hormonal production is crucial for male reproductive and general health.

questions.text: Preservative commonly used for soft tissue preservation for histopathological examination is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Formalin

 

  • Chemical for preservation for histopathology samples: Formalin. But it is not used as preservative for Toxicological analysis because extraction of poison becomes difficult.
  • Chemicals used for Preservation of Viscera for Toxicological analysis: Anyone of the following two preservatives may be used:

 

1) Saturated solution of common salt (NaCl, i.e. sodium chloride):

 

  1. Most commonly used preservative (easily available & cheap)
  2. It is indicated in all poisoning cases except Corrosives

 

2) Rectified spirit:

 

  1. Best preservative
  2. Indicated for most of the poisons except alcohol, acetic acid, Chloral hydrate, Chloroform, formaldehyde, formic acid, kerosene, phosphorus, paraldehyde, Phenol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ethyl Alcohol: Not commonly used for histopathological tissue preservation due to its dehydration properties, which can alter tissue morphology.

 

Option C. Saturated Salt Solution: Commonly used as a preservative for toxicological analysis. It is easy to obtain and cost-effective. However, it is not suitable for preserving tissue for histopathology because it does not adequately preserve tissue morphology and detail.

 

Option D. Normal Saline: Primarily used for medical procedures and as a temporary transport medium. It does not provide the long-term preservation needed for histopathological examination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Formalin is the preservative of choice for soft tissue preservation for histopathological examination due to its ability to maintain tissue morphology and cellular details.

questions.text: Which nerve, after injury results in foot drop? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Common peroneal nerve

 

Common Peroneal Nerve (also known as Common Fibular Nerve) is the nerve primarily responsible for foot drop when injured.

 

  • Origin: The common peroneal nerve is a branch of the sciatic nerve, which splits into the tibial nerve and the common peroneal nerve near the apex of the popliteal fossa.
  • Function: It innervates the muscles of the anterior and lateral compartments of the leg, such as the tibialis anterior, which dorsiflexes the ankle. An injury to this nerve can result in the inability to dorsiflex the foot, leading to "foot drop."
  • Common injury sites: This nerve can be compromised at the fibular head where it is superficial, making it susceptible to injuries.      

 

 

Hence, injury to the common peroneal nerve will lead to:

 

  • Weakness of dorsiflexion of foot or foot drop
  • Loss of eversion
  • Loss of extension of toes
  • Sensory loss
    • Anterior and lateral side of the leg
    • Dorsum of the foot including the medial side of the great toe

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Femoral Nerve:

 

  • Origin: Arises from the lumbar plexus and is composed of fibers from the L2 to L4 nerve roots.
  • Function: Primarily innervates the anterior thigh muscles like the quadriceps, which are responsible for knee extension. It also provides sensation to the anterior thigh and medial leg.
  • If injured: A person may have difficulty in extending the knee and reduced sensation in the innervation area, but it will not cause foot drop.

 

Option C. Tibial Nerve:

 

  • Origin: Another branch of the sciatic nerve.
  • Function: It innervates the muscles of the posterior compartment of the leg, which are primarily responsible for plantarflexion of the ankle and flexion of the toes.
  • If injured: A person may have difficulty in plantarflexing the ankle or flexing the toes and may have a loss of sensation in the sole of the foot, but foot drop is not a symptom.

 

Option D. Sciatic Nerve:

 

  • Origin: The largest nerve in the body, originating from the sacral plexus with roots from L4 to S3.
  • Function: Innervates much of the posterior thigh, all of the leg except for a small medial area, and most of the foot.
  • If injured: Since the sciatic nerve gives rise to both the tibial and common peroneal nerves, injury can cause a range of motor and sensory deficits in the leg, depending on the injury's location. However, an injury specifically leading to foot drop would more directly implicate its common peroneal branch rather than the entire sciatic nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for diphtheria carrier state? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Erythromycin

 

The drug of choice for the carrier state of diphtheria is erythromycin.

 

  • Erythromycin is a macrolide antibiotic that is effective against the bacteria that cause diphtheria. It is used to eradicate the bacteria from carriers and prevent the spread of the disease.
  • Other antibiotics like amoxicillin, rifampicin, and tetracycline are not the first-line treatment for diphtheria carrier state.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythromycin is the drug of choice for the carrier state of diphtheria due to its effectiveness in eradicating Corynebacterium diphtheriae from carriers and preventing the spread of the disease. Other antibiotics like amoxicillin, rifampicin, and tetracycline are not considered first-line treatments for this condition.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used for induction of anesthesia in pediatric patients? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Desflurane

 

  • Desflurane is a highly pungent gas, and its use for inhalational induction can lead to airway irritation, coughing, breath-holding, and even laryngospasm, especially in pediatric patients.
  • Therefore, desflurane is not typically used as an induction agent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Halothane: Due to its pleasant odor and rapid onset, Halothane was historically a popular choice for inhalational induction in children. However, concerns regarding hepatotoxicity and arrhythmias have reduced its usage in modern practice.

 

Option B. Sevoflurane: Sevoflurane is one of the most commonly used agents for inhalational induction in pediatric patients due to its non-irritating nature and rapid kinetics.

 

Option D. Nitrous Oxide: Nitrous oxide is often used as an adjunct to other inhalational anesthetics for both induction and maintenance of anesthesia. It has a rapid onset and is generally well-tolerated by pediatric patients. It can be used for inhalational induction, especially in combination with more potent agents like sevoflurane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Desflurane is not typically used for the induction of anesthesia in pediatric patients due to its pungent nature, which can cause significant airway irritation and laryngospasm.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in the vertex presentation with complete flexion attitude of head? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Suboccipito-bregmatic diameter

 

Explanation:

 

Suboccipito-bregmatic diameter (9.5 cm) is seen in vertex presentation with a complete flexion attitude of the head.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Suboccipito-frontal diameter:

 

  • This diameter measures about 10.5 cm and is seen when the head is only partially flexed.
  • It is not the smallest diameter and is not optimal for vertex presentations with complete flexion.

 

Option C. Occipito-frontal diameter:

 

  • This diameter measures approximately 11.5 cm and is seen in cases where the head is in a neutral position, neither fully flexed nor extended.
  • It is larger and more difficult for the passage of the fetal head through the birth canal.

 

Option D. Occipito-posterior position:

 

  • This is not a diameter but a fetal position where the back of the fetal head is directed towards the mother's back.
