  • This position often leads to a more difficult labor and is associated with different presenting diameters, depending on the degree of head flexion or extension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The suboccipito-bregmatic diameter (9.5 cm) is seen in vertex presentation with complete flexion of the fetal head, facilitating easier passage through the birth canal.

 

Ref: Page no   92 Textbook of obstetrics by JB Sharma

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿C is more potent than A
﻿﻿﻿B is more potent than A

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the dose-response curve shown in the image below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) B is competitive antagonist

 

This questions tests the knowledge regarding two different things about dose response curve:

 

a. Potency and Efficacy: Remember, to take HELP whenever in doubt. It means Height of the curve tells about Efficacy (higher the curve, the more efficacious the drug is) and Left sidedness of the curve tells about Potency (Drugs with curves on left side are more potent than drugs with curve on right side)

 

b. Type of Inhibition: If the curve shifts parallelly to right, the drug is a competitive inhibitor, if it shifts down, the drug is a non-competitive inhibitor.

 

What is given in graph: 

 

  • The DRC of drug B has shifted to the right of the DRC of drug A , although the height of the two curves is the same. On the other hand, Drug C has shifted the curve down.
  • Further height of curve in Drug A and B is same but more than Drug C.
  • Curve of Drug A is on most left followed by Drug C and then Drug B.

 

Inferences:

 

Therefore, the following inferences can be drawn from the given image:

 

  • The efficacy of Drug A = Drug B > Drug C
  • The Potency of Drug A > Drug C > Drug B
  • Drug B is a competitive inhibitor of Drug A
  • Drug C is a non-competitive inhibitor of Drug A

 

Educational Objective:

 

Efficacy: The height of the curve represents the efficacy of the drug. The higher the curve, the more efficacious the drug.

 

Potency: The position of the curve along the x-axis (left or right) indicates the potency. Drugs with curves on the left side are more potent than those on the right side.

 

Type of Inhibition

 

  • Competitive Inhibition: A competitive inhibitor will shift the dose-response curve to the right without changing the maximum effect (efficacy). This indicates that higher concentrations of the agonist can overcome the inhibition.
  • Non-Competitive Inhibition: A non-competitive inhibitor will reduce the maximum effect (efficacy) of the agonist, causing a downward shift in the dose-response curve.

choices.text: Usually, terminates in awakening followed by confusion.
There may be neurological conditions associated.

questions.text: What is the false statement regarding somnambulism? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Person will have full consciousness.

 

Individuals who are sleepwalking typically act without conscious awareness and usually have no memory of the episode upon awakening.

 

Other Options:

 

Somnambulism, also known as sleepwalking, is a disorder of arousal from slow-wave sleep.

 

Option A. Disorder of sleep arousal: True. Sleepwalking arises from deep, non-REM (NREM) stage 4 sleep, making it a disorder of arousal.

 

Option C. Usually, terminates in awakening followed by confusion: True. When sleepwalkers are awakened, they are often disoriented and confused.

 

Option D. There may be neurological conditions associated: True. While many cases of somnambulism have no clear cause, certain neurological conditions can be associated with it.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sleepwalking (somnambulism) is an arousal disorder originating from deep, non-REM stage 4 sleep. Individuals who sleepwalk typically act without conscious awareness and have no memory of the episode upon awakening. The person who is having sleep walking is difficult to awake.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 555.

questions.text: The cross product ratio can be obtained by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Case control study

 

The cross-product ratio is a measure of association between two categorical variables, and it can be arrived at from a case-control study.

 

In a case-control study, the odds ratio (OR) is often used as a measure of association between the exposure and the outcome. The cross-product ratio is an alternative measure of association that can be derived from the odds ratio.

 

Interpretation

 

OR> 1 → Association Present

OR =1 → No Association

OR< 1 → Inverse/Negative Association → RF is protective(beneficial)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ecological study: This type of study examines the associations between exposure and outcomes at the population or group level, not at the individual level, and does not typically use the cross-product ratio.

 

Option B. Cohort study: This type of study follows a group of exposed and non-exposed individuals over time to observe the incidence of outcomes. It uses relative risk rather than the cross-product ratio.

 

Option C. Cross-sectional study: This study observes a population at a single point in time, assessing both exposure and outcome simultaneously. It can measure prevalence but not the cross-product ratio specifically.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cross-product ratio, or odds ratio, is a measure of association commonly derived from case-control studies to determine the relationship between exposure and outcome.

questions.text: A 35-year-old farmer is bitten by a scorpion. Which of the following acts as a physiological antidote to scorpion venom? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prazosin

 

Antidote for scorpion venom: Prazosin acts as a physiological antidote for scorpion venom.

 

Effects of scorpion venom: hemolytic and neurotoxic

 

Symptoms of scorpion venom

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Physostigmine: A cholinesterase inhibitor used to treat anticholinergic toxicity. It is not effective against scorpion venom.

 

Option B. Norepinephrine: A vasopressor used to treat severe hypotension. It is not suitable as an antidote for scorpion venom, which can cause hypertension and other systemic effects.

 

Option D. Atropine: An anticholinergic drug used to treat bradycardia and certain types of poisonings. It is not effective against scorpion venom.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prazosin acts as a physiological antidote for scorpion venom by counteracting the severe cardiovascular and systemic effects induced by the venom.

questions.text: Identify the size of the given blade used for incision and drainage of a superficial abscess and arteriotomy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 11

 

The blade shown in the image is number 11 blade used for skin incisions (E.g., Incision and Drainage) and Arteriotomy

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

11 number blade is used In stab incisions needed when lancing an abscess or inserting a chest drain and in skin incisions and arteriotomy

choices.text: It’s administered on the anterolateral aspect of thigh
A prior adverse reaction with temperature above 37 degrees is a contraindication
Cellular pertussis component in the vaccine is not recommended after 7-years of age
The diphtheria toxoid dose in adults is much lesser than the pediatric dose

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy experienced symptoms of a sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and a slight fever. Upon examination, the presented clinical image is visible. Which of the following sentences is false regarding the vaccine that could have prevented this condition? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A prior adverse reaction with temperature above 37 degrees is a contraindication

 

A prior adverse reaction with temperature above 37 degrees is a contraindication: This is false. A prior adverse reaction with a temperature above 40 degrees Celsius is a contraindication, not 37 degrees Celsius. Minor reactions, such as a mild fever, are not typically considered a contraindication for future vaccinations.

 

Other Options:  

 

Option A.  It’s administered on the anterolateral aspect of thigh: This is true. The DPT vaccine is typically administered intramuscularly on the anterolateral aspect of the thigh in infants and young children.

 

Option C. Cellular pertussis component in the vaccine is not recommended after 7-years of age: This is true. The whole-cell pertussis vaccine is generally not recommended for individuals over the age of 7 due to an increased risk of adverse reactions. Instead, the acellular pertussis vaccine is used in older children and adults.

 

Option D. The diphtheria toxoid dose in adults is much lesser than the pediatric dose: This is true. The diphtheria toxoid dose in adults is lower than in pediatric formulations to reduce the risk of adverse reactions while still providing adequate immunity.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Functional residual capacity
Inspiratory capacity

questions.text: Which of the following decreases in pregnancy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Functional residual capacity

 

Explanation:

 

Functional residual capacity (FRC) is the volume of air remaining in the lungs at the end of a normal expiration. During pregnancy, the diaphragm is elevated due to the enlarging uterus, leading to a decrease in FRC by approximately 22%. This is primarily due to reductions in expiratory reserve volume and residual volume.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory rate: The respiratory rate typically remains unchanged during pregnancy, staying at about 14-16 breaths per minute.

 

Option B. Vital capacity: Vital capacity, which is the sum of inspiratory reserve volume, tidal volume, and expiratory reserve volume, remains unchanged during pregnancy.

 

Option D. Inspiratory capacity: Inspiratory capacity increases during pregnancy by about 10%. This increase is due to the higher tidal volume and inspiratory reserve volume.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functional residual capacity decreases during pregnancy due to the elevation of the diaphragm caused by the enlarging uterus.

 

  • Functional residual capacity decreases in pregnancy.

 

 

Ref: Page no 189, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: What is the best imaging study for diagnosis of cerebral infarct?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diffuse weighted MRI

 

Explanation:

 

Diffusion-weighted MRI is the most sensitive investigation for diagnosis of cerebral ischemia.  It is particularly useful for identifying acute ischemic changes in the brain due to its ability to detect diffusion restriction of water molecules in the brain tissue.

 

 

Diffusion restriction: hyperintense on DWI and hypointense on ADC.

 

  • Diffusion restriction is seen with:
    1. Acute stroke
    2. Hypercellular tumors
    3. Abscess
    4. Epidermoid cyst
    5. Keratin-Craniopharyngioma/ Cholesteatoma

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FLAIR MRI: Fluid-Attenuated Inversion Recovery (FLAIR) MRI is useful for identifying older infarcts and chronic changes but is less sensitive in the acute phase of a stroke.

 

Option B. Non-contrast CT: While commonly used for initial assessment due to its availability and speed, it is less sensitive in the early stages of a stroke, often not showing changes until several hours post-onset.

 

Option D. СECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT): Typically used to assess for complications or other causes of symptoms but not as sensitive as DWI for early detection of cerebral infarcts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diffusion-weighted MRI is the optimal choice for early detection of cerebral infarcts, making it an indispensable tool in acute stroke management. Its ability to show diffusion restriction provides critical information that can influence therapeutic decisions.

questions.text: The following appearance in IVP is caused by:(NEET PG  2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ureterocele

 

Explanation:

 

  • The IVP shows bilateral cobra head or adder head sign/ cobra head appearance. It describes the cystic dilation of the distal end of ureter.
  • It may be simple (like in this case where it is located at the VUJ) or may be ectopic in location.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Horse shoe kidney: Characterized by a "hand-shake" or "flower vase" sign due to the fusion of the kidneys across the midline, typically seen in the lower lumbar region. This appearance does not match the image shown.

 

 

Option C. Retroperitoneal fibrosis: Often causes medial deviation of the ureters or a "silent kidney" if severe obstruction occurs. Not relevant to the observed sign.

 

 

Option D. Posterior urethral valve: Affects male infants primarily and involves obstruction within the posterior urethra, leading to bladder and kidney changes. It does not cause the "cobra head" appearance seen here.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ureterocele should be suspected when an IVP reveals a "cobra head" sign, representing cystic dilation of the distal ureter. This condition can affect urinary drainage and lead to complications, requiring timely diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with end-stage renal disease is scheduled to receive a kidney transplant from his son who is a compatible donor. What is this type of transplant known as?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Allograft

 

Explanation:

 

An allograft is a transplantation of tissue or an organ from one individual to another of the same species but with different genetic makeup. In this scenario, the kidney transplant from a son to his father is an example of an allograft because they are both human but genetically different individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autograft: An autograft is a transplantation of tissue from one part of the body to another part of the same individual. Examples include skin grafts taken from one area of the body to treat burns in another area.

 

Option C. Xenograft: A xenograft involves the transplantation of tissue or organs from one species to another. This type of transplant is not common in clinical practice due to the high risk of immune rejection and other complications. An example would be a pig heart valve transplanted into a human.

 

Option D. Isograft: An isograft is a transplantation of tissue or organs between two genetically identical individuals, such as identical twins. This type of transplant is also known as a syngeneic transplant and has the advantage of minimal risk of immune rejection due to the genetic identity between the donor and the recipient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A kidney transplant from a son to his father is classified as an allograft because it involves the transfer of an organ between two genetically different individuals of the same species.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs causes activation of K+ channels? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nicorandil

 

Nicorandil is a drug that causes the activation of K+ channels. It is unique among the options listed because it acts as both a potassium channel opener and has nitrate-like effects, which contribute to its vasodilatory properties. By opening potassium channels, nicorandil causes hyperpolarization of the vascular smooth muscle cells, leading to relaxation and vasodilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Molsidomine: Molsidomine is a nitric oxide donor that works by activating guanylate cyclase, increasing cyclic GMP (cGMP) levels, and causing vasodilation. It does not activate K+ channels.

 

Option C. Isosorbide dinitrate: Isosorbide dinitrate is also a nitric oxide donor that acts by increasing cGMP levels through the activation of guanylate cyclase, leading to vasodilation.

 

Option D. Nitroglycerin: Nitroglycerin is another nitric oxide donor that causes vasodilation by increasing cGMP levels through the activation of guanylate cyclase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nicorandil is the drug that causes activation of K+ channels, leading to hyperpolarization and vasodilation. It also has nitrate-like effects, distinguishing it from other nitric oxide donors like molsidomine, isosorbide dinitrate, and nitroglycerin, which do not activate K+ channels but work by increasing cGMP levels.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of revised trauma score (RTS)?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pulse rate

 

Pulse rate is NOT a part of revised trauma score.

 

The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) is a scoring system used to evaluate the severity of traumatic injuries in patients.

 

It takes into account the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), systolic blood pressure, and respiratory rate to calculate a score that can predict the likelihood of survival.

 

The score range is 0-12.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glasgow Coma Scale: The GCS is included in the RTS and evaluates the patient's level of consciousness based on eye, verbal, and motor responses.

 

Option B. Systolic Blood Pressure: SBP is included in the RTS and measures the pressure in the arteries when the heart beats.

 

Option D. Respiratory Rate: RR is included in the RTS and measures the number of breaths per minute.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) includes the Glasgow Coma Scale, systolic blood pressure, and respiratory rate, but does not include pulse rate.

choices.text: Physiological hernia failing to go back

questions.text: What is the basis for the formation of omphalocele?( NEET PG 2019 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Physiological hernia failing to go back

 

  • Omphalocele is characterized by the herniation of abdominal viscera through an enlarged umbilical ring.
  • Amnion protects the viscera, which may include the liver, small and large intestines, stomach, spleen, or gallbladder.
  • The defect is caused by the bowel's failure to return to the body cavity after its physiological herniation between the sixth and tenth weeks.

 

 

Omphalocele is associated with other congenital anomalies (e.g., trisomy 13, trisomy 18, or Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome) and with increased levels of alpha-fetoprotein (AFP).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excessive length of the intestine: During early embryonic development, the intestines do grow at a rapid pace, leading to temporary herniation of the midgut into the umbilical cord around the 6th week. This is called physiological midgut herniation. The intestines then rotate and usually return into the abdominal cavity by the 10th week. It's not the excessive length of the intestine itself that causes omphalocele; rather, it's the failure of the intestines (and sometimes other organs) to return to the abdominal cavity.

 

Option C. Herniation of liver: While the liver can indeed be one of the organs present in an omphalocele, its herniation is not the primary cause of omphalocele. Instead, it is a consequence of the failure of the physiological hernia to return to the abdominal cavity. In larger omphaloceles, the liver is more commonly seen as part of the herniated content.

 

Option D. Herniation of umbilicus: This option is not precise. The umbilicus itself is not what herniates in omphalocele. Instead, it's through the region of the umbilicus that the intestines and possibly other organs herniate out into the umbilical cord during development. If they fail to return to the abdomen, an omphalocele forms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omphalocele is primarily caused by the failure of the physiological hernia of the midgut to return to the abdominal cavity during fetal development, not merely by the excessive length of the intestine or specific organ herniation.

choices.text: Endometrial hyperplasia

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with a lower abdominal mass and lower abdominal discomfort. On examination, the uterus appears uniformly enlarged and adnexa is free. MRI shows the presence of a myometrial cyst. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenomyosis

 

Explanation:

 

  • Adenomyosis is the presence of endometrial tissue in the myometrium. The uterus is generally uniformly enlarged up to 12-14 weeks size and can be tender on examination.
  • Investigation of choice: Ultrasound
  • On ultrasound, the following can be seen in adenomyosis:

 

 

  • Management of adenomyosis
    • Medical management: For symptomatic relief
    • Total Hysterectomy (Definitive treatment - Treatment of choice if family is complete)

 

Other options

 

Option A. Endometriosis: This presents as 5Ds (Dysmenorrhoea, Dyspareunia, Dyschezia, Dysfertility and Dull-aching abdominal pain). Diagnostic modality of choice is laparoscopy. Myometrial cysts are not seen. Endometriotic (chocolate) cysts in the ovary may be seen.

 

Option C. Leiomyoma: Fibroids or leiomyomas usually present with menorrhagia and dysmenorrhoea. If very large, they will present with abdominal mass and pelvic pressure. On ultrasound, depending on the location, well circumscribed rounded lesions are seen.

 

Option D. Endometrial hyperplasia: This will present as menorrhagia. On ultrasound the endometrium will be thickened.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenomyosis is characterized by a uniformly enlarged uterus with myometrial cysts, diagnosed primarily via ultrasound.

 

Ref: Page no 196, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: 1st pharyngeal arch gives rise to all except:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Levator veli palatini

 

Levator veli palatini: The muscle responsible for elevating the soft palate, playing an essential role in swallowing. It prevents food and liquids from entering the nasopharynx during swallowing. This muscle is not derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch but from the 4th pharyngeal arch. It is innervated by the pharyngeal plexus, with contributions primarily from the vagus nerve (CN X).

 

First pharyngeal arch gives rise to:

 

  • Muscles of mastication (temporalis, masseter, lateral and medial pterygoids)
  • Mylohyoid
  • Anterior belly of digastric
  • Tensor tympani
  • Tensor velipalatini and
  • Anterior 2/3 of tongue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial pterygoids: It is one of the muscles of mastication which assists in elevating the mandible and plays a role in the side-to-side movement of the jaw. It originates from the medial pterygoid plate of the sphenoid bone and the pyramidal process of the palatine bone and inserts into the medial surface of the mandible. The medial pterygoid is derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch and is innervated by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve.

 

Option C. Lateral pterygoids: Like the medial pterygoid, it is also a muscle of mastication which depresses the mandible and side-to-side jaw movements. The muscle has two heads, superior and inferior, and it inserts into the neck of the mandible and the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint. Derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch, it is innervated by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve.

 

Option D. Tensor veli palatini: It is responsible for tensing the soft palate and assists in opening the auditory (Eustachian) tube, equalizing the pressure between the middle ear and the nasopharynx. This muscle is derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch and is unique among the palatal muscles because it is innervated by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Most common joint involved in septic arthritis is:  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Knee

 

SEPTIC (PYOGENIC) ARTHRITIS

 

  • Refers to Infection of Joint.
  • Septic arthritis word is a misnomer as initially, there is only infection of joint and if not treated early then, Arthritis develops. Thus, all sepsis of joints do not cause arthritis, only inadequately treated ones do.
  • Etiology and pathology:
    • Hematogenous route of infection is most common in all age groups
    • Most common organism: Staphylococcus aureus.
       
  • Diagnosis:
    • X-rays are usually normal or may indicate soft tissue swelling.
    • MRI may show effusion, synovitis or cartilage destruction.
    • Aspiration of joint fluid helps to confirm the diagnosis by culture and also helps to differentiate from transient synovitis.
    • Order of investigations done: X-ray followed by MRI, then Aspiration.
    • Culture of the aspirate is the gold standard for diagnosis.
       
  • Septic arthritis with negative cultures: Diagnostic Criterion (Morrey and associates criterion) – 5 out of 6 must be present
    1. > 38.3°C temperature
    2. Swelling of suspected joint
    3. Pain in joint that increases with movement
    4. Systemic symptoms
    5. No other pathologic process
    6. Satisfactory response to antibiotics therapy
       
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Absent movements of a joint after ruling out trauma in pediatric population is septic arthritis until proven otherwise.
    • Knee: Most commonly affected joint; position is flexion
    • Hip: Position is flexion, abduction and external rotation.
       
  • Treatment:
    • Arthrotomy (opening the joint capsule), surgical drainage (decompression), synovectomy and antibiotics (2 weeks IV and 4 weeks oral).
    • Non-operative treatment is not considered as cartilage destruction occurs very rapidly and can cause permanent joint destruction.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Hip. Infections that can affect the hip are primarily either an infection of the bone i.e., osteomyelitis, or an infection of the joint i.e., septic arthritis. 

 

Option C. Shoulder. Infection of the shoulder joint is rare. It may occur after total shoulder replacement. The most common bacteria responsible for the infection are Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus epidermidis, and Propionibacterium acnes.

 

Option D. Elbow. Elbow joint infection may occur due to infected or septic arthritis, septic joint, infection after elbow surgery or after elbow replacement, bursal infection, soft tissue infection or cellulitis. 

 

Educational objective:

 

The most common joint involved in septic arthritis is the knee joint, followed by the hip joint.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases have autosomal recessive inheritance? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Albinism

 

Albinism is typically inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. To have albinism, an individual must inherit two copies of the mutated gene for albinism, one from each parent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. G-6-PD deficiency: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G-6-PD) deficiency is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner, not autosomal recessive. It affects males more often than females.

 

Option C. Marfan's syndrome: Marfan's syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, not autosomal recessive. A single copy of the mutated gene from one parent is enough to cause the condition.

 

Option D. Lesch-Nyhan syndrome: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner. It primarily affects males who inherit the mutated gene from their carrier mothers.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Anterior nerve roots are more commonly involved
Mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved
Trigeminal dermatome is most commonly affected

questions.text: What is correct regarding the diagnosis based on the given image?  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved

 

The above image shows confluent, red, pustular lesions in a single dermatome suggestive of herpes zoster or shingles. The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.

 

Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia (NOT Anterior nerve roots) for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution as shown in the image below.

 

 

 

Herpes zoster:

 

  • Thoracic dermatome is most commonly affected (NOT Trigeminal).
  • The rash is restricted to a dermatome, but sometimes a few chickenpox‐type lesions can be found elsewhere. The lesions are infectious
  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  1. Painful zoster infections in adults
  2. Facial zoster at any age
  3. Immunocompromised

 

The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior nerve roots are more commonly involved: False. In herpes zoster, it is the dorsal (posterior) nerve roots and ganglia that are predominantly involved, not the anterior nerve roots. The virus remains latent in the dorsal root ganglia and reactivates there, leading to symptoms in the corresponding dermatomal distribution.

 

Option C. The lesions are not infectious: False. The lesions of herpes zoster are highly infectious, particularly when the blisters are open and the fluid is accessible. The virus contained in these lesions can infect individuals who have not previously had chickenpox or the vaccine, leading to varicella (chickenpox).

 

Option D. Trigeminal dermatome is most commonly affected: False. While the trigeminal dermatome can be significantly affected (especially concerning due to the risk of herpes zoster ophthalmicus if the ophthalmic branch is involved), it is not the most commonly affected dermatome. The thoracic dermatomes are more frequently involved in herpes zoster cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Herpes zoster, commonly involves reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus within the dorsal root ganglion, leading to painful cutaneous eruptions that can affect mucous membranes within the involved dermatomes.
  • Herpes zoster lesions are infectious, particularly to those who are not immune to varicella-zoster virus, and thoracic dermatome is the most frequently affected area.

 

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no. 25.27-25.28

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 4.13

questions.text: Boundaries of Calot triangle are formed by all except? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Gall bladder

 

The gallbladder itself does not form a boundary of Calot's triangle. Instead, it's closely related to the triangle, being situated just adjacent to it.

 

It's an important landmark in cholecystectomy (surgical removal of the gallbladder) because of the structures that it contains. The identification of this triangle helps to prevent injury to the common bile duct during surgery.

 

  • Boundaries of Calot's triangle is bounded:
    • Medially/Left side - Common hepatic duct
    • Right side/ Laterally   Cystic duct
    • Superior - lower surface of liver
    • Contents of calot’s triangle - Cystic artery and lymph node of lund 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Common hepatic duct: This forms the inferior boundary of Calot's triangle. The common hepatic duct is the duct formed by the joining of the left and right hepatic ducts. It later joins the cystic duct to form the common bile duct.

 

Option B. Cystic duct: This duct connects the gallbladder to the common hepatic duct and subsequently forms the common bile duct. The cystic duct forms the lateral boundary of Calot's triangle.

 

Option C. Cystic artery: Inferior surface of liver forms the superior boundary of calot’s triangle

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatocystic triangle and triangle of Calot - Hepatocystic triangle (blue): Upper boundary of hepatocystic triangle is the inferior border of liver. Lateral, the cystic duct and the neck of the gallbladder. Medial, the common hepatic duct.

choices.text: Crocein Scarlet MOO and Solvent Yellow 3

questions.text: Bindi Leukoderma is caused by which chemical? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Para Tertiary butylphenol (PTBP)

 

Bindi leukoderma is caused by para tertiary butylphenol (PTBP) present in adhesive sticker Bindi.

 

  • This is called contact leukoderma or chemical leukoderma in which the chemical increases sensitivity and induces apoptosis of the melanocytes in the area of contact.
  • There is also evidence that azo dyes, by virtue of structural similarity to tyrosine, can directly inhibit methanogenesis by competing with that amino acid for binding with tyrosinase enzyme.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. p-phenylenediamine (PPD): Commonly found in hair dyes and can cause allergic reactions and leukoderma but is not the cause of Bindi leukoderma.

 

Option C. Mono-benzyl ether of Hydroquinone (MBEH): Used in rubber and other synthetic materials to cause depigmentation but not in bindi adhesives.

 

Option D. Crocein Scarlet MOO and Solvent Yellow 3: Azo dyes used in Alta dye, associated with chemical leukoderma but not specifically with bindi leukoderma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Para Tertiary butylphenol (PTBP), which is a chemical present in high concentrations in the glue of sticker bindis and is known to cause leukoderma through its melanocytotoxic properties.

 

Common chemicals in Indian setup which can Cause chemical leukoderma are:

 

 

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 128 page no 128.74

Online source: https://europepmc.org/article/pmc/2965911

Question Level – Intermediate 

Question Id-7458 Unique Key-Q8927704

questions.text: In Menke's disease, which of the following enzymes would be affected?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lysyl oxidase

 

Lysyl oxidase is the enzyme affected in Menkes disease. Menkes disease is a genetic disorder that impairs copper absorption and transport, leading to a deficiency of copper-dependent enzymes like lysyl oxidase. Lysyl oxidase is crucial for the cross-linking of collagen and elastin fibers in connective tissues, and its deficiency results in connective tissue abnormalities seen in Menkes disease.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lysyl hydroxylase: Lysyl hydroxylase is not directly affected by Menkes disease. Lysyl hydroxylase is involved in the post-translational modification of collagen, and its dysfunction can lead to certain types of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, not Menkes disease.

 

Option C. Prolyl oxidase: Prolyl oxidase is not directly associated with Menkes disease. It is involved in the formation of collagen cross-links but is not specifically affected in this condition.

 

Option D. Prolyl hydroxylase: Prolyl hydroxylase is not the enzyme affected by Menkes disease. It plays a role in collagen synthesis, but its deficiency is not a characteristic feature of Menkes disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Menke’s kinky hair syndrome is an x-linked defect (affects only male child). It is a condition in which dietary copper is absorbed from GI tract; but cannot be transported to blood due to absence of an intracellular copper binding ATPase (mutation in ATP7A gene).

 

Copper is not mobilized from intestinal cells as well as in other tissue cells. The copper that has entered into the cell is not able to get out of the cells, and so it is accumulated. Hence, copper is not available for metabolism, resulting in defective cross-linking of connective tissue. Vascular and connective tissues are affected, and child dies usually in infancy. Deficiency of copper results in defective function of lysyl oxidase.

questions.text: An 18-year-old female presents with severe headache and high fever of 101°F. On examination, papilloedema and nuchal rigidity was present. Gram staining of the CSF is shown below. What is the Causative organism? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neisseria meningitidis

 

The clinical presentation of severe headache, high fever, papilloedema, and nuchal rigidity, combined with the Gram stain results, is highly indicative of meningococcal meningitis, caused by Neisseria meningitidis. The image from the Gram staining of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) showing intracellular gram-negative diplococci supports this diagnosis. Neisseria meningitidis is known for appearing as gram-negative diplococci, often resembling kidney beans, and typically found within white blood cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Haemophilus influenzae type B is a gram-negative bacillus. In CSF, long bacillary filamentous forms predominate.

 

 

Option C. Streptococcus pneumonia is a gram positive, capsulated, flame shaped or lanceolate shaped diplococci.

 

 

Option D. Listeria monocytogenes is a gram positive bacillus and typically presents with tumbling motility in liquid media, not as diplococci.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria meningitidis - Intracellular gram-negative diplococci in gram staining.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best level of prevention of breast cancer? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Early diagnosis and treatment

 

Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial in the management of breast cancer. This involves screening methods such as mammography, which can detect cancer at an early stage when it is more likely to be treated successfully. Early treatment can significantly improve survival rates and outcomes for patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Specific protection: Specific protection involves preventive measures that protect against specific diseases, such as vaccinations or using protective equipment. Currently, there is no vaccine or specific protective measure that can prevent breast cancer.

 

Option C. Disability limitation: Disability limitation is part of tertiary prevention and focuses on minimizing the impact of an ongoing illness that has already caused some level of disability. It involves strategies to prevent complications and further disability. This is more applicable after a disease has been diagnosed and is not the best level of prevention for breast cancer.

 

Option D. Rehabilitation: Rehabilitation is also a part of tertiary prevention and aims to help individuals recover as much function as possible after a disease has caused disability. It includes therapies to restore physical, psychological, and social functioning. While important, it is not the best preventive strategy for breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early diagnosis and treatment (secondary prevention) are the most effective methods for preventing the progression of breast cancer, as they allow for early detection and intervention, significantly improving the chances of successful treatment and reducing mortality rates.

questions.text: Identify the instrument:  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Maddox rod

 

The above instrument is a Maddox rod.

 

A Maddox rod is a specially constructed device, consisting of a series of parallel cylinders, that converts a point source of light into a line image. It can be used to test for horizontal and vertical deviations, and when used in conjunction with another Maddox rod, for cyclo deviations.

 

Maddox Rod Test

 

Patient is asked to fix on a point light in the centre of Maddox tangent scale at a distance of 6 metres. A Maddox rod (which consists of many glass rods of red colour set together in a metallic disc) is placed in front of one eye with axis of the rod parallel to the axis of deviation.

 

 

 

Due to dissimilar images of the two eyes, fusion is broken and heterophoria becomes manifest. The number on the Maddox tangent scale where the red line falls will be the amount of heterophoria in degrees.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maddox wing: An instrument used to measure the horizontal and vertical deviations at near using a different mechanism involving a scale and moving wings.

 

Option B. Maddox glass: This term is not commonly used; it might refer to the Maddox rod or Maddox wing.

 

Option D. Phoropter: An instrument used in refraction testing to determine eyeglass prescriptions, consisting of multiple lenses that can be rotated into place to assess visual acuity and lens power.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Maddox rod is an instrument consisting of parallel cylindrical lenses used to convert a point light source into a line image, aiding in the diagnosis of horizontal, vertical, and cyclo deviations in ocular alignment.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with progressive blurred vision, photophobia, and eye pain. On examination, there was conjunctival redness, a mid-dilated pupil, and a shallow anterior chamber in the right eye. He has been treated both medically and surgically for the condition but showed no improvement. The following procedure incorporates a device to aid drainage. Identify the device.  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ex-Press™ implant

 

The clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of glaucoma not responsive to medical treatment and trabeculectomy and the device used is Ex-Press™ glaucoma implant (mini shunt).

 

It is a minimally invasive glaucoma surgery (MIGS) to increase aqueous drainage.

  • A tiny stainless-steel implant called Ex-PRESS is used to treat glaucoma.
  • It is implanted during a modified trabeculectomy underneath a scleral flap.
  • Hypotony-related complications are less common than with conventional trabeculectomy.
  • By creating a communication between the anterior chamber and the sub-space/sub-conjunctival Tennon's space, glaucoma drainage devices enable aqueous outflow.
  • While formerly only used in high-risk patients or after a failed trabulectomy, these devices are gaining popularity.
  • The commonly used devices are as follows:
    • ﻿﻿Shunts using episcleral explants
    • ﻿﻿Ahmed glaucoma valve- Silicone
    • ﻿﻿Molteno implant- Polypropelene plate and silicone plate
    • ﻿﻿Baerveldt implant- Silicone
    • ﻿﻿Mini-shunts
    • ﻿﻿Ex-Press™M Mini-Shunt- Stainless steel
    • ﻿﻿iStent®- Titanium

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ahmed Glaucoma Valve:

  • Made of silicone.
  • Contains a valve mechanism to prevent hypotony.
  • Popular for its ease of implantation and reliable outcomes.
  • Used in cases requiring controlled aqueous humor outflow but differs in design and function from the Ex-Press™ implant

 

Option C. Molteno Implant:

  • Made of polypropylene plate and silicone plate.
  • One of the earliest glaucoma drainage devices, offering various plate sizes.

 

Option D. Baerveldt Implant:

  • Made of silicone.
  • Designed to provide large surface area for filtration.
  • Requires ligation to prevent early postoperative hypotony.
  • Also used for glaucoma management

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ex-Press™ glaucoma implant is a minimally invasive device used during modified trabeculectomy to enhance aqueous drainage and reduce intraocular pressure in patients with glaucoma. This implant is characterized by its stainless-steel construction and effectiveness in controlling glaucoma with fewer hypotony-related complications.

questions.text: What is the first line of treatment of mastitis in a lactating mother? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dicloxacillin

 

Explanation:

 

Beta-lactamase-resistant penicillins are recommended in the treatment of mastitis. These include cloxacillin, dicloxacillin, or flucloxacillin. Erythromycin is given to women who are penicillin-sensitive. Dicloxacillin is often the first choice due to its effectiveness against the common causative organism, Staphylococcus aureus.

 

Puerperal Mastitis:

 

  • Definition: Mastitis is an inflammatory condition of the breast that may occur in breastfeeding women during the puerperium.
  • Pathogenesis: Infants are inoculated by personnel carrying S. aureus and transmit the bacteria to the breastfeeding mother through the nasopharynx.
  • Risk Factors:
    • Maternal age > 30 years
    • Maternal fatigue and stress
    • Sores and cracked nipples
    • History of mastitis after a previous pregnancy
    • Breast engorgement, blocked lactiferous ducts, and milk stasis
  • Etiology:
    • Most cases of mastitis result from infection with S. aureus.
    • Other organisms include coagulase-negative staphylococci, β-hemolytic streptococci, Streptococcus faecalis, Escherichia coli, and other bacteria such as Enterobacter cloacae, Pseudomonas picetti, and Haemophilus influenzae.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Maternal fever (100.4°F or higher)
    • Chills, myalgia, malaise
    • Breast tenderness with associated erythema, usually unilateral
    • Segmental erythema on the breast, typically in the upper, outer quadrant, with variable degrees of induration
    • Palpable, fluctuant mass suggesting a breast abscess should prompt immediate breast ultrasound
    • Milk may be expressed for leukocyte and bacterial counts, though this is not recommended for diagnosing uncomplicated mastitis
  • Treatment:
    • Antibiotics: Dicloxacillin, amoxicillin, or nafcillin, or a first-generation cephalosporin
    • Penicillin Allergy: Erythromycin or vancomycin
    • Duration: Antibiotic therapy should be continued for 10 to 14 days to avoid resistant organisms
    • Breastfeeding: Women should continue breastfeeding, initiating feeds on the unaffected breast and changing the infant's position at different feeds to prevent the development of a breast abscess
    • Symptomatic Relief: Analgesics like ibuprofen or acetaminophen, increased fluid intake, adequate nutrition, cold or warm compresses, and breast support should be provided

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cefazolin: While cefazolin is a cephalosporin and can be effective, it is not the first-line treatment compared to dicloxacillin for mastitis.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is typically used for more severe infections and is not the first-line treatment for mastitis.

 

Option D. Ampicillin: Ampicillin may be used but is not as effective as dicloxacillin for treating Staphylococcus aureus infections in mastitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dicloxacillin is the first-line treatment for mastitis in lactating mothers, especially effective against Staphylococcus aureus.

 

Ref: https://www.glowm.com/section-view/heading/Puerperal%20Mastitis/item/142

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Gestational hypertension

questions.text: A baby was born at 34 weeks of pregnancy; the appearance of the baby is given below. What is the mother suffering from? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gestational diabetes

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a large for gestational age (LGA) fetus. Macrosomia is a condition where a newborn baby is significantly larger than average. This can often be identified by a higher birth weight and size compared to typical babies born at the same gestational age.

 

Causes of Macrosomia:

 

  1. Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM) and Overt Diabetes Mellitus:
    • Maternal hyperglycemia leads to fetal hyperglycemia, which stimulates insulin production in the fetus. Insulin acts as a growth hormone, leading to increased fetal growth and fat deposition.
  2. Maternal Obesity:
    • Increased maternal body mass index (BMI) is associated with a higher risk of delivering a macrosomic baby.
  3. Previous Baby with Macrosomia:
    • A history of delivering a large baby increases the risk of subsequent babies also being large.
  4. Post-term Pregnancy:
    • Pregnancy extending beyond the due date increases the chance of the baby growing larger.
  5. Excessive Weight Gain in Pregnancy:
    • Significant maternal weight gain during pregnancy contributes to larger fetal size.

 

Conditions Not Associated with Macrosomia:

 

  • Anemia and Antepartum Hemorrhage (APH): These conditions are typically associated with fetal growth restriction rather than macrosomia.
  • Thrombocytopenia: This condition has no direct association with fetal weight.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Rubella: Rubella infection during pregnancy can cause congenital rubella syndrome, which is typically associated with intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), not macrosomia.

 

Option C. Hypothyroidism: Maternal hypothyroidism can lead to complications such as preterm birth and low birth weight but is not directly linked to macrosomia.

 

Option D. Gestational Hypertension: Gestational hypertension is associated with IUGR and preterm birth rather than increased fetal size.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gestational diabetes is a significant risk factor for macrosomia, leading to the birth of large for gestational age (LGA) babies.

 

Ref: Page no 2169, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected

questions.text: A female patient presents to the clinic with a painful lump in her breast that has been increasing in size over the past few days. After examination, the doctor diagnoses her with a breast abscess and prescribes antibiotics to help clear the infection. The doctor attempts to aspirate the abscess using a needle and syringe, but no fluid is obtained. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A second attempt at aspiration

 

Explanation:

 

If the first attempt at aspiration fails to obtain fluid, the next logical step is to attempt aspiration again, potentially with ultrasound guidance. Ultrasound guidance can enhance the accuracy of the procedure by allowing direct visualization of the abscess, ensuring that the needle is correctly positioned to access the abscess cavity. This method is less invasive than incision and drainage (I&D), making it a preferred option if it can effectively manage the abscess.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incision and Drainage: Incision and drainage is generally considered if aspiration fails repeatedly or if the abscess is too large. While effective, it is not typically the immediate next step after a single failed aspiration attempt. It is more invasive than aspiration and usually reserved for cases where less invasive methods are unsuccessful.

 

Option B. Continue antibiotics only: Antibiotics are crucial in managing breast abscesses by treating the underlying infection. However, they alone might not suffice for large or dense abscesses. The pus trapped within the abscess often needs to be physically removed to expedite healing and provide symptom relief. Continuing antibiotics without addressing the abscess can lead to prolonged infection and discomfort.

 

Option D. Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected: This option is not recommended. The failure to collect aspirate does not imply the absence of infection. The antibiotics were prescribed based on the clinical diagnosis of a breast abscess, and stopping them prematurely could allow the infection to worsen. Continuation of antibiotics is important until the course is complete or unless indicated otherwise by a physician.

 

Educational Objective:

 

If the initial aspiration attempt for a breast abscess fails, the next step should be to attempt aspiration again, preferably under ultrasound guidance, before considering more invasive procedures like incision and drainage. This approach ensures accurate access to the abscess and minimizes invasiveness.

questions.text: The production of which of the following hormones is increased in obesity? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Insulin

 

In obesity, there is typically an increase in insulin production due to insulin resistance. This resistance at the cellular level leads to impaired glucose uptake by cells, prompting the pancreas to secrete more insulin in an attempt to maintain normal blood glucose levels—a state referred to as compensatory hyperinsulinemia. Over time, this can strain the pancreas and exacerbate metabolic issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thyroxine: Thyroxine levels are generally not increased in obesity; thyroid function can sometimes be altered, but not in the manner of increased production directly due to obesity.

 

Option C. Growth hormone: Growth hormone levels are often decreased in obesity. Growth hormone has lipolytic effects, helping to break down fats, and its lower levels in obesity are associated with an adverse metabolic profile.

 

Option D. Adiponectin: This is a hormone produced by adipose tissue that enhances insulin sensitivity and has anti-inflammatory effects. Levels of adiponectin are typically lower in individuals with obesity, which contributes to increased insulin resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In obesity, insulin resistance occurring due defect at receptors which causes compensatory hyperinsulinemia. Thyroxine, growth hormone, and adiponectin have lipolytic effects, hence, their levels are reduced in obesity.

 

Reference - Harrison/Obesity

questions.text: Which of the following organisms follow a bird-arthropod-human transmission route? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Japanese encephalitis

 

Japanese encephalitis follows bird-arthropod-human transmission.

 

JE virus infects several extra-human hosts, e.g., pigs and birds (like pond herons). The basic cycles of transmission are:

 

(a) Pig → Mosquito → Pig

(b) Bird → Mosquito → Bird

 

Humans are incidental "dead-end" hosts and are infected by the bite of infected Culex mosquitoes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malaria: Caused by Plasmodium parasites, transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes, primarily involves a human-mosquito-human cycle without bird involvement.

 

Option C. Plague: Caused by Yersinia pestis, typically involves rodents and fleas in its transmission cycle; humans are incidental hosts.

 

Option D. Paragonimiasis: Caused by Paragonimus worms, involves a cycle between snails, crabs/crayfish, and mammals (including humans), but not birds or typical arthropods like mosquitoes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The transmission cycles of diseases like Japanese encephalitis is crucial for implementing effective public health measures. In the case of JE, controlling mosquito populations and minimizing human exposure to mosquito bites, especially in areas where birds are present, are key strategies in preventing the disease.

choices.text: It is recommended for patients with colorectal cancer

questions.text: True statement about teduglutide is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a GLP- 2 analogue

 

Teduglutide is a glucagon-like peptide-2 (GLP-2) analogue. It is used to treat short bowel syndrome in adults and works by promoting the growth of the intestinal lining, thereby improving nutrient absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Its half-life is 6 - 8 hours: The half-life of teduglutide is actually around 2 hours, not 6-8 hours.

 

Option C. It is administered orally: Teduglutide is not administered orally; it is administered via subcutaneous injection.

 

Option D. It is recommended for patients with colorectal cancer: Teduglutide is not recommended for patients with colorectal cancer. It is specifically approved for use in patients with short bowel syndrome.

 

Therefore, the true statement about teduglutide is that it is a GLP-2 analogue, making option A the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Teduglutide is a GLP-2 analogue used to treat short bowel syndrome. It is administered via subcutaneous injection and has a half-life of about 2 hours. It is not recommended for patients with colorectal cancer.

questions.text: Identify the fibres in the image given below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Projection

 

The internal capsule, a type of projection fibre, is the marked structure.

 

Projection fibres -

 

  • Connect the cerebral cortex to other brain areas and the spinal cord.
  • These fibers run vertically, either ascending to the cortex (afferent fibers bringing in sensory information) or descending from the cortex (efferent fibers sending out motor commands).
  • The corona radiata and the internal capsule are examples of areas containing many projection fibers.
  • They facilitate communication between the cortex and other parts of the CNS like the brainstem, thalamus, and spinal cord.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Short Association:

 

  • Also known as "U-fibers" or "short arcuate fibers" which connect neighboring gyrus.
  • They allow for communication between adjacent or nearby cortical regions.
  • Primarily found in the gray matter just below the cortical surface.
  • Their presence helps in localized processing and integration of information within a single cerebral hemisphere.

 

Option B. Long Association:

 

  • Connect more distant areas within the same hemisphere.
  • Examples include the superior longitudinal fasciculus, which connects the frontal lobe to the posterior temporal, parietal, and occipital lobes, and the uncinate fasciculus, which connects the frontal lobe to the anterior temporal lobe.
  • These fibers are crucial for integrating information across distant cortical areas within the same hemisphere.

 

Option D. Commissural:

 

  • Connect corresponding regions of the two cerebral hemispheres, allowing them to communicate with each other.
  • The most prominent example is the corpus callosum, which is the largest white matter structure in the brain and provides a broad band of neural connections between the left and right cerebral hemispheres. Other examples include the anterior commissure and the posterior commissure.
  • These fibers are essential for the two hemispheres to share information and coordinate activity.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following regimen is commonly used in the treatment of retinoblastoma? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Vincristine, carboplatin and etoposide

 

Chemotherapy commonly used is a three-drug regimen containing vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide.

 

Treatment of retinoblastoma –

 

 

Other 3 Options: Not commonly used for retinoblastoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most commonly used chemotherapy regimen for retinoblastoma includes vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide. This combination is effective in reducing tumor size and facilitating further local treatment options.

choices.text: Red degeneration of fibroid
Torsion of fibroid
None of the above

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a fibroid uterus develops severe acute pain abdomen at 28 weeks of gestation. There is no history of fever. WBC count is 8000cells/µl. The most likely diagnosis is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Red degeneration of fibroid 

 

Explanation:

 

Red degeneration- occurs mostly in pregnancy. Due to thrombosis of capsular veins.

 

  • Patient presents with tense, tender abdomen with fever.
  • After excluding other obstetric complications (e.g.- abruption, appendicitis, twisted ovarian cyst, pyelitis)
  • Treatment:  Symptomatic - hydration, rest and analgesia
  • Surgical management AVOIDED

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pre-term labor: This is unlikely, as in preterm labor, the pain isn’t acute severe. It will be increasing in intensity and frequency and occurring at regular intervals. Preterm labor is also associated with cervical dilatation and effacement

 

Option C. Torsion of Fibroid: This can happen in a pedunculated subserous fibroid but is quite a rare occurrence, It will be additionally associated with vomiting and will require surgical management

 

Educational Objective:

 

Red degeneration of fibroid during pregnancy presents with acute severe pain, and symptomatic treatment is the primary approach, avoiding surgical intervention.

 

Ref: Page no 275, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gyn 6th edition

questions.text: Which nerve passes through the foramen marked in the image below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Inferior alveolar nerve

 

The marked structure is the mandibular foramen, which is an opening located just below the mandibular angle.

 

  • The inferior alveolar nerve (IAN) is a branch of the mandibular nerve (CN V3).
  • The IAN descends behind the lateral pterygoid muscle, passing between the sphenomandibular ligament and the mandibular ramus, and enters the mandibular canal via the mandibular foramen.
  • The mandibular foramen is the entry point for the IAN and the vessels of the mandible.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lingual nerve:

 

  • It is a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3), which is the third division of the trigeminal nerve.
  • The lingual nerve provides general sensory innervation (touch, pain, temperature) to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • It is closely associated with the chorda tympani nerve (a branch of the facial nerve) which carries taste fibers from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. However, the lingual nerve itself doesn't carry taste sensation; it just provides a pathway for the chorda tympani nerve.

 

Option B. Mandibular nerve:

 

  • The mandibular nerve is the third division (V3) of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V), which is the main sensory nerve of the face.
  • It has both sensory and motor components.
  • The sensory branches of the mandibular nerve include the buccal, lingual, and inferior alveolar nerves, which innervate areas such as the lower teeth, gingiva, skin of the cheek, and anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • Its motor fibers innervate the muscles of mastication (chewing) and other muscles like the mylohyoid, anterior belly of the digastric, tensor tympani, and tensor veli palatini.

 

Option C. Chorda tympani nerve:

 

  • It's a branch of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) and carries taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • It also carries preganglionic parasympathetic fibers to the submandibular and sublingual salivary glands, which play a role in salivation.
  • While it is not a branch of the mandibular nerve, it is closely associated with the lingual nerve (a branch of V3) in the oral cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inferior alveolar nerve is another major branch of the mandibular nerve (V3) which provides sensory innervation to the lower teeth (mandibular teeth) and the surrounding gingiva. Before it enters the mandibular canal in the jaw, it gives off a branch called the mental nerve, which exits the jaw through the mental foramen to supply sensation to the lower lip and chin. The inferior alveolar nerve also carries motor fibers to the mylohyoid muscle and the anterior belly of the digastric muscle.

questions.text: The given image shows what grade of placenta previa? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) III

 

Explanation:

 

The image illustrates Type 3 placenta previa where the placenta partially covers the internal os. This classification is part of the older classification system known as Browne’s classification.

 

Placenta previa is categorized into different types based on how much the placenta covers the internal os of the cervix:

 

Older Classification (Browne’s classification):

 

  • Type 1: The lower edge of the placenta enters the lower segment but is away from the os.
  • Type 2: The placenta reaches the margin of the os but doesn’t cover it.
  • Type 3: The placenta partially covers the internal os (when fully dilated, it doesn’t cover).
  • Type 4: The placenta completely covers the os.

 

Newer Classification (based on Transvaginal Sonography - TVS; by ACOG):

 

  1. True Placenta Previa: The placenta covers the internal os.
  2. Low-lying Placenta: The placenta lies within 2 cm of the internal os but does not cover it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV: This would mean the placenta completely covers the os, which is not the case in the given image.

 

Option C. II: This would mean the placenta reaches the margin of the os but does not cover it, which is not consistent with the image.

 

Option D. I: This would mean the lower edge of the placenta enters the lower segment but is away from the os, which does not align with the given image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placenta previa is classified based on the extent to which the placenta covers the internal os, with Type 3 indicating partial coverage.

 

Types of Placentae previa

 

Older Classification (Browne’s classification)

 

 

 

Newer Classification (based on Transvaginal Sonography -TVS); By ACOG

 

  1. True Placenta Previa: Placenta covers the internal os
  2. Low lying placenta: Placenta lies within 2 cm of the internal os but does not cover it. 

 

Ref: Page 658, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is admitted with fever, icterus, conjunctival suffusion, and hematuria for 15 days. Which serological test should be done for diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Microscopic agglutination test

 

History of fever with liver and kidney involvement should arouse suspicion for leptospirosis (Weil's disease).

 

A microscopic agglutination test is used for the diagnosis of leptospirosis.

 

Serotype-specific tests:

 

  • Microscopic agglutination test
  • Macroscopic agglutination test

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Widal test: Incorrect, the Widal test is used to diagnose typhoid fever, which involves testing for antibodies against Salmonella typhi antigens but does not present with the same symptom profile as described.

 

Option C. Weil Felix reaction: Incorrect, this test is historically used for diagnosing rickettsial infections, which are caused by different organisms and have different clinical features.

 

Option D. Paul Bunnell test (monospot test): Incorrect, this test is used to diagnose infectious mononucleosis caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, characterized by symptoms like fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes but not typically associated with icterus or hematuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 The Microscopic Agglutination Test (MAT) is crucial for diagnosing leptospirosis in patients presenting with symptoms like fever, jaundice, red eyes, and hematuria, as it accurately detects the presence of antibodies against Leptospira, confirming the infection.

questions.text: Which among the following monitors is most commonly used to monitor the depth of anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bispectral index

 

  • The bispectral index (BIS) is the most commonly used method to monitor the depth of anesthesia and determine the level of consciousness under anesthesia.
  • BIS is derived from the EEG (electroencephalogram) and shows the cerebral drug effect of an anesthetic drug.
  • BIS values range from 0-100, where lower values indicate deeper anesthesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EEG: While EEG is the basis for BIS, it is not typically used directly in clinical practice to monitor anesthesia depth due to its complexity.

 

Option B. Provoked lower esophageal contractility: This is not a standard or common method for monitoring the depth of anesthesia.

 

Option C. Entropy: Entropy monitoring is another EEG-based technique used to assess the depth of anesthesia. However, it is less commonly used compared to BIS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The bispectral index (BIS) is the most commonly used monitor to assess the depth of anesthesia, providing an EEG-derived measure of the cerebral effects of anesthetic drugs.

questions.text: What is the test of significance conducted for two or more proportions? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chi-square test

 

The Chi-square test is used to determine if there is a significant association between categorical variables. It is especially useful for testing the relationship between two or more proportions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Student's test: This typically refers to the t-test, which is used to compare means between two groups. It is not appropriate for proportions.

 

Option C. Z test: While the Z test can be used for proportions, it is usually employed for large sample sizes and comparing the means of two populations.

 

Option D. ANOVA: Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) is used to compare the means among three or more groups, not for comparing proportions.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the test being shown below: NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Cover-uncover test

 

The test shown is the cover - uncover test.

 

Cover-uncover test:

 

  • The cover test is used to detect the presence and type of heterophoria.
  • One eye is covered with an occluder while the other eye fixates on an object.
  • The covered eye will deviate if heterophoria is present.
  • After a few seconds, the cover is removed, and the movement of the previously covered eye is observed.
  • The direction of movement of the eyeball indicates the type of heterophoria (e.g., outward movement suggests esophoria).
  • The speed of movement indicates whether recovery is slow or rapid.

 

 

Prism Bar cover test: Cover test is performed with a prism bad to measure deviation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obscure test: Not a standard test for detecting eye alignment issues.

 

Option B. Prism test: A generic term that can refer to various tests involving prisms, including the prism cover test used to measure the degree of deviation.

 

Option D. Maddox rod test: Used to detect and measure phorias and tropias, but involves a Maddox rod and a point light source, creating a line image, not the cover-uncover sequence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cover-uncover test is a simple and effective method to detect and diagnose latent and manifest deviations of the eyes by observing the movement of the uncovered eye during fixation on a target.

questions.text: Mr. Seth recently underwent surgery to remove a parathyroid gland due to hyperparathyroidism. The surgeon informed the patient that one or more of the parathyroid glands may be transferred to another location during the surgery to protect them or due to their location. The parathyroid is commonly transferred to? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Brachioradialis

 

Explanation:

 

The most common site for the relocation of the parathyroid gland(s) is in the forearm muscle, specifically the nondominant side brachioradialis. Transplantation to this location provides several advantages:

  • Accessibility: The forearm location is easily accessible for potential future surgical interventions if necessary.
  • Monitoring: This location allows for straightforward monitoring of parathyroid function using simple clinical tests.
  • Functionality: The transplanted gland(s) will continue to produce parathyroid hormone normally, aiding in the regulation of calcium levels in the body.
  • Ease of Removal: If there is disease recurrence after surgery, the forearm location facilitates easy removal.
  • Typically, a total of 12 to 14 pieces are transplanted in a type of heterotopic transplant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Triceps: Triceps is not a preferred site for parathyroid transplantation due to less accessibility and monitoring challenges compared to the brachioradialis.

 

Option B. Biceps: Biceps is also not commonly used for parathyroid transplantation because it does not offer the same ease of access and monitoring advantages as the brachioradialis.

 

Option C. Sartorius: Sartorius is not a preferred site for parathyroid transplantation. The forearm muscle (brachioradialis) is favored for its convenience and monitoring benefits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The brachioradialis muscle in the forearm is the most common site for parathyroid gland relocation during surgery due to its ease of access, convenient monitoring, and straightforward removal if needed.

choices.text: Wilson's disease
Autoimmune hepatitis
Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency

questions.text: A 55 yr old man is found to have hepatomegaly on physical examination. He also complains of dark tan despite avoiding sun exposure. His liver microscopy is given on the slide below. This patient most likely suffers from: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemochromatosis

 

The patient most likely has hemochromatosis. The liver microscopy image in the given scenario shows hepatocellular iron deposition is dark-brown in H&E stain (A) and blue in Prussian blue-stained section (B).

 

 

Hemochromatosis is defined by an abnormally high accumulation of body iron, the majority of which is deposited in parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas. Iron can also build up in the heart, joints, and endocrine systems.

 

Hemochromatosis, also known as primary or hereditary hemochromatosis, is an inherited disorder caused by excessive iron absorption.

 

Secondary hemochromatosis, acquired hemochromatosis, or hemosiderosis refers to the accumulation of iron in tissues as a result of parenteral iron administration, usually in the form of transfusions, or other causes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wilson's disease: Primarily involves copper accumulation in the liver and other tissues, leading to liver disease and neuropsychiatric symptoms.

 

Option B. Autoimmune hepatitis: Characterized by inflammation of the liver due to autoimmune disorders, not associated with iron deposition.

 

Option C. Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency: Leads to liver and lung disease due to the accumulation of abnormal alpha-1 antitrypsin protein in the liver, not iron.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemochromatosis is characterized by excessive iron deposition in the liver and other organs, which can be confirmed by the distinct staining patterns seen in liver biopsy samples.

questions.text: What method is most effective for visually representing the fluctuations in disease occurrence within a given area over time? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Line graph

 

Line graphs or line diagrams are the best way to plot the changes in the incidence of a disease in a given area over time (TREND of any event).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Histogram: Is graphical presentation for ‘continuous quantitative data’

 

  • Continuous groups are marked on x-axis (abscissa) while frequencies are marked on y-axis (ordinate).

 

 

Option C. Ogive:  Is graph of cumulative relative frequency distribution

 

 

Option D. Stem and leaf plot:  Represents quantitative data in graphical format which helps us visualize the shape of distribution. We are able to represent frequencies for different classes of values.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Line graphs are the most effective method for visually representing the fluctuations in disease occurrence over time, making them ideal for identifying and analyzing trends in epidemiological data.

choices.text: Substance P

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter is responsible for anterograde dilatation of the small intestine?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. VIP

 

Explanation

 

VIP is responsible for anterograde dilatation of the small intestine.

 

During peristalsis, segment of intestine behind the bolus contracts while segment in front of it relaxes.

 

Cholinergic neurons in the anterograde direction produce NO and VIP which cause relaxes the segment of the intestine in front of the bolus.

 

Cholinergic neurons in the retrograde direction produce substance P and acetylcholine which contracts the segment of the intestine behind the bolus.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acetylcholine: Incorrect as acetylcholine is involved in the contraction of the intestinal segment behind the bolus, not in the dilatation.

 

Option C. Substance P: Incorrect because it also contributes to the contraction of the intestinal muscles behind the bolus.

 

Option D. Serotonin: Incorrect as serotonin is involved in overall motility and secretion within the gut but not specifically in anterograde dilatation as described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

VIP is crucial for the anterograde dilatation of the small intestine, promoting the relaxation of the intestinal segment ahead of the bolus during peristalsis, thereby facilitating the forward movement of intestinal contents.

questions.text: Which muscle is typically represented by the color blue? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Extensor carpi radialis longus

 

Explanation:

 

  • Origin: It originates from the lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus.
  • Insertion: It inserts into the base of the second metacarpal bone on the dorsal side.
  • Action: This muscle extends and abducts the wrist. It helps in the extension of the wrist joint and also assists in radial abduction.
  • Innervation: It's innervated by the radial nerve.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Brachioradialis:

 

  • Origin: This muscle originates from the proximal two-thirds of the lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus.
  • Insertion: It inserts into the lateral surface of the radius near its styloid process.
  • Action: The primary function is to flex the elbow. However, unlike most other flexors of the elbow, which are pronators, the brachioradialis is a supinator when the forearm is pronated and a pronator when the forearm is supinated, making it a neutralizer of the forearm.
  • Innervation: The brachioradialis is innervated by the radial nerve.

 

Option C. Supinator:

 

  • Origin: The supinator muscle has a two-headed origin – one from the lateral epicondyle of the humerus (by the radial collateral ligament) and one from the proximal ulna (from the annular ligament and the supinator crest).
  • Insertion: It wraps around the upper third of the radius.
  • Action: As its name suggests, it supinates the forearm, meaning it rotates the forearm to turn the palm anteriorly or upwards.
  • Innervation: It is innervated by the deep branch of the radial nerve.

 

Option D. Flexor carpi radialis brevis:

 

  • Origin: It originates from the medial epicondyle of the humerus.
  • Insertion: It inserts into the bases of the second and third metacarpal bones.
  • Action: This muscle flexes and abducts the wrist.
  • Innervation: It's innervated by the median nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Molecular defect causing liver disease in Dubin-Johnson syndrome is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ABCC2

 

Molecular defect causing liver disease in Dubin-Johnson syndrome is ABCC2 (codes for canalicular protein with ATP-binding cassette), it leads to the mutation of multiple drug-resistant protein 2 (MRP2) receptor. Hence, there is a defect in the transfer of conjugated bilirubin from the liver to bile in Dubin-Johnson syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ATP7A: This gene is associated with Menkes disease, a disorder of copper metabolism.

 

Option B. ATP7B: This gene is associated with Wilson's disease, another disorder of copper metabolism.

 

Option D. SERPINA1: This gene is associated with Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, a condition that can lead to liver and lung disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The molecular defect causing liver disease in Dubin-Johnson syndrome is in the ABCC2 gene, which encodes for a canalicular protein involved in the excretion of conjugated bilirubin.

choices.text: Single positive blood culture for HACK group is a major criterion
