Single positive blood culture for Coxiella Burnetti is a major criterion
Complete dehiscence of prosthetic valve
Documentation of four minor criterion allows a clinical diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the modified Duke's criteria: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Single positive blood culture for Coxiella Burnetti is a major criterion

 

Single positive blood culture for Coxiella Burnetti is considered as one of the major criteria to establish the diagnosis of infective endocarditis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Single positive blood culture for HACK group is a major criterion: Incorrect terminology; it should refer to the HACEK group, and typically more than one positive blood culture is required unless other major criteria are also met.

 

Option C. Complete dehiscence of prosthetic valve: This would provide imaging evidence of endocardial involvement and thus falls under a major criterion if detected via appropriate imaging but is not accurately captured in this statement.

 

Option D. Documentation of four minor criterion allows a clinical diagnosis: According to the Modified Duke’s Criteria, at least five minor criteria are needed to conclude infective endocarditis if no major criteria are met.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The detection of C. Burnetti in a single blood culture is a major criterion for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis due to the organism's strong association with this disease, despite being difficult to culture.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy has swelling of knee joints and non-blanching rashes as seen in the picture. Urine exam reveals haematuria +++ and proteinuria +. Platelet levels are normal. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP)

 

In the given clinical scenario, the boy exhibits typical signs and symptoms of Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP). HSP is a type of small vessel vasculitis that commonly affects children. It is characterized by the presence of a purpuric rash, as well as arthritis and abdominal pain. Additionally, approximately 50% of patients with HSP develop renal complications that can range from asymptomatic microscopic hematuria to severe, progressive glomerulonephritis.

 

In patients with HSP, the onset of nephritis typically follows the development of the rash. The pathogenesis of HSP nephritis is believed to be associated with the deposition of polymeric immunoglobulin A (IgA) in glomeruli.

 

  • Here are some common types of vasculitis that can affect children.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): SLE typically presents with a butterfly malar rash over the face, especially involving the nasolabial folds. It also includes systemic symptoms like fever, joint pain, and renal involvement, but the presentation and rash pattern differ from HSP.

 

Option C. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP): ITP presents with petechiae all over the body due to thrombocytopenia, and the patient typically has a low platelet count. Peripheral smear usually shows an increase in megakaryocytes.

 

Option D. Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN): PAN is a medium vessel vasculitis that presents with fever, abdominal pain, skin changes like livedo reticularis, muscle and joint pain, and neuropathy. It does not typically present with the purpuric rash and renal involvement seen in HSP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is characterized by a purpuric rash, arthritis, abdominal pain, and renal complications such as hematuria and proteinuria, typically following the rash development.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used as an anti-smoking agent? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Varenicline

 

Varenicline is an FDA-approved medication that helps individuals quit smoking by reducing the craving and withdrawal symptoms associated with tobacco use. It acts as a partial agonist at alpha4 beta2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, which can both stimulate the receptor (to reduce craving) and block nicotine from binding (to reduce the rewarding effects of cigarettes).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Busulfan: An alkylating agent used primarily in the treatment of chronic myelogenous leukemia.

 

Option B. Acamprosate: Used to treat alcohol dependence by reducing the craving for alcohol.

 

Option D. Gabapentin: An anticonvulsant that is also used for neuropathic pain and certain mood disorders.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Varenicline is a partial agonist at α4β2 & α7 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. As a partial agonist it prevents high and reinforcement and also controls craving and withdrawal due to tobacco use. It is the most effective agent for tobacco use disorders.

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 505.

questions.text: Calcitonin levels are increased in: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hyperparathyroidism

 

Calcitonin, a hormone secreted by the thyroid gland, is involved in the regulation of calcium levels in the body. In conditions where there is an increase in parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels, such as in hyperparathyroidism, there is a corresponding increase in blood calcium levels. The body responds to this hypercalcemia by increasing the secretion of calcitonin to help lower the calcium levels back to normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperthyroidism: While hyperthyroidism involves the thyroid gland, it does not typically result in increased calcitonin levels. Hyperthyroidism mainly increases thyroid hormones like thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3), not calcitonin.

 

Option B. Hypoparathyroidism: This condition is characterized by decreased PTH levels, leading to hypocalcemia (low calcium levels), not hypercalcemia that would stimulate calcitonin production.

 

Option D. Cushing's syndrome: Cushing's syndrome involves an excess of cortisol, a steroid hormone, and does not directly affect calcitonin levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increased calcitonin levels are typically seen in response to hypercalcemia, as seen in hyperparathyroidism. This is a compensatory mechanism to help maintain calcium homeostasis.

choices.text: It is faster than AV nodal pathway
It is slower than AV nodal pathway

questions.text: Identify the false statement about the bundle of Kent? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It is slower than AV nodal pathway

 

The false statement about the bundle of Kent is that it is slower than the AV nodal pathway. In fact, the bundle of Kent provides a rapid conduction pathway between the atrium and the ventricle, bypassing the AV node. This pathway allows for faster conduction than the AV nodal pathway due to the nature of the myocardial fibers involved and the lack of delay that normally occurs at the AV node.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is faster than the AV nodal pathway: This statement is actually true. The bundle of Kent facilitates faster electrical conduction from the atria to the ventricles by bypassing the slower AV node, contributing to the clinical manifestations of pre-excitation syndromes.

 

Option C. Leads to a short PR interval: This is true. The rapid conduction via the bundle of Kent results in premature activation of the ventricles, reflected as a shortened PR interval on an electrocardiogram.

 

Option D. Leads to a prolonged QRS duration: This is also true. The activation of ventricular myocardium via the accessory pathway occurs in a less synchronized manner compared to normal conduction through the His-Purkinje system, leading to a broader and prolonged QRS complex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bundle of Kent is an accessory pathway connecting atrium and ventricle with conduction through Na+ channels leading to bypass of physiological AV conduction.

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/WPW

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to OCP use? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thromboembolism

 

Thromboembolism is an absolute contraindication to the use of Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs). The use of combined oral contraceptives (COCs) can significantly increase the risk of venous thromboembolism, particularly in individuals with a history of thromboembolic events or known thrombogenic mutations.

 

Absolute Contraindications of Combined OCPs according to the WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria:

 

  • MEC Category 4: Unacceptable health risk if the method is used.
    • Breastfeeding and < 6 weeks postpartum
    • Not breastfeeding; < 21 days postpartum with risk factors for Venous Thromboembolism
    • Age ≥ 35 years with smoking ≥ 15 cigarettes/day
    • Hypertension with systolic BP ≥ 160 OR Diastolic BP ≥ 100 mmHg
    • Hypertension with vascular disease
    • History of DVT/Pulmonary embolism
    • Acute DVT/Pulmonary embolism
    • DVT/Pulmonary embolism on anticoagulant therapy
    • Major surgery with prolonged immobilization
    • Known thrombogenic mutations (e.g., Factor V Leiden, prothrombin mutation, protein S, C, antithrombin deficiency)
    • Current and history of ischemic heart disease
    • Stroke (history of cerebrovascular disease)
    • Complicated valvular heart disease
    • Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome
    • Migraine with aura (any age)
    • Current breast cancer
    • Severe cirrhosis
    • Hepatocellular adenoma/carcinoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic Renal Disease: Chronic renal disease is not an absolute contraindication but requires careful consideration depending on the severity and associated conditions.

 

Option C. History of Amenorrhea: A history of amenorrhea is not an absolute contraindication to the use of OCPs.

 

Option D. Diabetes Mellitus: Diabetes mellitus is not an absolute contraindication. However, it requires careful monitoring, especially if the patient has vascular complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thromboembolism is an absolute contraindication to the use of combined oral contraceptives (COCs) due to the increased risk of venous thromboembolism associated with these medications.

choices.text: It is the most common type of squint.
Miotics are used as the treatment strategy in the high AC/A ratio.
It is associated with high myopia.
Refractive type can be fully corrected by use of spectacles.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding accommodative esotropia? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is associated with high myopia.

 

Accommodative esotropia is the most common type of esotropia and is associated with hypermetropia (farsightedness), not myopia (nearsightedness). The condition often presents in children around 2 to 3 years of age and is characterized by an inward turning of the eyes that is related to the effort of focusing (accommodation).

 

Types:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is the most common type of squint: True. Accommodative esotropia is indeed the most common type of esotropia seen in children. This type of squint is related to the effort of focusing (accommodation) and is associated with farsightedness (hypermetropia).

 

Option B. Miotics are used as the treatment strategy in the high AC/A ratio: True. Miotics can be used to manage accommodative esotropia associated with a high AC/A ratio. Miotics reduce the need for accommodation, thereby reducing the associated esotropia.

 

Option D. Refractive type can be fully corrected by use of spectacles: True. The refractive type of accommodative esotropia can be fully corrected by using spectacles that correct the hypermetropia. These spectacles reduce the accommodative effort, thereby correcting the esotropia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Accommodative esotropia, the most common type of squint, is associated with high hypermetropia and can often be fully corrected by spectacles. It is not associated with high myopia. Different treatment strategies, including the use of spectacles and bifocals, depend on the specific type and underlying cause of the esotropia.

questions.text: Pott's puffy tumor is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Subperiosteal abscess of frontal bone

 

  • Pott's puffy tumor is the subperiosteal abscess of the frontal bone.
  • Pott puffy tumor is a soft doughy forehead swelling due to frontal bone osteomyelitis with associated subperiosteal abscess. PPT is a rare complication of frontal sinusitis, but can also occur due to trauma.
  • It is more often seen in adults as frontal sinus is not developed in infants and children.
  • The pathophysiology for the development of frontal skull osteomyelitis can occur due to hematogenous spread of the infection or to direct extension of infection.
  • Presents with tender forehead swelling associated with fever, headaches, nasal discharge, or symptoms of increased intracranial pressure
  • Treatment consists of large doses of antibiotics, drainage of abscess and trephining of frontal sinus through its floor. Sometimes, it requires removal of sequestra and necrotic bone by raising a scalp flap through a coronal incision

 

 

Complications of frontal sinusitis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subperiosteal abscess of ethmoid bone: Incorrect, as the ethmoid bone typically presents with other orbital or intranasal complications.

 

Option C. Mucocele of frontal bone: Incorrect, as mucoceles refer to mucus-filled cysts resulting from blocked sinus ducts, not infections.

 

Option D. Mucocele of ethmoid bone: Also incorrect and refers to a different pathological condition involving the ethmoid sinus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pott's puffy tumor is a severe and rare complication of frontal sinusitis, presenting with distinctive forehead swelling and potentially grave complications. Prompt diagnosis and comprehensive treatment are crucial to prevent further spread of infection and ensure recovery.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 224

questions.text: Inspiratory stridor is found in what kind of lesions: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supraglottic

 

  • Inspiratory stridor is seen in supraglottic lesions.
  • Types of stridor and sites of origin
    • Inspiratory stridor - laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
    • Expiratory stridor - bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.
    • Biphasic stridor - laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis and subglottic stenosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subglottic - More commonly associated with biphasic stridor due to narrowing at the level just below the vocal cords.

 

Option C. Tracheal - Can cause either biphasic or expiratory stridor depending on the extent and exact location of the obstruction.

 

Option D. Bronchus - Primarily causes expiratory stridor due to obstructions in the lower airways.

 

Educational Objective:


Inspiratory stridor is a key clinical sign indicating a potential obstruction in the supraglottic region of the airway. Recognizing this symptom is critical for diagnosing and managing airway obstructions effectively to prevent respiratory distress.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 333, 334

questions.text: Contact based isolation is employed for which of the following diseases? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MRSA

 

Contact-based isolation precautions are specifically employed for managing patients who are infected with or are carriers of MRSA (methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus). MRSA is known for its ability to spread via direct contact with infected or colonized individuals, or indirectly through contact with contaminated surfaces and objects. This isolation strategy involves using personal protective equipment, such as gloves and gowns, when interacting with the patient, and applying rigorous hygiene practices to prevent the spread of the bacterium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diphtheria: While also a communicable disease, it primarily requires droplet-based isolation due to its transmission through respiratory droplets.

 

Option C. Mumps: Similar to diphtheria, mumps is spread through respiratory droplets and thus requires droplet precautions.

 

Option D. Asthma: Not an infectious disease; it is a chronic respiratory condition that does not require transmission-based precautions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The three categories of transmission-based precautions include:

 

  • Contact- based isolation is used for infections, diseases, or germs that are spread by touching the patient or items in the room. Examples include MRSA, VRE, diarrheal illnesses, open wounds, and RSV.
  • Droplet-based isolation is employed for diphtheria and mumps.
  • Airborne precautions are required to protect against conditions like measles, severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), varicella (chickenpox), and Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

questions.text: For a population of 10,000, the land area necessary to implement the controlled tipping using the trench method is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 acre

 

Controlled tipping or controlled burial is similar in principle to sanitary landfill but at a smaller scale that is appropriate in rural areas. 

 

Trench Method— The waste collection truck deposits its load into the trench where the bulldozer spreads and compacts it. Approximately, 1 acre of land is required for a population of 10000 for a depth of 2 feet and usable for 1-year duration

 

Educational Objective:

 

For implementing controlled tipping using the trench method, 1 acre of land is sufficient for a population of 10,000, considering a depth of 2 feet and a usage duration of one year.

questions.text: While you are evaluating a baby, you show him a bright pink teddy bear that he reaches out to with both hands. What is the earliest age by which this milestone is typically achieved? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4 months

 

Bidextrous reach is seen at 4 months and unidextrous reach at 6 months.

 

 

Fig: Bidextrous grasp approach to a dangling ring 4 months

 

Fine motor development:

 

  • Hands come together in midline by 5 months
  • Bidextrous Reach comes by 4 months
  • Tries to reach for object from both hand will be bidextrous approach & from one hand will be unidextrous approach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bidextrous reach, where a baby uses both hands to reach out for objects, is typically achieved by 4 months of age.

questions.text: A pregnant lady with a history of recurrent abortions is now diagnosed to have antiphospholipid syndrome. What would be the best mode of treatment for her? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aspirin + heparin

 

Explanation

 

Aspirin + heparin:

 

  • Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by recurrent pregnancy loss, thrombosis, and the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies.
  • The primary cause of pregnancy loss in APS is believed to be due to inhibition of trophoblast function and differentiation, which leads to placental dysfunction.
  • The best management approach for pregnant women with APS includes:
    • Low dose aspirin: Initiated as soon as pregnancy is confirmed. Aspirin helps by preventing platelet aggregation and improving blood flow to the placenta.
    • Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH): Started once fetal cardiac activity is detected. LMWH helps prevent blood clot formation, thus reducing the risk of thrombosis and improving pregnancy outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin only: While low-dose aspirin is beneficial, it is not sufficient alone for the prevention of complications in APS. The addition of heparin provides better protection against thrombosis and pregnancy loss.

 

Option C. Aspirin + heparin + steroids: Steroids are not routinely used in the management of APS during pregnancy due to their potential side effects and lack of evidence showing added benefit in preventing pregnancy loss when combined with aspirin and heparin.

 

Option D. Aspirin + steroids: Similar to the previous option, steroids are not recommended as part of the standard management for APS in pregnancy. The combination of aspirin and heparin is the preferred treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best management for pregnant women with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) to prevent recurrent pregnancy loss includes low-dose aspirin and low molecular weight heparin (LMWH).

 

Ref: Page no 2907, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady presents with third degree uterine prolapse. Which of the following is the best management for her?( NEET PG 2019 )
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

 

Explanation

 

  • In the given case scenario, vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair is the ideal management.
  • This is also called as Ward Mayo repair
  • This is recommended to patients who satisfy the following criteria:
    • >40 years of age
    • Have completed their families
    • Do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fothergill repair: This is also known as Manchester repair and involves conserving the uterus. In this procedure, cervical amputation with plication of the cardinal ligaments is done. It is done in young women who have completed their families with utero-vaginal prolapse.

 

Option B. Sling operation: This is preferred in women who are young, nulliparous (yet to have children/ complete their families) with prolapse

 

Option D. Shirodkar procedure: This is a modification of Manchester/ Fothergill surgery and does not include cervical amputation

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair (Ward Mayo repair) is the preferred management for older women (>40 years) with third degree uterine prolapse who have completed their families and do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function.

 

Ref: Page 221, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Which of the following phases of a clinical trial is also referred to as efficacy trial? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phase 3

 

Phase 3 of a clinical trial is often referred to as an efficacy trial. This is because phase 3 trials are designed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the investigational drug or intervention in a larger and more diverse patient population. Phase 3 trials typically involve several hundred to several thousand participants and are usually randomized, controlled trials that compare the investigational drug or intervention to either a placebo or an active comparator.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phase 1 trials are typically the first-in-human studies and are designed to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of the investigational drug or intervention.

 

Option B. Phase 2 trials are designed to evaluate the safety and preliminary efficacy of the investigational drug or intervention in a larger patient population than in phase 1 trials.

 

Option D. Phase 4 trials, also known as post-marketing surveillance studies, are conducted after a drug or intervention has been approved by regulatory agencies and are designed to monitor the long-term safety and effectiveness of the drug or intervention in a larger patient population than in earlier phases of the trial.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The following diagram depicts the fluctuation in population over the years spanning from 1983 to 1989 within a specific location. Which type of statistical diagram is being employed in this instance? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Component bar graph

 

  • The given image shows a component bar graph. It is used to represent data in which the total magnitude is divided into different subsets or components.
  • A bar chart or bar graph is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data. They can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.
  • In a multiple bar chart, 2 or more sets of data are shown simultaneously.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Histogram is used for continuous quantitative data presentation.

 

 

A bar chart can be distinguished from a histogram because the rectangles are

 

separated by the spaces. This indicates that the data forms discrete categories.

 

In a histogram, the rectangles are not separated by spaces as the data represented forms a continuous set instead of discrete groups.

 

Option B. Line Diagram: Is a better chart Used in depiction of TREND. There is no closed loop and no histogram in the background.

 

 

Option D. Multiple Bar Graphs: Multiple bar graphs show two or more sets of data simultaneously with separate bars for each category side by side. This is different from a component bar graph, where each bar is divided into segments representing different components.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A component bar graph is used to represent data where the total magnitude is divided into different subsets or components, effectively illustrating the proportion of each category within the total value.

questions.text: A patient presents with gastrointestinal problems including abdominal pain and distension, bloody and mucus-filled diarrhea, and tenesmus, with rectal prolapse. A stool examination reveals the presence of typical barrel-shaped eggs. What is the possible causative agent? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trichuris trichiura

 

The given clinical picture and the barrel-shaped eggs are suggestive of infection with Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).

 

The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:

 

  • Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
  • They float in the saturated salt solution.
  • It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.

 

Other Options


Option A. Giardia lamblia: The stool examination usually reveals oval-shaped cysts or trophozoites. Giardia does not produce eggs, distinguishing it from helminthic infections.

 

Option C. Ascaris lumbricoides: The eggs are typically oval-shaped and brown-colored. They have a distinct thick shell and are not barrel-shaped, which helps differentiate them from Trichuris trichiura eggs.

 

 

Option D. Ancylostoma duodenale:  The eggs are oval and thin-shelled, significantly different in appearance from the barrel-shaped eggs of Trichuris trichiura.

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Table listing appearance of various organism in stool/sputum examination

questions.text: Identify the Sensory nerve supply for the given area of hand? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Radial nerve 

 

The area marked in the image is supplied by radial nerve.

 

 

  • Origin: Arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus.
  • Main Functions: Primarily a motor nerve for the extensor muscles of the arm and forearm. It also has sensory branches for the skin on the back of the hand and the posterior arm and forearm.
  • Motor Innervation: Triceps brachii, anconeus, brachioradialis, and all the extensor muscles in the forearm.
  • Sensory Innervation: Supplies the posterior surface of the arm and forearm, and the radial aspect of the dorsum of the hand.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior Interosseous Nerve (PIN):

 

  • Origin: It's a continuation of the deep branch of the radial nerve.
  • Main Functions: Purely motor nerve that supplies the extensor muscles of the forearm.
  • Motor Innervation: All the deep extensors of the forearm, including extensor pollicis longus, extensor pollicis brevis, extensor indicis, and others.
  • Sensory Innervation: The PIN does not have a sensory function.

 

Option C. Median Nerve:

 

  • Origin: Formed by the union of the medial and lateral roots from the brachial plexus.
  • Main Functions: Supplies most of the flexor muscles in the forearm and some muscles in the hand.
  • Motor Innervation: Flexor muscles in the anterior forearm (except flexor carpi ulnaris and the ulnar half of flexor digitorum profundus) and thenar muscles and first two lumbricals in the hand.
  • Sensory Innervation: Palmar aspect of the lateral three and a half fingers and the associated palm area.

 

Option D. Ulnar Nerve:

 

  • Origin: Arises from the medial cord of the brachial plexus.
  • Main Functions: Supplies muscles in the hand and a few in the forearm.
  • Motor Innervation: Flexor carpi ulnaris and the ulnar half of flexor digitorum profundus in the forearm. In the hand, it supplies most intrinsic muscles, including the hypothenar muscles, the palmar and dorsal interossei, and the third and fourth lumbricals.
  • Sensory Innervation: Provides sensation to the palmar and dorsal aspects of the medial one and a half fingers and the associated hand region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sensory function of the radial nerve is provided by its four main sensory branches:

 

  • Inferior lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm: Supplies the lateral aspect of the anterior upper arm between the deltoid and the elbow.
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of the arm: Supplies part of the posterior aspect of the upper arm.
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of the forearm: Supplies a tapered strip of the middle portion of the posterior forearm.
  • Superficial branch of the radial nerve: Supplies the posterior surface of the lateral 3 ½ digits and the associated areas of the palm.

questions.text: Vaccine that requires strain change due to evolving organism is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Influenza

 

 

The influenza vaccine is unique among vaccines because it requires periodic updates or strain changes almost every year. This necessity is due to the evolving nature of the influenza virus, particularly the frequent antigenic changes in its surface glycoproteins (hemagglutinin and neuraminidase). These changes can occur through two primary mechanisms:

 

  • Antigenic Drift: Minor changes that occur gradually over time as the virus replicates. These small genetic mutations can alter the antigenic properties of the virus, necessitating updates to the vaccine to maintain its effectiveness.
  • Antigenic Shift: Less frequent but more significant changes that can lead to the emergence of a completely new influenza virus subtype. This can potentially lead to pandemics if the new subtype spreads widely and the population has little to no immunity against it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diphtheria: The vaccine for diphtheria does not require frequent updates or strain changes. The causative bacterium (Corynebacterium diphtheriae) does not exhibit the same level of antigenic variation that necessitates vaccine modification.

 

Option C. Polio: Polio vaccines target stable viral antigens of the poliovirus, which do not undergo frequent antigenic changes, thus not requiring periodic strain updates.

 

Option D. Typhoid: Typhoid vaccines, such as those for Salmonella Typhi, also do not require frequent changes in formulation, as the bacterial antigens are relatively stable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The influenza vaccine must be updated regularly to match the antigenically evolving influenza virus strains, primarily due to antigenic drift (gradual) and shift (drastic). This adaptation is essential to enhance vaccine effectiveness and control the spread of flu each season, highlighting the dynamic challenge of influenza virus surveillance and vaccine formulation.

questions.text: Identical twins have similarities in all of the following except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fingerprint pattern

 

Monozygotic twins (Identical twins) are conceived when a single egg fertilized by a single sperm splits into two after fertilization. Such twins have 100% of their genes in common. Both of them invariably have the same blood type and are of the same sex.

 

 Dizygotic twins (Faternal twins) are conceived when two eggs are fertilized by two different sperms. They share 50% of their genes, just like any other siblings. Their blood types and sex can be either same or different.

 

So, all the inheritable characteristics will be exactly same in identical twins (e.g. Blood group, DNA fingerprinting, Iris Color).

 

But Fingerprints are not inheritable hence different even in identical twins. No finger-prints of 2 individuals are similar. It is 100% accurate method of identification.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood Group: Identical twins invariably have the same blood type.

 

Option B. DNA Fingerprinting: Identical twins have identical DNA profiles because they share the same genetic material.

 

Option D. Iris Color: Iris color, being a genetic trait, will be the same in identical twins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While identical twins share the same blood group, DNA fingerprinting, and iris color due to their identical genetic makeup, their fingerprint patterns are unique to each individual due to non-inheritable factors.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient is brought to the ER in a state of unconsciousness. Her BP is 70/50 mm of Hg and her ECG is shown below. What is the next best step in the management of her condition? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Synchronized cardioversion

 

Any hemodynamically unstable rhythm, requires synchronized cardioversion (Shock delivered in sync with R wave to prevent R-on-T phenomenon)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: AV Nodal blockers are used if hemodynamically stable.

 

Option B: Maximum of 30mg of adenosine can be tried if patient is Hemodynamically Stable.

 

Option C: Carotid massage is not recommended for hemodynamically unstable patient.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Aspirin increases fever by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis
PGI2 is responsible for resetting the temperature to a higher level
Fever occurs during inflammation due to release of histamine

questions.text: Which of the following is true about fever? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IL-1 is an endogenous pyrogen

 

Fever is a common symptom of many illnesses, and it is an important defense mechanism of the body. It is often associated with infection, inflammation, and tissue damage. Pyrogens are substances that cause fever.

 

IL-1 (interleukin-1) is an endogenous pyrogen, meaning that it is a substance produced by the body that induces fever. It is produced by activated immune cells such as macrophages and monocytes in response to infection, inflammation, and tissue damage. IL-1 acts on the hypothalamus to increase the set point of the thermostat, leading to a higher body temperature.

 

  • Endogenous pyrogens, such as prostaglandins, IL-1, and TNF
  • Exogenous pyrogens, which are bacterial lipopolysaccharides. They cause endogenous pyrogens to be released from leukocytes (IL-1 and TNF)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs): Aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) actually reduce fever by inhibiting the synthesis of prostaglandins, which are involved in the process of fever. Prostaglandins are produced by cells in the hypothalamus in response to pyrogens (fever-inducing substances), and they increase the set point of the hypothalamic thermostat, leading to a higher body temperature. NSAIDs inhibit the enzyme cyclooxygenase (COX), which is required for the synthesis of prostaglandins, thereby reducing fever.

 

Option B. PGI2 (prostaglandin I2): PGI2 (prostaglandin I2) is not responsible for resetting the temperature to a higher level.

 

Option D. Histamine: Histamine is not directly involved in the process of fever, although it is involved in the process of inflammation. Histamine is a chemical mediator that is released by mast cells and other immune cells in response to injury or infection, and it causes dilation of blood vessels and increased permeability of capillaries. This leads to the characteristic redness, swelling, and heat that are associated with inflammation. However, histamine does not directly cause fever.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis from the image given below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pterygium

 

The likely diagnosis, based on the above image, is pterygium.

  • Pterygium is a subconjunctival fibrovascular tissue encroaching the cornea.
  • It is a wing-shaped fold of conjunctiva encroaching upon the cornea from either side within the interpalpebral fissure.
  • It is more common in people living in hot climates, and a response to prolonged effect of environmental factors such as exposure to sun (ultraviolet rays), dry heat, high wind and abundance of dust.

 

Clinical features:

  • It is more common in elderly males doing outdoor work.
  • It may be unilateral or bilateral.
  • It presents as a triangular fold of conjunctiva encroaching the cornea in the area of palpebral aperture, usually on the nasal side but may also occur on the temporal side.
  • Deposition of iron seen sometimes in corneal epithelium anterior to advancing head of pterygium is called stocker's line.
  • Mostly asymptomatic.
  • Irritation and grittiness are caused by a dellen – localized drying of tear film.
  • Cosmesis may be a significant problem.
  • Visual disturbances occur when it encroaches the pupillary area or due to corneal astigmatism induced due to fibrosis in the regressive stage.
  • Diplopia may occur due to limitation of ocular movements.
  • PARTS OF A PTERYGIUM:

 

A fully developed pterygium consists of three parts

  1. Head (apical part present on the cornea),
  2. Neck (limbal part), and
  3. Body (scleral part) extending between limbus and the canthus.

 

Differences between pterygium and pseudopterygium

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pinguecula: A yellowish, benign growth on the conjunctiva that does not encroach onto the cornea.

 

Option B. Concretions: Small, yellowish-white deposits on the conjunctiva, often associated with chronic conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Bitot's spots: Foamy, whitish lesions on the conjunctiva, typically associated with vitamin A deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pterygium is characterized by a wing-shaped fold of conjunctiva encroaching upon the cornea, commonly seen in people exposed to prolonged environmental factors like UV rays and dust. The treatment includes surgical removal and techniques to prevent recurrence.

questions.text: Which one of the following drugs inhibits neutrophil recruitment? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Colchicine

 

Colchicine is primarily used to treat gout and familial Mediterranean fever. One of its mechanisms of action is the inhibition of neutrophil migration into inflamed tissues, thereby reducing inflammation. It disrupts the microtubules inside cells, including neutrophils, affecting their mobility and reducing their recruitment to sites of inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Montelukast: Montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist used mainly for asthma and allergic rhinitis. While it can reduce inflammation, its primary action is not on neutrophil recruitment.

 

Option B. Sodium Cromolyn: Sodium cromolyn is a mast cell stabilizer used to treat conditions like asthma and allergic rhinitis. It prevents the release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators from mast cells but doesn't directly inhibit neutrophil recruitment.

 

Option D. Febuxostat: Febuxostat is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor used for the treatment of chronic gout. It reduces uric acid production but doesn't specifically inhibit neutrophil recruitment.

 

Therefore, Colchicine is the drug that inhibits neutrophil recruitment, making option C the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Colchicine is the drug that inhibits neutrophil recruitment by disrupting microtubules, thus affecting neutrophil mobility and reducing inflammation. This mechanism makes it effective in treating conditions like gout and familial Mediterranean fever.

choices.text: Fishing and fisheries beyond territorial waters

questions.text: Which item is included in the concurrent list of the Indian Constitution? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adulteration of food

 

The concurrent list in the Indian Constitution includes subjects on which both the central and state governments can legislate. One of the items included in this list is the adulteration of food. The legislative framework in India is divided into three lists as per the seventh schedule of the Constitution:

 

  1. Union List: Contains subjects on which only the Parliament can make laws. This list includes 100 items, such as defense, foreign affairs, atomic energy, and others.
  2. State List: Contains subjects on which only the state legislatures can make laws. This list includes 61 items, such as police, public health, and agriculture.
  3. Concurrent List: Contains subjects on which both the Parliament and state legislatures can make laws. This list includes 52 items, such as criminal law, marriage and divorce, bankruptcy and insolvency, and the adulteration of food.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fishing and fisheries beyond territorial waters: This subject is included in the Union List, meaning that only the Parliament has the authority to legislate on this matter.

 

Option C. Regulating labor in mines: This subject is also included in the Union List, placing it under the legislative jurisdiction of the Parliament.

 

Option D. Public health and sanitation: This subject is included in the State List, meaning that only state governments have the exclusive authority to legislate on public health and sanitation matters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The adulteration of food is included in the Concurrent List of the Indian Constitution, allowing both the central and state governments to legislate on this issue. The Union List and State List contain subjects exclusive to the Parliament and state legislatures, respectively.

questions.text: Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which did not subside even after 3 weeks of birth, was observed in a neonate. On investigating, liver enzymes, PT/INR and albumin levels were normal. No hemolysis was seen on a peripheral blood smear. A drop in bilirubin level was observed within a week after treatment with phenobarbital. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Crigler Najjar type 2

 

In the case described above, the neonate had unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that did not subside even after 3 weeks of birth, but had normal liver enzymes, PT/INR, and albumin levels, and no hemolysis was seen on a peripheral blood smear. These findings are consistent with a diagnosis of Crigler-Najjar type 2. The fact that bilirubin levels dropped after treatment with phenobarbital further supports this diagnosis.

 

Crigler Najjar type 2 is an autosomal recessive disease with non-hemolytic unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia caused by homozygous missense mutations in UGT1A1 resulting in reduced (partial) enzymatic activity.

 

  • Causes of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia- Physiologic (newborn), Crigler-Najjar, Gilbert syndrome, Hemolytic
  • Gilbert syndrome: Partial deficiency of uridine diphosphate glucuronyltransferase (UDPGT) caused by polymorphism. It is more common, affecting 5-10%. It occurs after puberty. It is not associated with chronic liver disease and no treatment is required.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rotor syndrome: Rotor syndrome is characterized by conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, not unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

 

Option C. Dubin-Johnson syndrome: Like Rotor syndrome, Dubin-Johnson syndrome is also characterized by conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It presents with a dark liver on gross examination due to the accumulation of pigment, which is not consistent with the findings described.

 

Option D. Crigler-Najjar type 1: This condition is more severe than type 2 and typically presents with extremely high levels of unconjugated bilirubin, leading to a high risk of kernicterus. Patients with Crigler-Najjar type 1 do not respond to phenobarbital treatment, unlike the neonate described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crigler-Najjar type 2 presents with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that responds to phenobarbital, distinguishing it from other forms of hereditary hyperbilirubinemia.

choices.text: Fine touch lost on the opposite side
Pain and temperature lost on the same side
Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side
Only pain lost on the same side

questions.text: Brown Sequard syndrome is characterized by? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side

 

Explanation

 

Brown-Sequard syndrome results from a hemisection (partial transection) of the spinal cord, leading to a distinct pattern of neurological symptoms:

 

  • Ipsilateral (same side as the lesion) Deficits:
    • Motor Function: There is paralysis below the level of the lesion due to damage to the corticospinal tract, which controls voluntary muscle movements. The paralysis is of the upper motor neuron type, characterized by increased muscle tone, spasticity, and hyperreflexia.
    • Proprioception and Discriminative Touch: Loss of fine touch, vibration sense, proprioception, and discriminatory tactile abilities due to damage to the dorsal columns (fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus) which carry these sensory modalities from the body to the brain.
  • Contralateral (opposite side as the lesion) Deficits:
    • Pain and Temperature Sensation: Loss occurs below the level of the lesion because the spinothalamic tract, which carries pain and temperature sensations, crosses over to the opposite side at the level of the spinal cord soon after entering. Thus, a hemisection will affect the fibers carrying information from the opposite side.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fine touch lost on the opposite side: Incorrect because fine touch is lost on the same side as the lesion, not the opposite.

 

Option B. Pain and temperature lost on the same side: Incorrect as pain and temperature sensations are lost on the opposite side due to the crossing of the spinothalamic tract.

 

Option D. Only pain lost on the same side: Incorrect because pain sensation is lost on the opposite side and is associated with temperature loss as well.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemi section of the spinal cord involves the ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown- Sequard syndrome.

 

 

Functions of tracts involved -

 

Fasciculus gracilis or fasciculus cuneatus → ipsilateral discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception

 

Spinothalamic tract → contralateral pain and temperature sensation

 

Corticospinal tract → primary motor activity same side of the body.

questions.text: Viral infection mimicking erythroblastosis fetalis is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Parvovirus B19

 

Parvovirus B19 infection can mimic erythroblastosis fetalis due to its ability to infect erythroid progenitor cells and inhibit erythropoiesis, leading to severe anemia. Erythroblastosis fetalis typically results from maternal antibodies targeting fetal red blood cells, causing hemolysis and severe anemia; Parvovirus B19 causes a similar effect through a direct infection of the erythroid cells.

 

Parvovirus B19 is associated with:

 

  1. Erythema infectiosum (fifth disease)
  2. Transient aplastic crisis
  3. Pure red cell aplasia
  4. Erythroblastosis fetalis (most commonly in early pregnancy)

 

Erythema infectiosum rash :

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus): Incorrect, as HSV does not typically cause the hematologic manifestations associated with erythroblastosis fetalis.

 

Option B. Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV): Incorrect, while EBV can cause hematological disturbances, it does not mimic erythroblastosis fetalis but is more associated with conditions like infectious mononucleosis.

 

Option C. Picornavirus: Incorrect, this group of viruses, which includes enteroviruses and rhinoviruses, does not produce hematological symptoms that mimic erythroblastosis fetalis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 infection can uniquely mimic erythroblastosis fetalis by causing severe fetal anemia and related complications through its direct impact on erythroid progenitor cells. Awareness of this potential complication is essential, particularly in pregnant women, as the infection can lead to significant fetal outcomes, necessitating careful monitoring and management.

questions.text: A patient with a history of facial trauma, presented with diplopia, epistaxis, and restricted eye movements. Looking at the CT image given below, what will be your diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Blow-out fracture

 

The given clinical scenario plus CT image suggests a blowout fracture.

 

Orbital blowout fractures:

  • Result from trauma to the orbit.
  • Mainly involve orbital floor and medial wall.
  • Clinical signs:
  • Periocular swelling (early stage)
  • Subcutaneous emphysema affecting the eyelids (commoner with medial wall fractures)
  • Enophthalmus (inward displacement of eyeball) and mechanical ptosis
  • Infraorbital nerve anaesthesia
  • Double diplopia (diplopia in both upwards as well as downwards gaze)
  • The muscle restriction is confirmed with a positive “forced duction test”.

 

Forced Duction Test:

  • It is used to determine whether the absence of movement of eye is due to paralysis of extraocular muscles or due to mechanical obstruction.
  • To perform this test, anaesthetized conjunctiva, is grasped with forceps.
  • Now, an attempt is made to move the eyeball in the direction where the movement is restricted.
  • POSITIVE forced duction test: If it is due to mechanical obstruction, it will not be possible to move the eyeball.
  • NEGATIVE forced duction test: If it is due to paralytic squint, eyeball can move.
  • Investigations:
    • Waters view in x-ray shows a teardrop opacity.
    • CT scan is used for confirmation of diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Initial management is to prevent further injury to the globe.
    • Surgical indications:
    • Enophthalmos
    • Diplopia
    • Ocular motility disorder
    • Immediate repair indicated if oculocardiac reflex or significant enophthalmos is present.
    • Delayed repair is done within 2 weeks.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Le-Fort fracture: Involves fractures of the maxillary bones and may present with midfacial mobility, but not typically with the specific signs of blow-out fractures.

 

Option B. Fracture maxilla: May involve the upper jaw but not specifically associated with the orbital floor fractures seen in blow-out fractures.

 

Option C. Fracture zygomatic: Involves the cheekbone and can cause facial asymmetry and infraorbital anesthesia, but typically does not cause the specific signs of a blow-out fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A blow-out fracture, typically resulting from orbital trauma, is characterized by periocular swelling, subcutaneous emphysema, enophthalmos, infraorbital nerve anesthesia, and diplopia. The diagnosis is confirmed by a CT scan showing the characteristic teardrop sign.

questions.text: Which Reflex is responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Bainbridge reflex

 

Explanation

 

Bainbridge reflex is a cardioaccelerator reflex that increases the heart rate when venous return is increased. Since this reflex arises from right atrium, it is also called right atrial reflex.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. J Reflex: Apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension due to J receptor (C-receptor, juxta-pulmonary capillary receptor) stimulation.

 

Option B. Cushing Reflex: Incorrect because the Cushing reflex involves increased blood pressure, bradycardia, and respiratory depression in response to increased intracranial pressure, not right atrial distension.

 

Option C. Bezold-Jarisch Reflex: Bezold-Jarisch reflex is the reflex characterized by bradycardia and hypotension, caused by stimulation of chemoreceptors present in the wall of left ventricles by substances such as alkaloids. It is also called coronary chemoreflex. Vagal fibers form the afferent and efferent pathways of this reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bainbridge reflex is responsible for inducing tachycardia in response to right atrial distension. It serves to adjust heart rate upward when venous return to the heart increases, ensuring optimal cardiac output and circulation efficiency.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. The child's parents mention that the pain has been increasing over the past few hours. On examination, the child appears distressed and has abdominal tenderness. An X-ray is ordered, and it reveals a gasless abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Acute Pancreatitis

 

  • A gasless abdomen is seen in acute pancreatitis.
  • Acute pancreatitis is an inflammation of the pancreas, which can be caused by gallstones, alcohol consumption, and other factors. It can lead to severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, and increased heart rate. A gasless abdomen is seen in acute pancreatitis. Other signs include sentinel loop, renal halo and colon cut-off.
  • Other causes of gasless abdomen on Xray include:
    • A paucity of small bowel gas may be a normal finding in some adults
    • Bowel ischemia
    • Intestinal atresia
    • Ascites
    • Gastroenteritis
    • Large abdominal mass - due to displacement

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ulcerative Colitis: Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease that affects the innermost lining of the large intestine (colon) and rectum. Symptoms include diarrhea, often with blood or pus, abdominal pain, and rectal pain. In children, it may affect growth. A gasless abdomen on X-ray is not a typical feature of ulcerative colitis.

 

Option B. Intussusception: Intussusception is a condition in which a segment of the intestine "telescopes" into another, leading to bowel obstruction. This can cut off the blood supply to the affected portion of the intestine. It is one of the most common abdominal emergencies affecting children under two. Classic symptoms include intermittent abdominal pain, "currant jelly" stools, and a palpable "sausage-shaped" mass in the abdomen. While it can lead to changes in an abdominal X-ray like dilated small bowel loops, a gasless abdomen is not the primary diagnostic feature of intussusception.

 

Option D. Crohn's Disease: Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, from mouth to anus. Symptoms can include abdominal pain, severe diarrhea, fatigue, weight loss, and malnutrition. Inflammation caused by Crohn's disease can involve different areas of the digestive tract in different people. Unlike acute pancreatitis, a gasless abdomen is not a primary feature seen with Crohn's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A gasless abdomen on X-ray is commonly associated with acute pancreatitis in children presenting with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. This condition should be considered when evaluating similar clinical presentations.

choices.text: Prostate carcinoma
Breast carcinoma
Stomach carcinoma

questions.text: Predominantly osteoblastic secondaries are seen in: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prostate carcinoma

 

Predominantly osteoblastic secondaries are seen in prostate carcinoma.

 

Metastatic bone tumors: Metastatic bone tumors outnumber primary bone cancers as the most common type of skeletal malignancy.

 

Osteoblastic (or sclerotic) bone deposition is seen in prostate cancer, carcinoid, small cell lung cancer, Hodgkin lymphoma, and medulloblastoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Breast carcinoma: While breast cancer can metastasize to bone, it typically results in osteolytic (bone-destroying) rather than osteoblastic lesions.

 

Option C. Stomach carcinoma: Metastases from stomach cancer to bone are relatively rare and typically do not exhibit osteoblastic activity.

 

Option D. Bone carcinoma: This option is less specific and generally refers to primary bone cancers, which are different from the metastatic osteoblastic lesions seen in prostate cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Osteoblastic metastases are a hallmark of prostate carcinoma, unlike breast and stomach carcinomas which are more likely to cause osteolytic or no bone lesions respectively.

choices.text: Positive predictive value
Negative predictive value

questions.text: What is the term for the likelihood that a patient who tested positive actually has the specific disease in question?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Positive predictive value

 

 

Positive predictive value tells that that a patient who tested positive actually has the specific disease in question.

 

 

  • ‘a’ are known as True positive (TP): Population having the disease and showing screening test results as positive
  • ‘d’ are known as True negative (TN): Population not having the disease and showing screening test results as negative
  • ‘b’ are known as False positive (FP): Population not having the disease but erroneously showing screening test results as positive
  • ‘c’ are known as False negative (FN): Population having the disease but erroneously showing screening test results as negative

 

Positive predictive value (PPV): Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who have the disease, out of all those who test positive on a screening test
PPV = a/ (a + b) × 100 = TP/ (TP + FP) × 100

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sensitivity: Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who have the disease (cases)
Sensitivity = a/ (a + c) × 100 = TP/ (TP + FN) × 100

 

Option B. Specificity: Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who do not have the disease (healthy)
Specificity = d/ (b + d) × 100 = TN/ (TN + FP) × 100

 

Option D. Negative predictive value (NPV): Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who do not have the disease, out of all those who test negative on a screening test
NPV = d/ (c + d) × 100 = TN/ (FN + TN) × 100

 

Educational Objective:

 

Positive predictive value (PPV) is the measure that indicates the likelihood that a patient who tested positive actually has the specific disease in question. It is crucial for assessing the effectiveness of a screening test in correctly identifying true positive cases.

questions.text: The preferred test for evaluating the difference in means between two study groups, where one group functions as a control, is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Unpaired t test

 

When comparing the means of two independent groups, where one group serves as a control, the appropriate statistical test to use is the unpaired t-test. This test is designed to determine if there is a significant difference between the means of the two independent groups.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chi-square test: This test is used for categorical data to assess whether there is a significant association between two variables.

 

Option B. Z test: The Z test is typically used for large sample sizes to compare the means of two populations or to test proportions.

 

Option D. Paired T test: The paired t-test is used when comparing means from the same group at different times or under different conditions (e.g., before and after treatment).

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came to ED with complaints of weakness, paresthesia, and breathing difficulty. Relevant investigations were done. The ECG obtained is suggestive of: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypokalemia

 

History suggestive of cramps, muscle weakness is common in hypokalemia. ECG shows PR, QTc prolongation, T wave inversion, u waves. “NikEleKam T waves aka reverse wellen sign” seen in Hypokalemia

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperkalemia: Typically, hyperkalemia would show peaked T waves, widened QRS complexes, and possibly a flattened P wave, which are not evident in this ECG.

 

Option C. Hypocalcemia: Would more typically show a prolonged QT interval but lacks the specific U wave features seen in hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Hypercalcemia: This condition would likely show a shortened QT interval, which is not present in this ECG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ECG Findings in Hypokalemia:

 

  • U-waves
  • Prolonged QTc
  • Flattened/inverted Ts
  • Sagging ST
  • ST Depression
  • Biphasic t-waves
  • ST elevation in aVR
  • PVCs/Ventricular Dysrhythmias
  • Pseudo-ischemic patterns

questions.text: A veterinarian developed an ulcer with central black eschar over the forearm as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most probable causative organism? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bacillus anthracis

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cutaneous anthrax which is caused by Bacillus anthracis.

 

Human anthrax presents in one of three ways:

 

  • ﻿﻿Cutaneous Anthrax (hide porter's disease)- Black eschar at the base, with a very prominent inflammatory ring around the eschar, is referred to as a malignant pustule.
  • ﻿﻿Pulmonary Anthrax (Wool sorter's disease) - Hemorrhagic pneumonia.
  • ﻿﻿Intestinal Anthrax- Hemorrhagic diarrhoea. It occurs mainly in primitive communities that eat the carcasses of animals dying of anthrax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Known for causing infections in wounds and burns, often producing a greenish pus but not typically associated with black eschars.

 

Option B. Yersinia pestis: Causes bubonic plague, associated with swollen and painful lymph nodes (buboes) rather than black eschars.

 

Option D. Francisella tularensis: Causes tularemia, which can present with ulcers at the infection site but lacks the characteristic black eschar of anthrax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cutaneous anthrax is characterized by the initial appearance of a small pimple that quickly turns into a painless ulcer with a necrotic (black) eschar at the center. This presentation is typical for individuals who have been in contact with infected animals or animal products, which is common in the veterinary profession.

 

Additional Information

 

Robert Koch validated the germ theory of disease after discovering the anthrax bacillus as the cause of anthrax. He also discovered the causative agents of tuberculosis and cholera. Hence, he is Known as the Father of Bacteriology.

 

Koch's postulates, which link specific microorganisms to specific diseases, state that the microorganism must be:

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Found in abundance in diseased organisms, but not in healthy organisms.
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Isolated from a diseased organism and grown in pure culture
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Able to cause disease when inoculated into a healthy organism
  4. ﻿﻿﻿Re-isolated from the diseased experimental host and identical to the original specific causative agent

questions.text: Which of the following fluoroquinolones has maximum bioavailability? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Levofloxacin

 

Levofloxacin is known for its high bioavailability, approximately 99-100% when administered orally. This means almost all of the administered dose reaches systemic circulation, making it effective for treating a variety of infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin also has good bioavailability, but it is generally lower than that of Levofloxacin, ranging from approximately 70-80%. It is drug of choice for meningococcal meningitis, also effective in enteric fever and anthrax.

 

Option C. Gatifloxacin: The bioavailability of Gatifloxacin varies, but it is generally less than that of Levofloxacin, ranging from around 60-90%. It is a respiratory FQ that causes dysglycemia, therefore has been withdrawn from India.

 

Option D. Norfloxacin: Norfloxacin has a bioavailability of about 30-40%, which is significantly lower than Levofloxacin. It is mostly used for urinary tract infections because of its lower systemic absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Levofloxacin has the highest bioavailability among the listed fluoroquinolones, with nearly 100% of the administered dose reaching systemic circulation. This high bioavailability makes levofloxacin highly effective for a wide range of bacterial infections.

questions.text: A team of emergency responders has been called to the scene of a bomb blast in a crowded city center. Upon arrival, they find multiple casualties with various injuries, including blast injuries. In a blast injury, which of the following organs is least vulnerable to the blast wave? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Liver

 

Explanation:

 

In the context of blast injuries, the liver is considered the least vulnerable to the direct effects of the blast wave due to its solid and dense nature. The primary blast wave from an explosion affects air-filled and delicate structures more significantly than dense, solid organs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GI tract: The GI tract, especially the hollow parts, is susceptible to blast injuries due to the presence of air. Typical injuries include subserosal hemorrhage and perforation of the intestines.

 

Option B. Lungs: The lungs are highly vulnerable to blast injuries because they are air-filled and delicate. Blast waves can cause severe pulmonary barotrauma, leading to conditions such as pneumothorax, hemothorax, and pulmonary contusion.

 

Option D. Ear drum: The eardrum is extremely sensitive to the pressure changes caused by a blast wave. It is a thin membrane that can easily rupture in an explosion, making it one of the most commonly injured organs in such scenarios.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a blast injury, the liver is the least vulnerable organ to the primary blast wave compared to the GI tract, lungs, and eardrum, which are more susceptible due to their air-filled nature and delicate structures.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented with a history of road traffic accident. The axial CT image is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?( NEET PG 2019 )
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Extradural Hemorrhage

 

Explanation:

 

The CT image demonstrates a right-sided hyperdense lesion, characteristic of an Extradural Hemorrhage (EDH). Features supporting this diagnosis include:

 

 

Shape and Location: The lesion exhibits a biconvex or "lens-shaped" appearance, typically not crossing sutures, localized at the pterion which is a common site for EDH due to its proximity to the middle meningeal artery (MMA).

 

Type of Trauma: Associated with high-energy trauma such as a road traffic accident, often causing arterial bleeding, specifically from the MMA.

 

Lucid Interval: Patients may experience a lucid interval where symptoms improve temporarily before deteriorating, due to the building pressure from the accumulating blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subdural Hemorrhage (SDH): Typically appears as a crescentic or "banana-shaped" collection that can cross sutures but not midline. It arises from bridging veins, often due to lower-energy trauma.

 

Option C. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage: Usually presents as diffuse or patchy areas of increased density in the subarachnoid spaces, not shown in the image.

 

Option D. Intraventricular Hemorrhage: Would be visualized within the ventricular system, which is not evident here.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for delusional disorder?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Young age

 

This is not a typical risk factor for delusional disorder. It usually starts in middle or late adult life.

 

Other Options:

 

Delusional disorder typically begins in middle or late adult life, and it is uncommon in young individuals.

 

Option A. Recent immigration: True. Recent immigration or cultural isolation can be associated with the development of certain types of delusions.

 

Option B. Social isolation: True. Individuals who are socially isolated are at increased risk for the development of delusional disorder.

 

Option C. Family history: True. Having a family history of delusional disorder can increase the risk of developing the condition.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Delusional disorder typically begins in middle to late adulthood. It is characterized by development of a single delusion or a set of related delusions, which are usually persistent and sometimes are life long.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 331.

choices.text: Prevention of seizures in severe pre-eclampsia
Prevention of recurrent seizures in eclampsia
Prevention of RDS in premature baby

questions.text: Magnesium sulphate has no role in? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prevention of RDS in premature baby

 

Explanation

 

Magnesium Sulphate (MgSO4):

 

MgSO4 is used for several obstetric indications, including:

 

  1. Eclampsia: MgSO4 is the drug of choice for the prevention and treatment of seizures in eclampsia.
  2. Prevention of Seizures in Severe Pre-eclampsia: It is used prophylactically to prevent seizures in women with severe pre-eclampsia.
  3. Tocolytic in Preterm Labor: MgSO4 is used as a tocolytic agent to reduce uterine contractions and delay preterm labor.
  4. Neuroprotection in Severe Preterm Infants (<29 weeks): MgSO4 is administered to provide neuroprotection for the fetus, reducing the risk of cerebral palsy and other neurological disorders in preterm infants.

 

Prevention of RDS (Respiratory Distress Syndrome) in Premature Baby:

 

  • MgSO4 does not play a role in the prevention of RDS. Instead, corticosteroids (such as betamethasone or dexamethasone) are used to accelerate fetal lung maturation and reduce the risk of RDS in preterm babies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prevention of Seizures in Severe Pre-eclampsia: MgSO4 is effectively used to prevent seizures in women with severe pre-eclampsia.

 

Option B. Prevention of Recurrent Seizures in Eclampsia: MgSO4 is the preferred treatment to prevent recurrent seizures in women with eclampsia.

 

Option D. Reducing Contractility of Uterus: MgSO4 is used as a tocolytic agent to reduce uterine contractility and delay preterm labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corticosteroids are used for the prevention of respiratory distress syndrome in preterm babies.

 

Ref: Page 1860, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: According to wound ballistics, A gunshot wound showing burning, blackening, tattooing around the wound, can be classified as: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Close shot entry wound

 

Burning (heat of the gases), blackening (deposition of soot) and tattooing (unburned powder particles embedding into the skin) are the features of entry wound. They are not found in exit wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Close shot exit wound: Exit wounds do not show burning, blackening, or tattooing. They are usually larger and more irregular than entry wounds.

 

Option C. Distant shot entry wound: Distant shot entry wounds do not exhibit burning, blackening, or tattooing. They show a clean entry hole.

 

Option D. Distant shot exit wound: Exit wounds from distant shots also do not show these features and are typically larger and more irregular.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entry Wound features:

 

  1. Contact Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present just on the margin; not around the wound. Very minimally visible.
  2. Close Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent)
  3. Intermediate Range: Only Tattooing present around the wound
  4. Distant range: None of these present around the wound.

choices.text: Retinal pigmentation
Pale waxy disc
Narrowing of vessels
ERG – normal

questions.text: What among the following is not true about retinitis pigmentosa? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. ERG – normal

 

ERG is abnormal in retinitis pigmentosa.

 

  • Retinitis pigmentosa is a primary pigmentary retinal dystrophy predominantly affecting the rods more than the cones.
  • It is the most common hereditary fundus dystrophy, with the most common mode of inheritance being autosomal recessive.
  • In early disease, it shows reduced scotopic rod and combined responses, and photopic responses reduce with progression.
  • Eventually, the ERG becomes extinguished.
  • The characteristic visual symptom is night blindness, which may present several years before visible changes in the retina appear.
  • Dark adaptation is affected, and tubular vision may occur in advanced cases.
  • Fundus changes include bone-spicule retinal pigmentation, arteriolar attenuation, and 'waxy' disc pallor.

 

  • Visual field changes-
    • Annular or ring-shaped scotoma is a typical feature which corresponds to the degenerated equatorial zone of retina. As the disease progresses, scotoma increases anteriorly and posteriorly and ultimately only central vision is left (tubular vision). Eventually even this is also lost and the patient becomes blind.

 

  • Electrophysiological changes-

1. Electro-retinogram (ERG) is subnormal or abolished.

2. Electro-oculogram (EOG) shows absence of light peak.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Pale Waxy Disc: Optic disc pallor due to progressive degeneration.

 

Option C. Narrowing of Vessels: Attenuation of retinal arterioles due to retinal thinning and atrophy.

 

Option D.  ERG (Electroretinogram: ERG is not normal in retinitis pigmentosa. It shows abnormal findings, such as:

  • Early Disease: Reduced scotopic (rod) response and combined responses.
  • Progression: Reduced photopic (cone) responses.
  • Advanced Disease: ERG becomes extinguished or abolished

 

Educational Objective:

 

In retinitis pigmentosa, the ERG is not normal; it shows progressive abnormalities reflecting the degeneration of photoreceptor cells. Other features include retinal pigmentation, pale waxy disc, and narrowing of retinal vessels.

choices.text: Anterior transmural
Posterior transmural

questions.text: Which of the following myocardial infarcts cause aneurysm as a post-MI complication? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anterior transmural

 

As a post-MI complication, anterior transmural infarcts contribute to aneurysm formation.

 

Myocardial infarction (MI) complications such left ventricular aneurysms (LVAs) and pseudoaneurysms can cause mortality or severe morbidity. The most frequent outcome of MI is an LVA, which typically involves the anterior wall.

 

Conduction blockages, right ventricular involvement, or both are more likely to make posterior transmural infarcts problematic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subendocardial: These infarcts affect only the innermost layers of the heart wall and do not typically cause aneurysms.

 

Option C. Posterior transmural: While serious and affecting the full thickness of the heart wall, posterior infarcts are less likely than anterior infarcts to result in aneurysm formation due to the smaller area typically involved and differing hemodynamic forces.

 

Option D. Inferior wall: Inferior MIs can lead to complications like arrhythmias or heart block but are less commonly associated with aneurysm formation compared to anterior transmural MIs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior transmural myocardial infarctions are most commonly associated with the formation of left ventricular aneurysms due to the location, extent of myocardial damage, and the dynamics of ventricular pressure that exacerbate the risk of wall outpouching and aneurysm development in this region.

choices.text: Skin lesions and bruises of various ages are seen on the body
It occurs due to the tendency of a child to fall repeatedly
The syndrome is a result of gun injuries

questions.text: Identify the true statement from the following about battered baby syndrome? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Skin lesions and bruises of various ages are seen on the body

 

Battered child syndrome is defined as the collection of injuries sustained by a child as a result of repeated mistreatment or beating. If a child's injuries indicate intentional trauma or appear to be more severe than could reasonably be expected to result from an accident, battered child syndrome should be suspected.

 

Skin lesions and bruises of different ages (from young to old) are a classical feature of a child with battered baby syndrome.

 

Skeletal survey helps in identifying bone injuries in Battered Baby syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It occurs due to the tendency of a child to fall repeatedly: False: While children do fall frequently, the pattern and severity of injuries in battered child syndrome are inconsistent with typical childhood falls and accidents.

 

Option C. Stab wounds are obvious: False: Stab wounds are not a common feature of battered child syndrome. The syndrome primarily involves bruises, fractures, and other signs of physical abuse.

 

Option D. The syndrome is a result of gun injuries: False: Battered child syndrome is not characterized by gun injuries. It involves repeated physical abuse, leading to various types of trauma, particularly bruises and fractures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Battered child syndrome is characterized by the presence of skin lesions and bruises of different ages, indicating repeated and ongoing physical abuse.

questions.text: Identify the condition for which Dohlman’s procedure is used: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Zenker's diverticulum

 

Dohlman's procedure is a surgical technique primarily used to treat Zenker's diverticulum. Zenker's diverticulum is a pouch that forms at the junction of the esophagus and pharynx, causing swallowing difficulties, regurgitation, and aspiration. Dohlman's procedure involves endoscopic division of the cricopharyngeal muscle to alleviate the obstruction and diverticulum formation. This method is favored for its minimal invasiveness and effectiveness in managing the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meckel's diverticulum: Meckel's diverticulum is treated with a diverticulectomy, which involves the surgical removal of the diverticulum. This congenital anomaly of the small intestine often presents with bleeding, inflammation, or obstruction.

 

Option C. Bochdalek hernia: Bochdalek hernia, a congenital diaphragmatic hernia, is typically treated with laparotomy or laparoscopic surgery and subsequent hernia repair. This condition involves abdominal organs herniating into the thoracic cavity through a defect in the diaphragm.

 

Option D. Menetrier's disease: Menetrier's disease, a rare disorder characterized by hypertrophic gastric folds and protein-losing gastropathy, does not have a specific surgical procedure for treatment. Management often includes supportive care, protein supplements, and medications such as proton pump inhibitors or cetuximab.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dohlman's procedure is specifically used to treat Zenker's diverticulum by endoscopic division of the cricopharyngeal muscle to relieve symptoms caused by the diverticulum.

questions.text: A pediatric patient is brought to the emergency department with signs of ocular hypotension and apnea.
