The parents are concerned about the child's condition and have provided a history of recent medication use. It is crucial to determine which drug may have caused these symptoms in the infant. Drug capable of causing ocular hypotension with apnea in infants is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brimonidine

 

Brimonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used to lower intraocular pressure in conditions such as glaucoma. It acts by decreasing the production of aqueous humor and increasing its outflow, thereby reducing intraocular pressure. While brimonidine is generally well-tolerated, it can have systemic side effects, particularly in infants. The most concerning systemic side effect in this context is central nervous system depression, which can manifest as symptoms like apnea (temporary cessation of breathing). Infants, especially premature ones, are more susceptible to such side effects. Therefore, brimonidine is the drug most likely responsible for causing ocular hypotension with apnea in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timolol: Timolol is a beta-blocker commonly used to lower intraocular pressure. While it can have systemic side effects, including bradycardia and bronchospasm, it is not typically associated with apnea in infants.

 

Option C. Latanoprost: Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analog that lowers intraocular pressure by increasing the outflow of aqueous humor. It can cause side effects such as changes in iris color and eyelash growth. However, it is not known to cause apnea in infants.

 

Option D. Dorzolamide: Dorzolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used in ophthalmology to reduce intraocular pressure. While it can cause ocular hypotension, it is not a common cause of apnea, especially in infants.

questions.text: What is the drug used to differentiate myasthenia gravis from cholinergic crisis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Edrophonium

 

Edrophonium is a short-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that is used in the Tensilon test to differentiate myasthenia gravis from a cholinergic crisis. In patients with myasthenia gravis, the symptoms will improve following administration of edrophonium. In contrast, symptoms will worsen in a cholinergic crisis, indicating that the problem is excessive acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obidoxime: Obidoxime is primarily used to treat organophosphate poisoning and is not used to differentiate myasthenia gravis from a cholinergic crisis.

 

Option C. Donepezil: Donepezil is a long-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used to treat Alzheimer's disease and is not used to differentiate myasthenia gravis from a cholinergic crisis.

 

Option D. Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic drug used to treat a variety of conditions, including poisoning by organophosphates and other substances that produce a cholinergic crisis. However, it is not used to differentiate myasthenia gravis from a cholinergic crisis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Edrophonium is the drug used to differentiate myasthenia gravis from a cholinergic crisis by temporarily increasing acetylcholine levels at the neuromuscular junction, thereby improving symptoms in myasthenia gravis and worsening them in a cholinergic crisis.

choices.text: Reducing fluid intake to <500 ml per day

questions.text: The best approach in the treatment of chronic SIADH is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tolvaptan

 

The best approach in the treatment of chronic SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion) is to use tolvaptan.

 

Tolvaptan is a selective vasopressin V2 receptor antagonist that works by blocking the action of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) in the kidneys, leading to increased urine output and improved serum sodium levels. It is currently the preferred treatment for chronic SIADH, as it has been shown to be effective in improving symptoms and reducing the risk of complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reducing fluid intake to <500 ml per day is not a recommended approach to treating chronic SIADH, as it can lead to dehydration and other complications.

 

Option C. Demeclocycline, a tetracycline antibiotic, is another treatment option for SIADH, but it is less effective and has more side effects compared to tolvaptan.

 

Option D. Fludrocortisone, a mineralocorticoid hormone, is not recommended for the treatment of SIADH, as it can worsen hyponatremia (low sodium levels) and increase the risk of fluid retention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tolvaptan is the best approach in the treatment of chronic SIADH due to its selective antagonism of the vasopressin V2 receptor, leading to increased urine output and improved serum sodium levels. Other methods, such as severe fluid restriction and demeclocycline, are less effective or have more side effects. Fludrocortisone is not suitable for treating SIADH and can exacerbate the condition.

choices.text: Pulmonary edema
Congestive cardiac failure
Acute kidney injury with anuria

questions.text: Intravenous mannitol is used in? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glaucoma

 

Intravenous mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that is often used in emergency situations to lower intraocular pressure in acute congestive glaucoma. It works by drawing fluid out of the eye, thereby reducing pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary Edema: Mannitol is not used for pulmonary edema. Diuretics like furosemide are more commonly used in such cases to remove excess fluid from the lungs.

 

Option B. Congestive Cardiac Failure: Mannitol is not used in congestive cardiac failure. Loop diuretics like furosemide or thiazide diuretics are more commonly used to reduce fluid overload in these patients.

 

Option C. Acute Kidney Injury with Anuria: Mannitol is contraindicated in cases of anuria due to acute kidney injury. The drug could potentially worsen renal function in such cases.

 

Therefore, intravenous mannitol is used for acute cases of glaucoma to reduce intraocular pressure, making option D the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective

 

Intravenous mannitol is specifically used in acute cases of glaucoma to rapidly reduce intraocular pressure by drawing fluid out of the eye. It is not used for conditions like pulmonary edema, congestive cardiac failure, or acute kidney injury with anuria, where other diuretics are more appropriate and effective.

questions.text: Which of the following Carbapenems has highest risk of causing seizures? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Imipenem

 

  • Imipenem is a Carbapenem that has a maximum risk of causing seizures , hence it is contraindicated in epileptic patients.
  • Imipenem excretion is primarily renal, so dosage adjustments are required to avoid seizures in patients with renal failure.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Meropenem: Meropenem has a lower risk of inducing seizures compared to imipenem, making it a safer alternative for patients with a history of seizures or those at higher risk.

 

Option C. Ertapenem: Ertapenem is also associated with a lower risk of seizures compared to imipenem and is used in various infections but is less effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Acinetobacter species.

 

Option D. Doripenem: Doripenem, like meropenem and ertapenem, has a lower seizure risk compared to imipenem and is used in treating complex bacterial infections.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Imipenem carries the highest risk of inducing seizures among the carbapenem antibiotics, particularly in patients with renal impairment or a history of epilepsy. Proper dosage adjustments and careful monitoring are essential to minimize this risk.

questions.text: A lady presents with fever, oral ulcers, photosensitivity, and rashes on her face, as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Systemic lupus erythematosus

 

The clinical presentation of fever, oral ulcers, photosensitivity, and the characteristic facial rash, often referred to as a "butterfly rash" due to its shape across the cheeks and nose, strongly suggests Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE). SLE is an autoimmune disease that affects multiple organ systems and often presents with a combination of systemic symptoms and specific skin manifestations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermatomyositis: This condition is characterized by muscle weakness and a skin rash, but the rash typically appears on the eyelids (heliotrope rash), knuckles, elbows, knees, and toes (Gottron's papules), which does not match this presentation.

 

Option C. Rosacea: Typically presents with facial redness, small red bumps or pustules on the nose, cheeks, forehead, and chin, but lacks the systemic symptoms such as fever and oral ulcers associated with SLE.

 

Option D. Melasma: Mainly a condition of hyperpigmentation that affects sun-exposed areas and does not involve systemic symptoms like fever or oral ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:


When presented with a patient who shows systemic symptoms like fever and oral ulcers in combination with a characteristic facial rash and photosensitivity, Systemic Lupus Erythematosus should be considered a likely diagnosis. Confirmatory diagnosis would require additional clinical and serological criteria, including a positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) test.

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/ SLE, Chap 356

questions.text: Which of the following helps in maintaining the patency of ductus arteriosus? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PGE1

 

PGE1 (prostaglandin E1) keeps the ductus arteriosus open (PDA). It is useful in maintaining the patency of the Ductus Arteriosus in term neonates who are awaiting surgical correction of underlying cyanotic congenital heart disease and having a duct dependent circulation.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. PGF2α: PGF2α (prostaglandin F2α) is involved in various physiological functions, including uterine contractions, but does not play a role in maintaining the patency of the ductus arteriosus.

 

Option C. PGH2: PGH2 (prostaglandin H2) is a precursor in the prostaglandin synthesis pathway but does not directly maintain the patency of the ductus arteriosus.

 

Option D. PGI2: PGI2 (prostacyclin) is a potent vasodilator and inhibitor of platelet aggregation but is not specifically used to maintain the patency of the ductus arteriosus.

 

Educational Objective

 

PGE1 (prostaglandin E1) is used to maintain the patency of the ductus arteriosus in neonates with congenital heart defects that require an open ductus arteriosus for adequate oxygenation and circulation.

questions.text: Which of the following is an oral factor Xa inhibitor? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rivaroxaban

 

Rivaroxaban is an oral Factor Xa inhibitor.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Bivalirudin: Bivalirudin is an injectable direct thrombin (factor IIa) inhibitor. It is used primarily in patients undergoing percutaneous coronary interventions (PCI) and for patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).

 

Option B. Dabigatran: Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor. It is used for the prevention of stroke in patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation and for the treatment and prevention of DVT and PE.

 

Option D. Enoxaparin: Enoxaparin is a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) administered via injection. It acts primarily by inhibiting factor Xa and to a lesser extent factor IIa (thrombin).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rivaroxaban is an oral factor Xa inhibitor used for the prevention and treatment of thromboembolic events. Other agents like bivalirudin, dabigatran, and enoxaparin have different mechanisms of action and routes of administration.

choices.text: It has rapid onset of action
It has less depressant action on heart
It has long duration of action
It causes less release of histamine

questions.text: Cis-atracurium is preferred over atracurium because? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It causes less release of histamine

 

Cis-atracurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent preferred over atracurium for several reasons:

 

  1. Histamine Release: Atracurium is known to cause histamine release, which can lead to hypotension and bronchospasm in susceptible individuals. Cis-atracurium, on the other hand, is a newer and more selective agent that causes less histamine release, making it safer and better tolerated.
  2. Metabolism: Atracurium is metabolized by plasma esterases, which can lead to variability in its effects. Cis-atracurium undergoes Hoffman elimination, a process that occurs at physiological pH and temperature, leading to more predictable and consistent metabolism, independent of organ function.
  3. Cardiovascular Effects: While both drugs have similar cardiovascular effects, the reduced histamine release with cis-atracurium minimizes the risk of hypotension and bronchospasm, which can be beneficial in patients with cardiovascular instability.
  4. Duration of Action: Cis-atracurium has a shorter duration of action compared to atracurium, which can be advantageous for titrating doses and facilitating recovery from anesthesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It has rapid onset of action: The onset of action for cis-atracurium and atracurium is similar, so this is not the primary reason for preferring cis-atracurium over atracurium.

 

Option B. It has less depressant action on heart: Both drugs have similar cardiovascular effects, and the preference for cis-atracurium is not based on a difference in cardiac depression.

 

Option C. It has long duration of action: Cis-atracurium does not have a significantly longer duration of action compared to atracurium. In fact, its duration of action is similar or slightly shorter, allowing for easier titration and recovery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cis-atracurium is preferred over atracurium because it causes less histamine release, reducing the risk of side effects such as hypotension and bronchospasm, and it undergoes Hoffman elimination, which contributes to its safer profile and predictable metabolism.

choices.text: Detect alterations in muscle direction
Detect alterations in muscle tension
Detect changes in the muscle's position
Detect changes in the muscle's length

questions.text: What is the primary role of the Golgi tendon organ?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Detect alterations in muscle tension

 

The Golgi tendon organ's main function is to detect alterations in muscle tension. This sensory receptor is embedded in the tendons and monitors the tension applied to these tendons by the contracting muscles. When this tension exceeds safe thresholds, the Golgi tendon organ sends signals to the central nervous system to relax the muscle, effectively reducing the tension and preventing potential damage. This is an essential safety mechanism designed to avoid overexertion injuries such as muscle tears or tendon detachments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Detect alterations in muscle direction: This is incorrect as the Golgi tendon organ does not have the capability to detect directional changes in muscle movement; it is specifically tuned to tension monitoring.

 

Option C. Detect changes in the muscle's position: This choice is incorrect because the Golgi tendon organ does not sense positional changes of muscles, which is typically the function of joint proprioceptors and muscle spindles.

 

Option D. Detect changes in the muscle's length: This is incorrect because it is the muscle spindles, not the Golgi tendon organs, that are responsible for detecting stretch or changes in muscle length.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Golgi tendon organ is critical for monitoring and responding to increases in muscle tension, activating a protective reflex that relaxes the muscle to prevent damage. Understanding the protective role of the Golgi tendon organ is essential for recognizing how the body maintains muscle health and prevents injury during physical activities.

questions.text: A HIV patient presents with persistent diarrhea. Microscopic examination of the stool is given below. Identify the causative organism:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cryptosporidium

 

Cryptosporidium is identified as the causative organism for diarrhea in this HIV patient based on the stool microscopy which shows small, round oocysts that contain four sporozoites. This characteristic is a defining feature of Cryptosporidium, which is uniformly acid fast on staining. This organism typically causes severe, persistent diarrhea in immunocompromised individuals like those with HIV. The round oocysts and their contents as seen under the microscope are crucial for the diagnosis of Cryptosporidium infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cyclospora: This option is incorrect because Cyclospora oocysts are typically 8-12 µm in size and contain two sporocysts, each with two sporozoites. They are also variable in their acid-fast staining, unlike the uniform acid-fast staining of Cryptosporidium.

 

Option C. Microspora: Incorrect as Microspora (more accurately Microsporidia) are not identified by oocysts but by smaller spores and are not typically seen on routine acid-fast stain of stool.

 

Option D. Cystoisospora: Incorrect because Cystoisospora is characterized by larger oocysts that are 23-36 µm in size, oval in shape, and contain two sporocysts each with four sporozoites, differing significantly from what is observed in the provided image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptosporidium infection should be considered in HIV patients presenting with persistent diarrhea, particularly when microscopy shows small, round oocysts containing four sporozoites that stain uniformly with acid-fast stain.

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the left main bronchus

questions.text: A patient died from bronchopneumonia following an intracerebral hemorrhage caused by cerebral metastases from a squamous cell carcinoma of the left main bronchus. What should be recorded in the line I (c) of the death certificate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cerebral metastasis

 

The correct entry for line I (c) of the death certificate in this scenario is "Cerebral metastasis." This is based on the structured approach to completing a death certificate, where underlying causes leading to death are recorded in a sequence from the final disease or condition directly leading to death backwards to the originating cause. Here, the sequence of medical events is:

 

  • The direct cause of death is bronchopneumonia (line I (a)).
  • It was preceded by an intracerebral hemorrhage (line I (b)).
  • The intracerebral hemorrhage was caused by cerebral metastasis (line I (c)), which is due to the squamous cell carcinoma of the left main bronchus (line I (d)).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchopneumonia: Incorrect for line I (c) as it is the final condition directly leading to death and should be placed in line I (a).

 

Option C. Intracerebral hemorrhage: Incorrect for line I (c) as it is the immediate precursor to death, directly resulting from the cerebral metastasis, and should be placed in line I (b).

 

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma of the left main bronchus: Incorrect for line I (c) as it is the underlying original disease causing the metastasis and should be placed in line I (d).

 

Educational Objective:

 

In completing death certificates, it is crucial to record conditions in the correct sequence from the immediate cause of death backwards to the underlying causes. Cerebral metastasis, in this case, acts as a pivotal condition leading to an intracerebral hemorrhage, and ultimately to bronchopneumonia and death, and should be correctly positioned in the sequence on the death certificate.

questions.text: A 23-year-old patient has a history of travel to China and the consumption of pickled crab. He now complains of rusty sputum and cough. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Paragonimus westermani

 

The patient’s symptoms of rusty sputum and cough, combined with a history of consuming pickled crab in China, strongly point to an infection with Paragonimus westermani. This organism is a lung fluke that causes paragonimiasis, a disease transmitted to humans through the consumption of raw or undercooked crab or crayfish contaminated with metacercariae. After ingestion, the metacercariae excyst in the human gut, and the juvenile flukes migrate to the lungs, where they encapsulate and mature, causing respiratory symptoms including cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fasciola buski: Incorrect because F. buski is an intestinal fluke primarily found in the duodenum and jejunum, not associated with respiratory symptoms.

 

Option B. Fasciola hepatica: Incorrect because F. hepatica primarily infects the liver and biliary tract, causing hepatic symptoms, not respiratory issues.

 

Option D. Schistosoma japonicum: Incorrect as S. japonicum typically causes intestinal and hepatic disease, not primary lung disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with a history of consuming undercooked crab or crayfish who present with respiratory symptoms, especially when accompanied by hemoptysis and rusty sputum, consider Paragonimus westermani infection. Praziquantel is the treatment of choice for this condition.

choices.text: Skin and subcutaneous fat are stripped from the underlying fascia
Skin, subcutaneous fat and fascia are stripped from tendons
Skin, subcutaneous fat, fascia and tendons are stripped from bone
Only skin is stripped off

questions.text: What does a de-gloving injury refer to?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Skin and subcutaneous fat are stripped from the underlying fascia

 

De-gloving injuries involve the traumatic separation of skin and subcutaneous fat from the underlying fascia. These injuries occur when significant force is applied that tears the skin and subcutaneous tissues away from the fascia, leaving deeper structures like muscles and tendons exposed only in more severe cases. This type of injury is often seen in severe accidents where shearing forces or high degrees of friction are involved, such as in motor vehicle accidents or industrial mishaps.

 

 

Degloving Injury

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Skin, subcutaneous fat and fascia are stripped from tendons: This is not the typical presentation for a de-gloving injury as it usually does not involve detachment of the fascia from the tendons. De-gloving primarily affects the more superficial layers — the skin and the subcutaneous fat.

 

Option C. Skin, subcutaneous fat, fascia and tendons are stripped from bone: This describes a more extensive avulsion than typical de-gloving and involves deeper structures including tendons and potentially even bone, which is beyond the classic definition of a de-gloving injury.

 

Option D. Only skin is stripped off: This choice does not accurately describe de-gloving injuries as they involve not only the skin but also the subcutaneous fat layer; both are separated from the underlying fascia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

De-gloving injuries are characterized by the stripping away of skin and subcutaneous fat from the underlying fascia, usually due to high-force impacts or abrasive injuries. These injuries can vary in severity and often require complex and multiple surgical interventions to manage, including assessments of tissue viability, possible debridement, and reconstructive procedures to restore function and appearance. Understanding the typical layers involved and the mechanism of injury is crucial for appropriate clinical management.

choices.text: Persistently depolarizing at neuromuscular junction
Competitively blocking the binding of ACh to its receptors
Repetitive stimulation of ACh receptors on muscle endplate
Inhibiting the calcium channels on presynaptic membrane

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of the curare group of muscle relaxants?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Competitively blocking the binding of ACh to its receptors

 

The curare group of muscle relaxants functions by competitively blocking the binding of acetylcholine (ACh) to its receptors at the neuromuscular junction. This action prevents acetylcholine from exerting its effect, leading to muscle relaxation by inhibiting neuronal transmission to muscles. These agents are categorized as non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents, distinguishing them from depolarizing types like Succinylcholine. The blockade is competitive, meaning that these agents and acetylcholine compete for the same binding sites on the ACh receptors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Persistently depolarizing at neuromuscular junction: Incorrect as this describes the mechanism of depolarizing muscle relaxants like Succinylcholine, not the non-depolarizing curare group.

 

Option C. Repetitive stimulation of ACh receptors on muscle endplate: Incorrect because this is not characteristic of curare-like drugs; repetitive stimulation of ACh receptors is more aligned with the depolarizing type of action.

 

Option D. Inhibiting the calcium channels on presynaptic membrane: Incorrect as curare-like drugs do not work by affecting calcium channels directly; their primary mechanism is competitive inhibition at the ACh receptor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The curare group of muscle relaxants are non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents that work by competitively inhibiting the action of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, preventing muscle contraction. This knowledge is essential for understanding how various types of muscle relaxants are used in clinical settings to achieve muscle relaxation during surgical procedures.

choices.text: Clinical assessment is unreliable
Most common clinical presentation is pain and tenderness in calf
Some cases may directly present as pulmonary thromboembolism

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding deep vein thrombosis (DVT)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mostly bilateral

 

The statement that DVT is "mostly bilateral" is false. Most cases of deep vein thrombosis are unilateral, affecting only one leg, with bilateral DVT occurring in about 30% of individuals. DVT predominantly occurs in the pelvic and leg veins, specifically the femoral and popliteal veins, and is more commonly found on the left side.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clinical assessment is unreliable: This statement is true. Clinical features alone are unreliable for diagnosing DVT due to variability in symptoms and signs, which is why diagnostic imaging, like venous Doppler ultrasound, is necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Option C. Most common clinical presentation is pain and tenderness in calf: This is true as pain and tenderness in the calf, often accompanied by swelling and warmth, are typical presenting symptoms of DVT.

 

Option D. Some cases may directly present as pulmonary thromboembolism: This is also true. A thrombus formed in the deep veins can dislodge and travel to the lungs, causing a pulmonary embolism, which may present with symptoms such as shortness of breath, chest pain, and rapid breathing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Deep vein thrombosis is more commonly a unilateral condition. Diagnostic certainty requires imaging studies due to the unreliable nature of clinical assessment alone. Awareness of its possible complication of pulmonary embolism is crucial for timely management and prevention of severe outcomes.

questions.text: What neurological condition is caused by thrombosis of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lateral medullary syndrome

 

Thrombosis of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) typically results in Lateral Medullary Syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome. This syndrome arises due to the compromised blood flow to the lateral part of the medulla oblongata, which is the area supplied by the PICA. Clinically, this presents with symptoms such as contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation on the body, ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation on the face, ataxia, nystagmus, vertigo, Horner's syndrome, dysphagia, ipsilateral bulbar palsy, and loss of the gag reflex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Weber syndrome: Incorrect. Weber syndrome is related to pathology in the posterior cerebral artery, which affects the midbrain, leading to ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy and contralateral hemiplegia.

 

Option C. Medial medullary syndrome: Incorrect. This syndrome is associated with disruption of the vertebral artery or anterior spinal artery, impacting the medial part of the medulla. It presents with contralateral paralysis of the body and ipsilateral paralysis of the tongue.

 

Option D. Millard Gubler syndrome: Incorrect. This involves vascular issues within the pons, resulting in facial nerve paralysis and contralateral hemiplegia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lateral Medullary Syndrome caused by thrombosis of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery, is crucial in diagnosing and managing stroke cases effectively.

questions.text: A patient presents with frequent urination, nocturia, and enuresis. 24-hour urine volume was measured and recorded to be 7 liters. The urine osmolarity was 260 mOsm/L. ADH assay was performed and the recorded values were reported as 0.8 pg/ml. An MRI of the brain was performed and T1 weighted indicated the absence of the bright spot. What is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pituitary DI

 

The presentation suggests Pituitary Diabetes Insipidus (DI), characterized by a primary deficiency of ADH (Antidiuretic Hormone) secretion. The patient's low ADH level (0.8 pg/ml) alongside the high urine output (polyuria) and low urine osmolarity (260 mOsm/L) supports this diagnosis. Additionally, the absence of the bright spot on T1-weighted MRI, which typically indicates the posterior pituitary, further points to a central (pituitary) origin of the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nephrogenic DI: Incorrect because, in nephrogenic DI, ADH levels are typically normal or elevated as the kidneys do not respond to ADH; the condition is not associated with an absent pituitary bright spot on MRI.

 

Option B. Primary polydipsia: Incorrect, as primary polydipsia typically presents with low ADH due to excessive fluid intake suppressing ADH secretion, but a pituitary bright spot would still be present.

 

Option D. Mannitol infusion: Incorrect because mannitol infusion would typically increase urine osmolality due to the osmotic effect of mannitol, which is not observed here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pituitary Diabetes Insipidus is diagnosed by the presence of low ADH levels, high urine output with low osmolarity, and absence of the posterior pituitary bright spot on MRI. Treatment typically involves the administration of synthetic ADH, such as Desmopressin.

choices.text: Profound feelings of guilt over trivial events

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of melancholia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sleep-onset insomnia

 

Sleep-onset insomnia is not typically a feature of melancholia. Melancholia, a term historically used in psychiatry to describe severe depressive states, commonly includes symptoms such as severe anhedonia, profound feelings of inappropriate guilt, significant weight loss, and early morning awakening or terminal insomnia rather than difficulty falling asleep at the beginning of the night. Sleep-onset insomnia is more characteristic of anxiety disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Severe anhedonia: Incorrect as an option for "not a feature" because severe anhedonia is indeed a hallmark of melancholia, where individuals experience a profound loss of pleasure in almost all activities.

 

Option B. Weight loss: Incorrect for "not a feature" as weight loss is commonly observed in melancholia due to decreased appetite or neglect of personal care.

 

Option D. Profound feelings of guilt over trivial events: Incorrect for "not a feature" because inappropriate or excessive feelings of guilt, often about matters that would not normally cause guilt, are a typical symptom of melancholia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Melancholia is characterized by early morning awakening rather than initial difficulties in falling asleep, alongside severe anhedonia, significant weight loss, and profound guilt.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy had painful sores in the mouth with a rash over the hands along with fever. Which of these is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coxsackievirus

 

The described symptoms of fever, painful sores in the mouth, and rash on the hands and feet are indicative of hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD). The most common viral cause of HFMD worldwide is Coxsackievirus A16. This virus leads to the development of characteristic small, tense vesicles with surrounding erythema on the palms and soles, along with oral lesions that are less painful than aphthous ulcers. The spread of this infection is typically via droplets or fecal contamination, and the incubation period is around 7 days.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pox virus: Incorrect, as pox viruses cause diseases like smallpox and molluscum contagiosum, which are clinically distinct from HFMD.

 

Option C. HHV-7: Incorrect, as Human Herpesvirus 7 generally causes roseola, a condition different from HFMD and characterized by high fever and a rash, but not typically localized to hands and feet or presenting with oral ulcers.

 

Option D. Parvovirus: Incorrect, as Parvovirus B19 causes fifth disease, which presents with a "slapped cheek" appearance and a lacy rash on the body, not the specific symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coxsackievirus, particularly type A16, is the typical viral cause of hand-foot-and-mouth disease, characterized by fever, vesicular eruptions on the palms and soles, and painful oral lesions. Management is primarily supportive, focusing on symptomatic relief, and the condition usually resolves within 7 to 10 days.

questions.text: Calculate the therapeutic index of a drug whose dose-response curves are plotted as shown below:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4

 

The therapeutic index (TI) is calculated using the formula

 

TI=LD50/ED50

 

where LD50 is the dose at which 50% of the population experiences a lethal outcome and ED50 is the dose at which 50% of the population achieves the desired therapeutic effect. From the provided graph:

 

  • ED50 (Effective Dose 50%) is 100 mg, indicating the dose at which 50% of the population responds with the desired therapeutic effect (hypnosis).
  • LD50 (Lethal Dose 50%) is 400 mg, indicating the dose at which 50% of the population is expected to die as a result of the drug.

 

Calculation

 

Therapeutic index (TI)=LD50/ ED50 = 400/ 100 = 4

 

This value of 4 implies that the lethal dose is four times the effective dose, providing a quantitative measure of the drug's safety margin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The therapeutic index indicates the safety margin of a drug. A TI of 4 means that the drug's lethal dose is four times its effective dose, offering some degree of safety in dosing errors before reaching toxic levels. This index helps guide clinical use, emphasizing the importance of dosage accuracy for safety.

questions.text: You notice the following appearance in the X-ray of a patient. Which of the following conditions is the least likely cause for this?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acute intestinal obstruction

 

The X-ray provided shows the presence of gas under both diaphragms, indicative of pneumoperitoneum, which typically does not occur in cases of acute intestinal obstruction unless there is an associated perforation. Acute intestinal obstruction primarily presents with signs such as multiple dilated loops of bowel and air-fluid levels, rather than the extensive free air under the diaphragm seen in this X-ray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenal ulcer perforation: This is more likely to cause pneumoperitoneum due to perforation of the ulcer, leading to escape of air into the peritoneal cavity.

 

Option B. Post laparoscopy status: It's common to find residual free air in the abdomen following laparoscopic procedures, which can persist up to several days post-operation.

 

Option C. Chilaiditi syndrome: This can mimic pneumoperitoneum on X-ray as it involves interposition of bowel between the liver and diaphragm, but usually does not involve actual free air in the peritoneal cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When observing a pneumoperitoneum on an X-ray, acute intestinal obstruction is the least likely cause unless it is complicated by bowel perforation. In clinical practice, distinguishing the source of pneumoperitoneum is crucial as it can significantly influence the management approach, including the urgency and type of surgical intervention required.

choices.text: Fat embolism syndrome following femur shaft fracture

questions.text: Which of the following does not lead to Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) at the blood-lung interface?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pneumonia

 

Pneumonia typically leads to ARDS through damage at the air-lung interface rather than the blood-lung interface. It causes direct injury to the alveoli and the air spaces, leading to inflammation and accumulation of inflammatory cells which in turn causes the alveoli to fill with fluid, impairing gas exchange.

 

 

X-ray showing Bilateral alveolar infiltrates as seen in ARDS

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fat embolism syndrome following femur shaft fracture: This can cause ARDS at the blood-lung interface by introducing fat globules into the bloodstream which then lodge in the pulmonary capillaries, causing local inflammation and potentially leading to ARDS.

 

Option C. Sepsis: Sepsis is a common cause of ARDS at the blood-lung interface as it involves systemic inflammation that leads to widespread capillary leak and acute lung injury.

 

Option D. Transfusion-related lung injury: This is another cause of ARDS at the blood-lung interface, typically triggered by an immune reaction to blood transfusions that results in acute lung inflammation and injury.

 

Educational Objective:
